reviewText:
I had doubts about whether I would be able to enjoy this after playing Firaxis's XCOM, but boy was I wrong. If you've enjoyed the challenge the original Julian Gollop's X-COM provided, Xenonauts is going to delight your socks off.

The dev team behind it have come a long way and have learnt quite a few lessons from other X-COM spiritual successors released before it. This shows as a much more fine tuned balance between being able to micromanage while still feeling like the overall commander-in-charge of your organisation. The oppressive feeling of a world unsure of your ability to deliver its salvation adds to the atmosphere of urgency, uncertainty, dread and hope all at once. Planetary Defence Simulator indeed.

Highly recommended!

reviewText:
By the time of this review I have played around 40 hours/TLDR: BUY THIS GAME!

The game opens with a world map and the ability to place a single base which will give you radar coverage and a few planes. From there your job is to build many bases and cover the landmasses of earth with air protection while sending out your ground teams to clear out alien crashsites and defend cities.

It is incredibly deep, from the customization of each soldier which ranks up over time; to the building and upgrading of bases which have much more than just hangars for your different planes.

This game also has a much richer gameplay than its more ''AAA'' counterpart XCOM albeit it does have much simpler graphics.

Really the only two things that could disuade you from buying it are the retro graphics and the isometric view of the maps.


P.S: This game has a huge amount of mod support and a growing mod scene with at least 5 complete mods that change completly the way the game is played and about a 100 smaller mods. It is growing everyday.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

All right, first things first; I would say (largely) discount the negative reviews. (Apparently some folks still don't yet understand how the concept of 'Early Access' works.) That being said, if you're the kind of person who might agree with those people, I would wholeheartedly recommend waiting until after development is completed to pick up (or at the very least, play) your own copy of Xenonauts. Goldhawk has been releasing updates with fair regularity, the game has been getting better and more complete each time, and they are currently very close (I'd venture to guess somewhere around 90%, give or take 5% or so) to having the game ready for its final update.

Is Xenonauts X-COM? No. (Of course, if you asked me if the most recent X-COM was X-COM, you'd get the same answer. I thought Firaxis did an interesting job with Enemy Unknown, it's just not the X-COM I grew up with.) Again, that being said, Xenonauts is the game that comes closest to emulating the feel of the original X-COM that I have ever seen. There have been many, many, MANY attempts at recapturing that brutal magic over the years; many have been interesting, some even enjoyable, but none that I felt were truly close. You can tell that this game was designed by people who clearly played the original game to death. Put the cosmetic differences aside, and it still *looks* like X-COM, and it *feels* like X-COM.

In its raw, unmodified state, the game is difficult - I'd even be willing to say brutally so. (I personally went to the trouble of digging into the data files to give myself a bit of a New Game+, just so I wouldn't lose entire funding regions within the first hour of play. Oh yeah, btw - this game is moddable. The data files are somewhat dense, but with some time and effort, you can modify quite a bit.) The original UFO Defense experience of having troops plasma-blasted to death instantly upon leaving the transport can and does happen. Also included is that feeling of finally having a leg up on the initial alien opponents when you research better weapons and armor - only to have a whole new group of enemies show up and proceed to lay waste to your crack troops with the same level of ease. The UFOs will have an even bigger field day against your interceptors if you let them - they get progressively bigger and nastier and will seem to simply shrug off hits from even your biggest guns.

The graphics, while not nearly as rendered and flashy as Enemy Unknown's, are still a huge leg-up from the original game's, and the interface is familiar without being clunky. The game's 1970's Cold War setting actually plays well with the alien invasion theme and helps many of the other design decisions and features to make sense as well. Almost everything that makes up the base of this game has been pulled almost directly from the concepts behind the original UFO Defense, from the basebuilding, tech, and tactical mechanics to the enemies and the weapons. Yes, the UFOs and interceptors look unique and different, there are more types of armor and weapons, and some of the aliens look different and have unique names - but Enemy Unknown did much the same thing, albeit to a lesser extent.

Xenonauts really shines in the areas where it makes improvements on the base gameplay from the original game. Air combat in Xenonauts is how air combat in Enemy Unknown should have been - interactive and fully tactical. Just like in the ground combat missions, what happens to your aircraft is entirely on you - make a mistake, and your planes will be shot down, potentially leaving that region of the world defenseless against the next alien attack. Xenonauts also improves on the tactical missions by including local armed forces on the ground combat maps, a genuine cover system, and more transparency in exactly how your troops' physical skills improve at the end of each mission.

This game is definitely worth picking up if you are a die-hard fan of old-school X-COM, or if you just like deep, challenging strategy games in general. Oh, and did I mention that you can mod it? Just imagine, an X-COM-like that you can customize to your own liking. Make it easier, make it harder, make it so you can sell alien corpses to museums - whatever you like. It can be done. Remember, with your help, Earth CAN survive the alien invasion! Now get out there and do your part, soldier!

reviewText:
If you're looking for a newer version of the widely renowned original XCOM: UFO Defense, you've come to the right spot! If you've never heard of XCOM, think the original was released in 2012, or came looking for a new strategy game that keeps you on your toes, you've come to the right spot as well! This game successfully meshes turn-based squad combat with a reaserch / funding / air combat strategy layer to keep you thinking about everything you do. I'd heartily reccommend this to anybody with an eye for such games, although be warned, the game is no A to B cakewalk... 9 / 10 I think it's worth $30 personally, but if you're on a tight budget, grab this if it ever goes on sale for $20 or less.

I'll assume your read the game description, so I'll spare you the back story and get right down to the gameplay. In the geoscape (the world map view), players control bases and their facilities:  equipping soldiers, researching, manufacturing, managing planes, and managing resources. From here, the goal is mainly to send dropships to crashed / landed ufos or alien bases in order to slow the invasion. The air combat is nice, but not too deep, and is usually resolved based on the tech you have unlocked more than skill (although there are already fancy mods to make this more skill based). These dogfights can be autoresolved if they aren't your bag of tea. The difficulty chosen affects the rate at which the invasion progresses on the geoscape. Although certainly a nice way to progress the game, the geoscape isn't where you spend most of your time.

That place would be the battlescape (the turnbased squad combat). This section of the game is incredible. Each unit is given time units to spend on its turn that let it act (all actions require different amounts of TUs) and the remainder of those are used to react to the aliens on their turn. Combat is highly tactical, and the differences in difficulty are most noticed here. The AI is extremely intelligent. The enemy is stronger and heartier than your troops, not to mention extremely intelligent. As the invasion progresses, so will their tech, alien / ufos composition, and numbers. Once killed, soldiers are gone forever, and this gives each firefight a nervous tension (The ironman mode continuously saves your actions to improve this feeling if you enjoy it). Never before has a game made me think so thuroughly during a turn as Xenonauts because of this.

The downsides? It's an indie game, so it's not to fancy visually. That said, it still has some incredibly detailed and hand painted sprites. At the time of writing, the game just got out of early access, and it still has one or two bugs two work out. On top of that, some oddities occur due simply to the engine constraints of the game. Beyond that, there really isn't anything to complain about, and my gameplays have been pretty smooth! The game is easily moddable by fiddling with the xml files (doable using notepad), and a nice handful of talented map makers have already begun adding maps to the game. The maps in this game are semi-random, so after multiple playthroughs, you will undoubtably see similar looking maps, and the ones the community makes keeps the game nice and fresh!

I trust that if you were an XCOM fan, you'd already have bought this - if not, you should just stop reading and do that. So to all those who have never experienced the thrill of XCOM - the thrill of defending the Earth from an invasion of unknown magnitude and power with technology you prioritized, researched, and manufactured so you could give them to men and women you armed, commanded, and lost - this is a great place to start.

The success of your defense efforts determines how well your program is funded as the game progresses. reviewText:
As a veteran of X-COM UFO Defense, Terror of the Deep, Apocolypse as well as the more recent remake XCOM Enemy Unknown/Enemy Within, I was very excited to play this.

I just finished it on Normal difficulty and I have to say I'm disappointed.

While its extremely faithful to the original (UFO Defense) and improves several things which I'll list in a bit, this iteration did not have the same charm as the original. While the finale was abrupt just like the original, it offered even less closure if thats possible.

The gameplay was very similar to the original.

PROs:

-Riot Shields offered new options for troop deployment
-Weapon diversification worked very nicely. In the original you could easily get by with everyone just using rifles.
-Some UI improvements
-Research flavor text was amusing

CONs:

-Manually controlling the interception portion of the game wasn't fun. I wound up auto-resolving all of them after some time.
-Music was atmospheric like the original, but wasn't as good. Some parts were extremely noisy and hard on your ears. Yes its supposed to be unsettling but it was almost painful.
-Time period: While an interesting idea I don't think it did enough with the concept. It was basically just a different art style.
-Lack of psionic attacks

A nice change of pace from the original...but not one I'd play again.

What I wanted was just the same X-Com UFO Defense with a better interface, and this failed to meet my expectations.
But if you enjoy UFO Defense, theres no reason you won't enjoy this.

I'm just disappointed it didn't offer more.

6/10

reviewText: The true spiritual successor to the fabled original  UFO: Enemy Unknown from 1994\n\nWhile the recent 3D XCOM: Enemy Unknown by Firaxis was a decent game in itself and has some great ideas it was very limited (Or streamlined")
date: especially in terms of the strategic side of the game where things like base building and base missions were markedly absent (And the scripted one from Enemy Within doesn't count :p ).\n\nThis game has it all
recommended:
I cannot see a feature missing from the original game that is not implemented in this one. Think the 1994 version lovingly re-implemented with modern tech and a fun little UFO interception mini-game.

There is also some great writing in the research reports etc. which give character to otherwise static screens.

Downsides? The graphics are not great (But then you do not care about that do you?) and the tactical map selection can be limited. There is a solution to the second issue in that this game is moddable and there are already map-pack mods out there to increase selection.

Im summary: The main thing is... I actually feel like the boss of an organisation dedicated to protecting humanity from the Aliens and making tough decisions rather than a spare tyre like in the recent remake.

Massive thumbs up."

reviewText: Hey, remember X-COM: UFO Defense? Well, Xenonauts is like that. A lot like that, actually. reviewText:
If you're ok with running a whole agency and doing squad based missions this game is for you. If you dont want to manage a bunch of cash, buildings, personnel while inbetween, carefully attacking any alien ships you shoot down to loot them for technology. Then go for something a bit faster paced. This remake has a slower reward system more like the older xcoms than the new ones.

As a fan of around 1000 hours of the original Xcoms on floppy disk and finishing my first game (and loss) of this new Xenonauts i can summarise a review of it as: Quite good.

Cons :

Clunky UI at times, world map is not always smooth to navigate around.
Isometric engine is a bit clunky and cant change angle
Maps are not radomised!  unlike in the original (a tiny Xcom coding team accomplished that 20 years ago)
Open Xcom (is free) and might be viable within a year (maybe?)

Pros:

Despite what the devs claim, this certainly is a clone of the original Xcom: UFO defence. And a good one,

Music is spooky, the ambient sounds.. are spooky. Artwork, is awesome. The graphics look dated but the style is consistent and feels like you're running a secret agency during the cold war.

streamlined features like not having to re-buy ammo for standard issue equipment after each mission you send your poor troops on.

Overall:

Great remake, makes you think and the game depth gives good immersion if you have the time. Interface is a bit clunky.

reviewText:
I never played the original XCOM; despite that, I love the genre, and played more Fallout Tactics and Chaos Gate than I care to think about, as well as more modern games like Silent Storm. This is to say that I'm viewing Xenonauts on its own merits and not colored by any association with its spiritual predecessor.

There's a lot to like here, and some parts of this game I'm really fond of. I like the setting, with retooled F-16s and MiGs giving things vague Independence Day vibes. The strategic game is fun, establishing bases, managing personnel and research projects, and dispatching interceptors to engage UFOs. Some might find the micromanagement of every soldier and every F-16 a little fiddly, but I enjoy it. The overall atmosphere is intriguing and the basic premise of defending Earth from alien scum is a classic.

Unfortunately, that's where the good ends. Manual air combat is lackluster, feeling unresponsive and offering few options other than to bring more firepower to the table and win the resulting slugging match. This is only a minor complaint, however, as it serves its purpose and air combats can be autoresolved if one wishes.

Ground combat is where I was truly disappointed. Again, I don't care if it's faithful" to a 1994 game or not
date: this game came out in 2014 and those are the standards I hold it to. At first glance
recommended: it seemed a little reminiscent of Silent Storm
hoursPlayed: with action points (TUs) and Snap Shots
voteText: Aimed Shots

votesHelpful: etc. It lacks Silent Storm's depth

votesFunny: and yet also somehow manages to exacerbate Silent Storm's worst flaws of unfathomable line-of-sight/vision/detection rules

reviewText:
Xenonauts started development before XCOM: Enemy Unknown was even announced to the public. It aimed to be a modern day remake of the original 'XCOM: UFO Defense', also know as 'UFO: Enemy Unknown' in Europe.

Xenonauts has stayed true to the original, plus expanded on it. Everything that was great about the original XCOM is here and even better. The UI is very nice and clean, Air and Ground Combat both feel great, and base/research/production management is very fun as well.

Edit 1: Now that the game is released, I can finish this review. From when I first made this review, there's been quite a few changes and much balancing, which made an already fun TBS even more so. My only real complaint is that the soldiers stat generation has had its minimum lowered, so when starting a new game or recruiting a new soldier, you often get soldiers with annoyingly low Time Units(TU for short).

The only saving grace is that they changed how much TU's shooting costs. Instead of a flat number, it's a percentage of their max TU's. This means that no matter how few TU's you have, you can still rally off as many shots as a high TU character. However, movement TU cost is still a flat number, so low TU will greatly restrict how far you can go, and if you want to shoot and move, you'll have a hard time with low TU's.

They also nerfed some of the armor and the shield. The shield is the biggest in my opinion. I used to love having two soldiers with shields, but with its small nerf, they start to become a liability far sooner than before. There IS a shield upgrade, but you get that option LONG after the first shield becomes a liability. Doesn't help that they nerfed the pistol pretty hard too.

With the release version I tend to drop the shield pretty quickly, and I rarely use the pistol due to its poor accuracy and range.

Anyway, enough with complaining. Despite the whining, this game is still incredible. If you like XCOM and/or Turn Based Strategy games, then this is definitely a game you'll need to pick up.

Edit 2: I made a mistake in the first paragraph. Xenonauts was not announced before XCOM: Enemy Unknown.

reviewText:
Gist of the game:

Build air bases around the world to try to achieve air supremecy over nations so they continue to fund you.

Recruit and equip ground troops to investigate crash sites, enemy bases, and alien terror attacks.

Perform research and to learn about the aliens and build new advanced planes and battlefield support equipment (guns/tanks/armor)

Manage budget and upkeep over investments in winning on the battlefield VS winning in the air.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
What got me to recommend the gmae:

I. Ground combat feels dynamic;

Alien got your squad penned down? Blast a hole in the wall with c4 and flank him!
Use machine gunners and flash grenades to suppress enemies.
Use anti-ballistic shield to make an assault on an alien UFO.
Do you toss c4 and rockets into the UFO to soften up the enemy or do you go in without the explosives in order to salvage alien items?
One wrong turn (the ground combat is turned based) in which you leave soldiers exposed in the open leaves the possibility that one alien machine gunner can mow down half your squad.
Many different kinds of grenades with different uses.
Fight a diverse variety (but not excessive) of aliens.

II. Somewhat dynamic air battles

just go watch a youtube video for this one.
The air battles are fun but sometimes very repetitive.

III. Difficulty

I like the difficulty a lot. The game has 4 options I believe: easy, normal, hard, insane.
I play on normal and it is very much a fun challenge. I have to do a lot of thinking.

Overall:

I predict this game is an instant classic and will be played long after its release for many years.

9.5/10

i put 9.5 instead of 10 because I think multiplayer ground combat would be really awesome and I think air combat is neat however it maybe could have been done better

reviewText:
Tactical turn-based squad combat within spitting distance of its finest.

The upsides:
The time unit system, inspired by the original X-COM. If your soldiers are fast, they can shoot their weapon several times, then run. Or shoot and move and shoot again.

The overwatch system. You just point your soldiers in the right direction and leave them some time units, and they'll shoot reactively when they see something.

Research. This could be better integrated, but the basic idea is that you need to acquire specific alien technology to study and thereby improve your equipment.

Difficulty levels. I'm playing on easy right now, and it is in fact easy. A small challenge in places, but if I'm a bit careful, I don't lose soldiers. Higher difficulty levels are progressively harder and require more care to get through.

The midsides:
Enemy variety is okay. You've got normal mooks, regenerating enemies, androids, reavers (scary), fliers, and psions (also scary). Enough to keep you on your toes, but I rarely see much difference between androids and baseline Caesians.

Weapon variety is a strict progression on one axis, with different purposes on another. Shotgun to scatter laser, for instance; rifle to laser rifle to plasma rifle. Armor progression is similar at first, but branches out a bit later, letting you choose between medium armor, flying scout armor, and walking tanks. The variety is just sufficient, no more.

The controls are mostly intuitive -- but who thinks about controls unless they're bad?

There's a decent number of maps, but you'll start recognizing them after a bit. For standard missions, I think there's like industrial, city, arctic, farmland, and desert, with about three maps each. That means you've got good odds of seeing a duplicate after just a few missions. And terror missions always take place in a city. Enemy bases have more variety, but you're not likely to see that many alien bases. I would have liked to see procedurally generated terrain, but that's difficult and time-consuming to create.

The downsides:
The UI is a little clunky for switching between levels (upstairs/downstairs).

There are occasional bugs -- the other day, I encountered a ghost Caesian. It wasn't aligned on tile boundaries, my soldiers could overlap it, and I couldn't shoot it. I had to run away. There are occasional crashes, too. Not quite stable enough for me to recommend ironman mode.

It's somewhat expected in this kind of game, but losses can snowball. You spent a lot of time building up your forces, then got a full team wipe and lost half your equipment in a bad mission. At that point, you should maybe scrub the campaign and start over. You research things in the wrong order and things get a lot more difficult than they would otherwise be.

reviewText:
A wonderfully well made remake of the original X-com: enemy unknown.

Apart from some minor UI grievances this is a very solid squad based tactical figting game. The maps are varied enough to not feel like too much of a repeat (especially compared to Firaxis' remake, where you constantly fight on exactly the same maps).

One jewel, that I feel immensely improves this game compared to the original is the introduction of the shield units (a person who carries a heavy shield and therefore can carry almost nothinng but a hand gun). It makes those what is hiding around the next corner"- and "breaching the spaceship"-situations so much less random since you have troops designed to soak a bit of damage.

Very recommendable."

reviewText:
As of writing this, Goldhawk Interactive (devs) are in the making of a sequel. I say this to raise awareness if you find yourself buying this game and enjoying it, as they've taken huge steps in listening to and incorporating feedback from the community.

-----------------------------------------------------

First off, it's inevitable that XCOM will be mentioned at some point, so lets start there. Yes, you're likely to enjoy this if you enjoyed the original XCOM games. Xenonauts began as a passion project on Kickstarter for those wanting to relive the original XCOM experience. It stays mostly true to XCOM without replicating it, even expanding on originally lacking features like interceptor combat, which is now much more involved.

Some elements of this game work in real-time (aerial combat, although you can pause), but the majority of your time (~85%) will be spent in grounded, turn-based missions. I should mention that both ground and aerial combat missions are skip-able, but of course you'll miss out on a lot of resources if you decide to pass on them. There  are  workshop (cheat) mods out there that allow you to essentially skip areas of gameplay you might not enjoy, so if you find yourself wanting to focus on the ground-based missions for example and ignore the Geoscape, you can pretty much do that.

About aerial combat: it is, in my opinion, not that great. It's not particularly bad, but it doesn't feel fleshed out beyond the dodge and missile mechanics. I tend to think of it more like an optional mini-game that gives you a break from other points of strategy every now and then. On a normal run I found myself skipping most aerial combat scenarios with little to no penalty for doing so, and apparently that's fine. Although I didn't enjoy it personally, I'm glad I was given the option to skip it as seems a more experimental point of gameplay compared to everything else.

Ground combat is brilliant, and most things in the Geoscape are brilliant. You'll need patience and time to plan out your approach to the alien invasion, particularly since this game is a multifaceted strategy. By the end, you'll probably be managing several bases and many troops/employers/vehicles at the same time. For those reasons, this might be a game you need to stick to before moving on, and certainly not play if you're an amnesiac. That would leave you with an overwhelming amount of management to do and no memory on how to do it. Also, if you like your micro/macro organisation, you'll fall in love with this. In the micro sense for example, each soldier can be personalized by name and load-out (there's a pretty huge arsenal if you research weapons), with class-specific types you can set as defaults. One thing that's lacking which affects both ground combat and the Geoscape, is vehicles. Only one vehicle variant exists in this game and it requires a hefty amount of resources to get up and running. But... is it worth it? No. Even when you acquire it, you sacrifice two soldiers in exchange for having it on the ground. Unfortunately it isn't even worth two soldiers. In short, vehicles are pretty underdeveloped in this game and almost not worth bothering about. You can upgrade it into pure bad-assery way later on, but the climb to get there isn't economically efficient.
Another flaw: monsters and civilians sometimes have stupid AI. Aliens tend to be at their most deadly when they're throwing grenades at you non-stop, and the AI still has issues with pathing and awareness, as it tends to know where you are half the time without a good reason as to why. I was able to ignore these issues as the experience was mostly fluid.
Oh, as a side note; pretty much everything in ground combat is destructible.

My lord, the writing. It is monstrously good, and might honestly be the best experience with reading I've ever had in a game ever. And normally I  hate  taking time to read in games. Hell, Xenonauts even comes with it's own novella, yes, a freaking  novella  hidden away in the extra features. Now, I don't think it compares to the in-game text you get for completing research projects, but it's still kind of impressive that they actually hired an author to do it. One of the major things keeping me coming back to this game was the thought of completing a research project and being handed a bit more information of the alien invasion.


SO, I recommend this game. It's worth the price, but most of all it's a lot of fun. A lot of issues posted in top reviews have been fixed/have fixes for download or are already within the game but need to be enabled. I suggest that upon starting the game you click the mod manager and enable the mod already downloaded which adds a ton of map variety.
I'll close out saying Xenonauts has a lot of really awesome mods in the Steam workshop section, so at the very least give it a glance over before or after playing for your first time. The community is regularly patching this with updates even after the devs recently stopped, so there's also a community build if you switch over to beta.

|---To put it simply, the spirit of X-Com lives here---|

Forget about fancy 3D glowy effects, forget about automatic cover usage. Forget about anything XCOM: Enemy Unknown did to make the serie more accessible.

This is basically UFO: Enemy Unknown reimagined in a cold war setting, with a proper air combat mode, a new interface, great arts (in crisp, high definition isometric 2D) and 5 years in the making.

reviewText:
Rarely do I drop cash on a game when its fully priced. But with Xenonauts I broke that trend, and the defilement team deserves every penny. The game is a brilliant spiritual successor to X-Com. It has its improvements over the original games, however any seasoned veteran of the games will be able to take to this as if they were right at home.

The new and improved air combat system is also a welcome addition. Though at times it can seem a bit dumb, having to micro your ships to fly directly at the enemy ships is a bit weird (when you click on them they adjust to their flight path but that's rarely what you want)

I would suggest anyone who lives X-Com buy this game. If you don't like the originals however, this game is not for you. It is every bit as difficult as the originals and every bit as nail biting.

reviewText: If you are a fan of the original UFO:Enemy Unknown (AKA X-Com:UFO Defence), then know that I used to play it from time to time until 2013, when I found Xenonauts, and since then I can't really play the original game anymore. The simplest way to describe Xenonauts is that it keeps the spirit of the original game and adds many improvements.\n\nIf the only game related to X-Com games you know is Firaxis XCOM, then know that XCOM doesn't really have much in common with the original game, despite the name, as at the core they are fundamentally different games. Asking which one is better is like asking whether apples or steaks taste better - some will like one better, some the other, and some will like both while knowing that they are simply different. And the same applies to XCOM and Xenonauts, they are different, and whatever you learn when playing XCOM is best to forget when playing Xenonauts. XCOM is like a Hollywood action move: It's flashy, with explosions, brave superheroes who eventually defeat the aliens with style while uttering their lines, avenging their fallen mates who the aliens had the nerves to inevitably kill early on. And if you like action movies, it doesn't really matter that it's cliched, gamey, doesn't often make much sense, and is hardly Enemy Unknown" when somebody pops up to explain everything three times the moment you encounter something new. Xenonauts is like a thriller: You don't really know what is going on

reviewText: It plays like X-COM without being a direct copy of X-COM.  Xenonauts offers you a lot more in the way of tactical planning and decision making, while still leaving room for you to fall into your own pattern and strategy for successful missions.  The variety of weapons is a huge upgrade from X-COM's typical Pistol/Rifle/Heavy weapon, and the balance between the weapons is pretty spot-on; you can use whatever you like, provided you plan accordingly, a strike team of pure pistol-wielding xenonauts is totally viable.\n\nThe research text is flavorful and a nice addition, immersing you more in the world and the reality of the invasion while still offering some form of believability.  The geoscape is far more lively, with alien activity being broadcasted as casualty reports" around the globe when left unchecked

reviewText:
I just finished the Vanilla version (no-mods) of the game with patch-level 1.59 so following comments apply to this kind of setup.

Xenonauts is a good (almost great) remake of the original X-Com (in Europe Ufo - Enemy Unknown) classic. It took me approx. 30 hours to complete the game on easy difficulty. 75 % this time was quality gaming - 25 % was boring grinding with too familiar ground maps.

Almost all the areas work well and all in all I like this game more than Firaxis version which I played last year.

I only have following negative comments about the game and I guess most of these might be issues which could be fixed with mods:
Repetitive maps (you get way too familiar with the maps after hours of grinding them)
Psionics and the lack of countermeasures for psi-powers. Aliens can take control of your soldiers and you cannot do literally anything for this. In original series you were able to have your own psi-soldiers and also equipment which helped against psi-powers
Reapers and ship invasions (when you storm downed enemy ships the reapers and their 100% kill-rate-attack gets so boring after they use the teleport elevators to kill you soldiers)
Too narrow tech tree (more stuff to research would be nice)
Air Combat balance. Too difficult in the beginning and too easy in the end. Also the actual air-combat mini-game is not so nice and I used automatic all the time
Soldier development. You cannot influence how soldiers improve and you as you cannot influence what skills and attributes you get you don't get attached to your team (I only noticed who had the most time units - rest of the attributes in my team were pretty much a black box" to me)"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While the new XCOM: ENEMY UNKNOWN is a good continuation of the XCOM franchise many of us enjoyed so much, Xenonauts stays truer to the older X-COM games. While there are a few thematic differences - the cold war era, and the names of organisations, aliens and objects being different (copyright evasion powers activate) - the game plays in an almost identical way - you can have multiple bases and troop craft, the interceptions are more interactive and still good, bases are viewed from above - and the tactical combat keeps up the level of tension fans will be wanting.

I also want to praise the addition of civilian combatants. They're not amazing, but sometimes it's nice to see the rest of the world fight back.

There are a couple of UI issues that need to be resolved, but nothing that makes it a chore to play, or breaks the game.

reviewText:
Imagine this :
You send a squad of eight, somewhat experienced troopers to a shot down UFO which you have never seen before nor do you know who or what's inside.
It's night, pitch black to be exact.
Your squad moves away from the security of the helicopter and slowly move forward, checking around every corner for any sign of aliens, their morale slightly lowering due to the darkness and the strange sounds.
They reach a cornfield, the UFO probably located behind it, so ofcourse you order them to enter the field as a sudden burst of plasma nearly hits your rifleman who took point. A big reptilian alien was hiding behind some strawbales and was waiting for you to take the bait, luckily a well-placed shot in the head took care of him quickly, good thing you brought a sniper along.
The troopers start throwing flares all around, watching every part of the field carefully as your pointman suddenly finds a patch of blood on the floor next to an empty shotgun, presumably of the farmer who lives here, yet no body to be seen.
A silhouet suddenly passes through an opening, only visible for a brief second, but enough to notice that that thing was something new.
Your heart starts to pound as you order your troops to stand ground, watching every possible entrypoint for that thing to come through.
You gunner suddenly opens fire, unleashing a hellfire of bullets to the opening you first came through, the large, bug-like horror flinching as it falls to the floor before it could reach them.
So now that's dealt with, it's time to breach the UFO...and that's where the true horror starts...

9/10 would get scared ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ again

reviewerDisplayName: Kim Jung Un Our Great Leader
reviewText:
Back in the dark ages I found a demo of X-com for my newly cobbled together 486. I wore that demo out. Even though the demo only contained one map I was able to get hours and hours out of it due to the high difficulty and the complete lack of any tool tips or tutorial. Some decade later X-com got a reboot which was massively dissapointing to me. Discovering Xenonauts was like finding that girl from junor high who gave you your 1st kiss then lost track of in highschool, has grown up into a hottie who makes pizza from cratch and cuban sandwiches while wearing heels and an apron (also she regards you as her 1st love).

Xenonauts is what X-com's re-boot should have been. Big studio AAA titles are falling into the same trap that hollowood blockbusters have. The cost of production is so high that risky ideas (read as good ideas) get a pass for more tried and true formulas (I'm looking at you infinity sequal titles). I guess a bunch of younger folks who never played the insanely hard original may try Xenonauts because they loved the re-boot. Most of those people will probably hate this game. They are going to die and die and die and not understand the satisfaction of keeping an entire team of veterans alive or the dread of losing an old friend.

Xenonauts for what is it, and how it was dev, is 10/10. It's not just a carbon copy of old x-com, it's better in all the right ways without losing any of the exacting tactical nature of the original. The coldwar setting is sick and adds immersion for me (I'm a grey bush who remembers the end of the cold war). The writing is great and combined with the art really draws you in and  adds depth and flavor, yet can be completely ignored if nobody got time for that and just want to grind out another mission real quick. In fact lots of things in this game can be sorta glossed over or invested in as the particular player sees fit.

This is what I love most about this game. You are free to solve this puzzel however you want. Some players are going to master dog fighting and some folks will auto calculate every air battle. Some may read every bit of flavor text in the game and soak up all the small details, and others will have eyes for ruthless ground games only. Whatever you find enjoyable you can go deeper and whatever you don't enjoy, you can dial down and not have to go down that road.

reviewText:
To put it simply, Xenonauts is an oldschool remake of the classic X-COM. And that means it retains the brutality of the original while still being incredibly fun to play.
The graphics, while somewhat cartoony in places (notably cars) serve the art style well and convey the message of grimness throughout the game.
Sound is fine, but some noises I found hurt my ears with headphones. Other than that not much of note aside from the good soundtrack.
UI is somewhat complicated but easy to learn, while providing most of the vital information to keep your guys from not dying a horrible, awful, painful, and plasma-y death.
Gameplay, the big G.
It feels like X-COM. Not in a shoddy knock off way, but in a The devs knew what they were doing when they made this glorious game graced by the almighty Gaben himself" way

reviewText:
The original X-Com was pulled into a time machine and this is what came out, if you want deeper strategy, base building, and loyal human soldiers dying by the truck load fighting an alien invasion then get this!

Pros; More micro management of resources, technology and building. More than one base, build as many as you want so long as you have the money. Air combat mini game against those pesky alien UFO’s. Send down bucket loads of soldiers down to fight the alien invaders (as not all of them are coming home). A longer prolonged campaign that can be drawn out.

Cons; No streamlined and snazzy graphics. Can sometimes seem overwhelming management wise for those not into deep and heavy strategy gaming.

I liked it, thumbs up!

reviewText: First of all don't go into this game looking for XCOM, you will probably find some elements adapted from it.  But yeah .... not XCOM.  I went into this expecting a turnbased strategy/management style game and left my Fanboy at the door.    If you can do that you probably will enjoy the game much better.  Its nice enough still trying to play it,  The learning curve for this game is extremely sharp and on the higher difficulty settings even more so. Don't expect much in the way of tutorials or explanations in game.  The game is very slow paced, its not something that you will complete in one sitting.  I enjoyed playing it,  the graphics are okay, the management and combat are complex. I am having a fun time, currently trying to get use to the interface and screwing around with the gameplay elements. Not really much of a story element.  I don't hate it so far and would probably reccomend it,  If you don't have a short attention span, and can handle the fact that it just drops you into the game with only a vague idea of what the hell your suppose to do.  Not saying that is a bad thing though.

reviewText:
============================================
XENONAUGHTS
============================================
Overview:

On the face of it Xenonaughts is a high quality 2D planetary defense game with stratergy and minigame elements with a little story telling all thrown in and mixed with a heavy influence from the Xcom Series and perhaps a bit of a steep price tag for an indie game attatched.

What the store doesnt tell is that the actual gameplay is a fantastic weave of impeccible timing, forced strategic and tactical improvisation and improvement, and delightful frustation when your elite squad wipes out for no apparent reason other than better guns" which will often cause you to swear vengence upon the alien scu- "liberators" the developers have done a fantastic job with this number which i shall go into further detail below
date:
fair warning though.

!!!!WALLS OF TEXT!!!!
You have been warned

============================================
The Guts:

Simply a fantastic game
recommended: I have been gaming for a little over 10 years now and I almost exclusively play stratergy and/or survival games
hoursPlayed: and of all the stratergy games I have played this has to be the most perfectly timed and tailored one fo them all at no point are you ever truely able to outgun the enemy your often outnumbered and if you turtle up one grenade or well placed lizard thing and your squads dead forcing you to rethink and restratergise without overwhelming you add the fact that if you dont plan and execute your stratergy and tactics right or do something stupid you cna lose your entire squad (and the alien victory conditions) adds an element of survival which automatically triggers the "KEEP EVERYONE ALIVE!" switch in me keeps me coming back after a rage quit form losing my entire squad (and not saving :P hey i refuse to accept a wipeout!).\n\nthe Pacing is also fantastic at no point are you ever really given too much to handle if you know what your doing (excluding the terror missions I failed everyone because of those *Censored tangent* reapers
voteText: the fact that both you and the aliens can build and attack bases also just putrs the cherry on the cake for me simply amazing the thrill i get when i discover an alien base
helpfulPercent: the first time i did i literally shouted out YEA I GOT YOU NOW YOU ALIEN MOTHER *censored* ... course it was 1 am and i got told off but still xD\n\nto be fair there are a couple issues
votesHelpful: 1 would be the graphics BUT it IS an indie game but if your into the more modern games it may not be summin you can get around
votesTotal: personally? i loved it
votesFunny: simple but detailed enough to let you know whats what and tell the differance between an alien lizard and a rock and perfectly fits the top down stratergy feel for me
commentsCount:
the second is bugs there are a couple which are frequent such as aliens shooting through walls or the psionics unnerving your men from start to finish regardless of location and distance BUT both of those and much much more are covered in the community edition which i have started playing and that just adds that extra little something to really finish off the game.

============================================
The Meat of the matter:

the game itself is split into 3 distinct parts

column18: research military assests such as squads vehicles hangers etc all the way to a alien encyclopedia (did i spell that right?)\nthe 2nd part is minigames which in itself is a novel but entertaining little piece fo frustration that i have never been able to pull of yet (but that may have something to do with the single fighter in use at any given time) where you cna either auto resolve or play yourself

reviewText:
I am editing this review for the released verson of the game. Okay so my initial impressions of this game was that it was the first true original xcom successor, and if you felt enemy unknown released in 2011 was too simple or just not enough like the original, you'll find all of that here and more. From watching this game very early on in development to full release, I can full heartedly say that it has come a long way, and the devs have certainly done a wonderful job making the game into all it could be. Some things in the game are still a little wonky, however it all has to do with the RNG of shooting which is to be expected in any pecentage based strategy game so I can't fault it for that as the original even had it. This game has a very wide enemy variety, and a fully interactive dogfighting minigame when shooting down enemy space ships of also wide varieties. Also this game captures my personal favorite part of the original xcom, which the 2011 verson didn't even come close to, and that is the dynamics of the game. In this game everything you do effects the way the game plays, if you don't go to certain missions or let certian abductions, bombings, etc happen, the enemies will gain the upper hand. And if they gain the upper hand instead of having a linear, boring experience like the 2011 game, you will have a very replayable strategy game that will keep you coming back to see your friends and loved ones get blown to pieces by plasma blasts. All in all this game is truly an example of what an early accsess game should be like, and has lived up to all my expectations for an xcom like successor.

FINAL VERDICT:

If you enjoy complex strategy games, I definitely recommend this title, however if you are looking for an easier stategy game to casually play, you won't find it here as even the normal difficulies can be extremely punishing for even experienced players. I personally love this game and hope to see its added modding community only produce more content for it.

reviewText:
I will start by the negative then lead to the good.

At first my men were falling like flys, I was losing parts of the world so fast that my bank account for my funding was in the red 10 days into the new month, all in all I was not having too much fun my men all ways seemed to drop their weapons on the floor and run or turn and shoot their fellow man in the face. All in all I was getting bored with this game and was going to mark this up as another wast of money spent.

I decided to give it one more try, I restarted the game and this time looked and making more bases, my team I always made shore one of my team was at high rank so the rest dont spazz out and that I have a hell of alot of saves as i go through a mission.

Has a feel of X-Com but feels alot more like UFO, all in all liked the game and will keep an eye out for more of Goldhawk games.

In love with the Xcom series, but finished them, well, then this just might be the game for you. It has the feel of the first couple of Xcom games, but nowhere near the graphics og Xcom enemy unknown. However, if you're not in it for the graphics, this is a fine game indeed.

reviewText:
This game is the remake of our beloved X-com that we've been waiting.

-All the things I always felt X-com was missing this game has in spades with a nice shiny art style in beautiful 2D sprites.

-The game has sounds and a soundtrack that help build up tension while your troops on tactical missions that keep you hoping the next corner is clear as you round it with just enough movement left before that soldier is stuck.

-UFOpidia? Perfectly done and a modding comunity has crafted addons that will further expand upon what was presented in game if you desire more.

-Greatly expanded air combat gameplay where it is its own mini game if you wish to skillfully down higher grade craft not to mention you can reasurch far more aircraft than any other Xcom style game that I'm aware of.  No more T1 fighter then the T2 late game and T3 is an all in one transport.. now you have many times more to choose from and they are rather role specific which keeps them fun and interesting as you realise you're not doing direct line upgrades but rather expanding your arsenel with something that tacles a new role.

-Body armor?  This game decided that each new suit of armor shouldn't nessisarly replace all prior armor but again fits a nice role so you might wish a few of each suit type if you want to take full advantage of their skills.

If you enjoyed any of the X-com games and even the most recent you will find this game by far the best X-com like expirence you have ever had.  With a modding comunity adding more content and regular patching still streaming in I can easy recomend this game to anyone who enjoys this style of game.

reviewText:
This game is very much indeed a true remake of the true x-com series.
It gives you everything X-com 1 have, and adds in alot of the features from the new x-com aswell.

Also vehicle section is more thought around, than in the original series.

Only downside I could find, was that I could wish for more research and maps. But I recond that will be added later, or through mods. Could be me that is being picky, its around 40ish researchable things or more. But i want more.
Highly recommend this game over the new X-Com. The scale of the game gets into its true form since its not for the x-box.

reviewText:
Full disclosure: I'm writing this review from the POV of someone who's certainly heard of but never played any of the Xcom games before starting this one.

Xenonauts is a strategy game where you command the titular international military group tasked with defending Earth from alien invasion in the late 1970s. It's supposed to be a remake of the original X-Com set during the Cold War, and as far as I know it's a pretty faithful recreation right down to the battlefield, base placement and troop equipment micromanagement. It seems deeper than, say, the newer XCOM series, not that that would make the newer games bad.

For me personally, it feels more like a classic Doctor Who serial without the Doctor or indeed almost any sense of optimism. (It doesn't really take advantage the fact that it's set during the Cold War - often you'll have NATO and Warsaw Pact soldiers working together in the same squad.) This game can be pretty brutal at times. The only thing that will save you from the nasty, aggressive aliens is attacking them wherever possible with maximum firepower, then stealing their stuff so your scientists can reverse-engineer it into even more firepower.

I quite like it myself, and it's an impressive indie effort, so I'd say it's good, but given its problems I would only call it good. Let's hope the sequel[www.xenonauts2.com] will be great.


My other observations:

Air combat is aces"

recommended: though it's 3v3 max and takes some getting used to. Make sure you don't insta-deploy to the first sight of UFO activity before formulating some sort of tactic for the situation

voteText: side entrances and/or destructible hull points to at least some of them. You pretty much need explosives
helpfulPercent: shields and/or expendable soldiers because at least some of the aliens will have holed up inside and they will shoot the hell out of your troops.\n\nTo my understanding
votesHelpful: the original X-Com eventually gave you tools to counter psionic attacks and develop your own. Xenonauts doesn't seem to give you anything of the sort except letting your braver troops/those who survived previous psychic attacks resist them more effectively.\n\nBullet trajectories aren't really modeled past your units' line of sight
votesTotal: from what I can tell. If you fire on where you know an alien is
votesFunny: but the alien is out of your LOS
commentsCount: it won't do anything unless you use projectile weapons such as rockets.\n\nLines of sight themselves can be weird. Soldiers seem to have a difficult time throwing grenades over objects
column16:
but alien forces seem to be able to see your forces often before you can see them.

Workshop support is truly this game's saving grace. There's already a number of mods that try to fix what I've described above.

I would say this is a rather rough but ultimately enjoyable game for people who want a no-holds-barred slugfest with MiGs and M16s against invading aliens. It's certainly smoother around the edges for people who don't want to play the original

It was boring and tedious, it was a constant wading through a full hoard of bugs, and in the end this game became a chore.

I never want to see this game again.

reviewText: The best darn $25 dollars I've spent, easily. Originally, I'm sure the developers thought they were making a xcom clone, and to be fair, they've tried their damnedest to do just that. But just playing 70 hours before its release, I can say they've made a true game, worthy of its own merit, with no need for the acclaim that comes from the backs of giants. You get what I'm saying? I don't think Chryssalids anymore, I think reapers. Sebilian and Caesan role off my tongue more easily than sectoid or mutan (whatever its called).\n\nXenonauts is a true alien invasion simulator, with all the inherent learning curves and complexity therein. You pick the placement of your first base, and go on from there, with some great tooltips for your first time round. Speaking of which, you will fail. Try as you might, there's a detail you overlooked, and you'll have a base attacked and destroyed by the aliens, or your chinook will be shot down after taking out an alien base. Something will happen. And you'll want to keep going. Not immediately, you understand, you build sentimental attachments to your crew, but after a while, you'll get than xenonauts itch.

reviewText:
Look at all these crazy video games about alien invasions!!! There are many ways you can waste aliens from the comfort of your slowly flattening computer chair. What's Xenonauts all about then? Oh, it's a remake of the original XCOM: Enemy Unknown!

Like the original XCOM, aliens invade, you shoot the aliens in the face, etc. Also like the original XCOM: It takes the ♥♥♥♥ing scenic route!!! Seeing through a game of Xenonauts will take a long, long time, and a lot of the time spent will occur in ground combat, where the idiots you're guiding through the ♥♥♥♥♥ town or the ♥♥♥♥ forest will need constant adjustment in order not to get blown up (and during the early game, your dudes will get blown up as much as the ones you're shooting, because this game is balls hard. Even on Normal.). The scenic route is made even more scenic-ier, because all the missions start to bleed through and look the same.

It's not all tedium - the game allows you to walk into the enemy's UFO, kill everyone inside, and hold it for five turns to win the mission automatically, which is a nice touch. The game is all about destructible environments, so you can take a squad of fast-moving shotgunners, blow a hole in the side of the UFO with a rocket launcher, and win a mission that way. There's all these neat little additions that fit nicely with the original's ethos (saving AP for return fire on aliens dumb enough to wander into firing range). There's also a few unconventional ones to make gameplay less pedantic and fussy, such as allowing unlimited flares on night missions. The developers COULD have not included them, making night missions extremely sucktacular engagements due to a very short LOS and with one soldier having to leave his gun in the dropship to be 'the guy who throws lights everywhere who is shot from behind by some extra-terrestrial ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hiding in a tree'. But they did, and you can throw as many as you want. Yay!

So it's kind of bland and it goes on for a long while (a campaign run is in the 50-100 hour ballpark). But it's a neat take on XCOM-style play, and mods are being added by the community to hammer out flaws. It's not going to replace the 2012 XCOM for me, but if you're looking for an update that captures the original very well, give this a shot.

reviewText: I had been playing this game for a while and always enjoyed it until I saw that there was the community edition, I've always been a fan of playing Iron Man mode (Can't undo your actions IE: if your trooper died because you did something stupid so be it.) However I noticed that the amount of BS in the community edition is ridiculous; I've had the enemy shoot and kill me from inside their spaceship. yes the door was open but there was still a wall seperating, I've grinded one of my guys to have 80 bravery which is really high and still get mind controlled. I've missed 95% shots more then 5% of the time only to have their retaliatory shot kill the trooper hiding behind two rows of cover. reviewText: I missed out on the delight of XCOM in my youth, and the modern incarnations never grabbed me, however this game has been fantastic and I have already sunk plenty of my time into the vanilla, community edition, and CE modded versions of the game. I highly recommend playing the Community Edition over standard release at this point as the community has created about the best version of the game that can be made.\n\nI would recommend this to anyone who enjoyed the original XCOM, or missed the boat and wants to see what the fuss is about. Warning: This game is pretty difficult, and so far I have yet to muddle my way through a full campaign on normal. Though I play on iron-man, so it's difficult to tell how well I'd do save-scumming. If you're unsure, check out some videos or take full advantage of the refund policy - but don't let this one pass you by if you like the idea of defending against a cold-war era alien invasion.

reviewText:
This is the X-Com reimagining we've all been waiting for.

Xenonauts was clearly made with enormous respect and admiration for the original, but this affection never stopped Goldhawk from reaching deep into the game mechanics and touching up everything that needed fixing, and many things that I never thought could have been improved. The result is not a mere 1:1 copy, and much more than just X-Com with a better interface. It's a refinement of the original, keeping the brilliant and still enormously engaging core loop intact and polishing it to perfection.

If you never played the original X-Com games, don't even try. They are hard to get into, and thanks to Goldhawk, there is simply no need to wrestle with them anymore. Xenonauts delivers the same experience that made the original a legend, except better in every possible way. A fantastic achievement.

reviewText: Play balancing has a long way to go in this game before it will be worth playing. Don't buy it until they have released a few patches to fix it. Alien psychic abilities are way too powerful and you have no way to defend against them. Expert marksmen will miss more often than not, even with a high % chance to hit. And the worst (possibly a glitch, I'm not sure) is loading a saved game only to have the situation different than when you saved. The worst example, in my own experience, was when I had cleared an alien base. All except the last room. (the command room) Decided to take a break, saved my game and exited. When I came back and reloaded, suddenly my troops were surrounded by aliens that hadn't been there when I saved. I couldn't continue the fight because my soldiers were automatically killed every time I reloaded. This and a number of other balancing and glitch issues make the game no fun to play. A perfectly good playthrough can quickly and easily be ruined by bad code and balancing. Hopefully they fix these things soon because the game has promise, it's just not where it should be yet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Beginning with the conclusion: If you enjoyed the original XCOM, buy this game immediately. It is a faithful modern remake.

It is not precisely the same--and every single change I have noticed is for the better. It provides additional control over some matters (such as UFO interception) that used to be purely automatic. Conversely, it automates some matters that used to be purely tedious, e.g., you are afforded an infinite supply of conventional infantry equipment. Like the third game, Apocalypse, you can view soldier stats prior to hiring. Like the original, soldiers are likely to die in one hit before you develop new armor, while aliens are noticeably resistant to less than concentrated fire. An airstrike" option lets you deal with crashed UFOs when you cannot afford to send in the ground troops
date: and still nets a minor gain.\n\nComparing it to the AAA title is more difficult
recommended: as it has virtually nothing in common with that that it does not have with the original. The graphics are modern and pleasing but most resemble higher-resolution versions of Apocalypse's sprites
hoursPlayed: maintaining a mildly retro feeling.  While soldiers have "roles
voteText: these are less classes and more changeable, customizable equipment loadouts, allowing you to quickly change equipment according to any established preference. Soldiers gain stats with experience, but do not gain unique skills.

reviewText:
I've played: the original three X-Com games from Microprose; the re-done X-Com: Enemy Unknown (and the DLC and expansion packs) from 2K Games; and Xenonauts.

If you're looking for a true spiritual successor to the original Microprose version of X-com, look no further than this game.  If you're familiar with the game mechanics, you'll easily adapt to this, once you figure out the way the various weapons and aliens work.

Make no mistake: this game is harder than Enemy Unknown.  It's also a lot less visually polished.  Still, the graphics are perfectly acceptable as 2D sprites (and also far more moddable).  Chances are, if you're considering this game, bleeding-edge graphics aren't your major concern.  You're (hopefully) in it for the gameplay.

Admittedly, I haven't played this one for a little while, but when I last played, there were only a few cheap" items that appeared in the game

reviewText: If you liked the original X-Com, this game is a much more faithful update than the Firaxis games which were produced about the same time Xenonauts was released.  If you miss the turn based combat and base management aspects of the game, this one is worth a try.  There are some new/improved aspects worth mentioning such as the air combat game which is slightly more involved than in the original X-Com, and some of the penny-ante management has been dispensed with, such as you are always assumed to have adequate ammunition for your basic weaponry.  If you enjoyed the original, then you'll find plenty to enjoy with this game, plus improved graphics.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I hesitate to call Xenonauts a spiritial successor to one of the greatest games of all time - UFO: Enemy Unknown (X-COM: UFO Defense in the USA) - rather instead, it's purely a spiritual remake.

The earth has come under attack from aliens, and you manage a PMC tasked with fighting them. The nations of the world fund the company, and based on how you defend each country the funding can rise or fall. This is done from a map view of the earth, showing your base, and craft as they start to appear. To begin, just a few small scout craft arrive, easily shot down. If you intercept the craft over land, sometimes it crash lands, forming a crash site you can investigate. Alternatively, the craft sometimes lands and you can send a dropship to the location. Once the dropship arrives at the site you enter an isometric view where you can move your units, and shoot at any aliens you encounter. This section is turn based, and the amount of movement you can make is determined by how many Time Units each unit has. Once you have cleared the site, you can recover alien technologies and take them back to your base to research, leading to the ability to manafacture new items. There are many other elements to both the management and tactical section of the game, which I won't spoil here.

If you're looking for a modern take or an evolution on this forumla, look instead into the excellent 2012 Fixaris reboot, XCOM: Enemy Unknown. This is a very different experience however, and I'd still throughly recommend trying the original. However Xenonauts now presents an interesting new third option. I've recommended the original to people, only to see them never really get into it thanks largely to the outdated interface. Xenonauts allows you to experiece the brilliance of the original, but tuned to remove those frustrations.

For example, one of the least enjoyable parts of the original was surely the inventory management. While I love the base management overall, manually replacing every last clip, medkit, rocket, grenade wore thin pretty quickly, especially when most of the items were cheap enough to never really be a concern. In Xenonauts, this is thankfully gone for most of the mundane consumables. Other areas which have been simplified include reloading, and using grenades. In X-COM, using a grenade was a series of actions, removing it from your belt, putting it in your hand, pulling the pin/setting the timer, throwing it. Each took a small amount of time units, and it was entirely possible to pull the pin, only to realise you didn't have enough time units left to throw it. While this did invoke exactly the feeling of panic it was no doubt supposed to, it was largely just frustrating. In Xenonauts all of this is just replaced with a single action with a single time unit cost. To my tastes, they developers have thankfully only simplified elements which probably needed it - it certainly doesn't feel dumbed down.

It might just be me, but Xenonauts does feel a little easier than UFO was. However, this really is no bad thing - UFO was punishingly difficult, and it wasn't unusual for newcomers to be in real trouble before even their first funding review. In Xenonauts, easy mode should allow new players to get a good long feel for the game before they start ramping up the difficulty.

If you loved UFO, or you enjoy classic tactical games, if you like retro graphics style, you'll most likely enjoy this greatly. It's such a closely tied remake of UFO it almost feels like I'm reviewing that, rather than Xenonauts - either way, I cannot recommend either one highly enough.

reviewText: Basically, if you liked X-COM and/or similar games, this is one that you must have. Compared to the new X-COM games, Xenonauts simply has more depth added to it and pretty much has everything you'd want for an X-COM clone. Don't let the 2D graphics fool you, this game offers everything that's lacking in the new X-COM: Vehicles, ability to customize loadouts further and mix between classes, an inventory system, and best of all, a more involving geoscape with air battles that offers you means to not only take command on the ground, but achieve air supremacy as well, if you know what you're doing, of course.\n\nNot to mention the excellent support from the devs, even for the Linux version of the game.

reviewText:
I played all the original x-com series and this is pretty good. however it has some balance problems and air combat can be quite repetative and slow. I just rage quit my latest game after turning up at a terror site to find at least 8 aliens stuffed into the corner of the map with me along with a bunch of blokes who were sitting ducks for the wierd things with fangs, so that number went up every turn. and as I didnt have laser weapons yet, each one would need multiple shots to take them down. even if they hit of course. the % chance of hitting something is wildly optimistic.

so 4 turns in its obvious that this mission is toast, i've no chance. i could try and grind it out but i would loose all my men, leaving me turning to random soldier generator and its list of people with huge strength and accuracy but with so little bravery they drop their weapons and run off like a big girl if an alien so much as coughs on the same map, or incredibly brave people who have so little time units they have to run along at the back of the group trying to catch up like an asthmatic fat kit or with so little health they croak when they get hit by a so much as a glancing blow off of a nerf gun.

or i could pack up the soldiers i have been training from that bunch of schlubs into an elite fighting unit and surrender and run off like the french army whenever they see so much of a menacing looking bratwurst appear on the horizon. And by doing that I'll loose a whole bunch of funding and possibly the region, so ending the whole game a bit earlier.

i chose ragequit.

again the laser weapon thing is annoying. you can pick them up off the aliens and use them, however when you end the mission they are automatically sold. WTF? Who in their right mind would automatically sell weaponry that a) you could use and b) was better than what you currently had? You can almost imagine the Python-esque conversation that would happen back in the barracks over that one...

reviewText:
Wow!  There have been a ton of games that have tried to do what X-COM: UFO Defense (or UFO: Enemy Unknown) succeeded so well with back in '94.  A scope that seems global, and you have soldiers that may well only make it through one mission alive.  Casualties are expected, and you feel like you are engaged in a true war with the aliens.

2012's XCOM by Firaxis is fantastic--it plays well, it's easy to pick up, and it's fun.  Still, to me that game felt more like an action movie.  I had six soldiers that survived more often than not (then again, I don't play the super high difficulties, so that might change things a bit).

Xenonauts puts you into a larger scale war, with dozens of troops at your command that you will need.  And some will die.  Heck, many will.  But this game has that skin-of-your-teeth feel to it that the original X-COM had.  The graphics are similar, and almost and updated version of the mid-nineties hit.  Yet there are numerous improvements that help troop and base management, the interceptor game became more strategic (with wingmen!), and there are more options overall that let you take the war to the aliens.

I'm re-learning the strategies to win all over again, like it was twenty years ago.  And I'm having a blast doing it!

reviewText:
Totally Addictive!
This game is in many aspects a clone of the original XCOM.
Which is a good thing!
Few games offer this kind of tactical gameplay: Jagged Alliance comes to mind, the rather crappy UFO Afterlight series, Silent Storm .... Of course there is the Firaxis XCOM, which is a really good game and I really liked it. But it is different from the original XCOM in many ways, and this is not.
Xenonauts gives you the basic XCOM experience with a graphical update and an improved interface. The game is very playable and it does not suffer from any crashes whatsoever.
There is mod support and a lot of mods are available.

One word regarding the difficulty level: When playing on veteran and above you will probably get your ♥♥♥ kicked. Basically after the first month it becomes very hard to do missions without losing men. Unless you are really experienced with the game and you know how to raid the larger UFOs.

reviewText: Let me start this review off by saying that this game is the spiritual successor to X-COM all of us fans of the original have been waiting for. Now, before all the Firaxis fans come out of the woodwork to make angry remarks, I have nothing against XCOM - from what I've heard it's a very good game in its own right; however from what I've seen (yes, I haven't yet had a chance to play it myself - yet - although the opinions I've heard/read and videos I've watched all seem to agree on this), the Firaxis remake changed the formula that made the original great into a more streamlined experience, that had been tailored to appeal to a larger audience - thus removing some of what made X-COM so enjoyable for some of us.\n\nHowever, Xenonauts has very much kept the formula the same. The basic gameplay mechanics are spot-on compared to what the original X-COM was like, except with some much needed touch-ups. First and foremost is the game resolution and interface - no longer will you need to suffer with an 800x600 resolution window and a clunky UI where the buttons don't reveal much (What does this do? Oh I just placed some primed C4 at my soldier's feet")
date: and the interface taking up a third of the screen! Xenonauts has really improved these aspects and honestly
recommended: I really think that this alone makes Xenonauts worth considering
hoursPlayed: due to the sheer increase in playability that has resulted by actually having a nice
voteText: clean interface that didn't come straight out of the 1990s.\n\nSecondly
helpfulPercent: there are the combat improvements. They've really changed up the air combat in this game from what was in the original
votesHelpful: and although I acknowledge that it's not to everyone's taste
votesTotal: it's certainly a lot closer to it than what X-COM's air combat was like

reviewText:
If you liked original X-COM, you will like this; it is almost exactly the same but with a much nicer UI.

The cold-war setting adds an interesting flavour, and the overall feeling while playing is very tense. There are a few minor bugs I've noticed with the UI, but nothing showstopping.

The only weak points I see are that the tactical locations are all very similar - they're using prebuilt tile maps and not randomly generating locations - it breaks the immersion a little bit when you  realize you've played the same map on a previous play. The dog-fighting mini game isn't very fun and you don't seem to gain anything by not using Auto Resolve. The Civilian AI could be a better too, as they seem to just run around in random patterns without any real objective or tactics. Keeping yourself in the black seems a little bit too difficult as well - but they provide full modding ability if you want to tweak any of the games parameters to tune the difficulty.

Those points aside, I really love this game. I enjoy approaching it like a roleplaying game - naming all my soldiers and coming up with Cold-War-Esque code names for my bases, dropships, and vehicles.

Highly reccomended for fans of deep strategy or tactical games.

reviewText:
The game I've been searching for ages. Since 2000 there has been so few of these really. Original X-com but updated. I've forgotten how much fun it is to individually equip tens of soldiers. Ground battles are as dangerous as they should be, air battles are innovative. Reminds be a bit of star wars rebellion space battles which was an excellent concept. But it's faster and more exciting.

Realism is there and it's not been sacrificed in order to maintain game balance. Your tank is cheap and overpowering. If not very accurate. I've yet to discover many aspects of the game, I'm not googling stuff to gain advantage so I don't want to share my other guesses about the tactics. I might be wrong after all.

There can be many additions for the game and from the start screen I understand that it is highly moddable. Which means a high replay value. I'm sure modders will add many fascinating stuff.

In short, I highly recommend if you are a turn based strategy fan. If you are new to the gendre you might find it a bit old school but trust me, you will love it after you spend 15 mins in your first pass and will want to start again the game.

It's not for casual gamer obviously. Even though it's not very hardcore, you still need some time to go through all the way and you need to be a patient wolf. It's not a fast pace game.

reviewText:
Do you want a game more brutal than X-Com? Do you want a tactical game where you make all the choices? Do you want to have a mission, everyone dies but doesn't destroy your game?
This game is for you! Xenonauts has been around for a while and it is aging well with the mods making it better.  The best example being is the improvement in lore and the extra explaining the progress in the game for both you and the aliens.

This game is basically the remake of the original X-Com, you control everything in your base which you NEED to control, not to worry about petty stuff like fuel, food and who got friendzoned by the hot accountant.  Instead your job is to control the men, control where to defend, who to send, what weapons given, what research to look into, what to invest, airpower, tanks or infantry equipment and where to even locate your base, 2nd and if able your 3rd.  Aliens come in a variety of ways, while the early game is somewhat bland, you do face 2 types which require certainly different tactics. Things will pick up in the mid game and things will get much harder, crazier and you will be expected to win. When Aliens begin to have the numbers, they will strike you back and destroy your base if you are not careful, soldiers are the key.

This game is hard, on any diffulty expect to lose men and women left and right, many will not survive the hordes of Aliens which will be BRUTAL AND UNFORGIVING. You will make bad decisions, you will falter, you will be blamed for things out of your control. But Xenonauts are responsible to protect the world. Also General of the Xenonauts Program. Good luck.
