reviewText:
Xenonauts
-------------
Summary: X-Com 1.5
Multiplayer: No
Completion: 30 hrs
Cards: Yes
Cloud: No

Can't get enough old-school X-Com? Xenonauts strives to be the spiritual successor of the original game. It brings a little more of everything and streamlines features that should have been in X-Com in the first place, while simultaneously removing certain elements. Thankfully the story doesn't completely retread the original game, and opts to create its own alien backstory, which is fun to experience.

The story takes place in the Cold War era, where everyone stops fighting and bands together due to the alien threat. Cue in the Xenonauts, a world-funded organization to counter the exterrestrials, study their technology, and adapt it for our own use. As the months go by, the aliens grow ever bolder, sending bigger and better ships, as though they are adapting to our own environment. Their numbers seemingly countless, they must be stopped, one way or another.

Since the game is basically X-Com, I'll just outline some of the changes and what i think of them. The following are changes I thought were good:
-All your loadouts are saved, and you can create your own custom loadouts and quickly equip soldiers to match that loadout with the press of a button.
-Shields are a great item to have, and are much appreciated. Sadly you can only use 1-handed weapons with them.
-Simultaneous movement. 'Nuff said.
-Able to launch ships and soldiers while injured/low on fuel.
-Civilians help you out! Suddenly the world doesn't feel as lonely as before.
-UFO designs are varied and interesting.
-I haven't seen aliens forever camp in one spot!
-Walking consumes 3TU instead of 4TU, letting you scout about 33% further.
-You are given all basic weapons for free in unlimited quantities.
-Good tiles, though some art is a little off, like the portraits.
-Enjoyable new story.
-Air combat is very involved, though I suck at it. Also, they will run from your fleets, the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.
-Airstriking is great. I don't want to do every UFO mission.
-Showing radar coverage is great. Makes me feel not-wasteful.
-Stun rockets and grenades are great, and can be obtained early.
-There's much less need of live aliens.
-You are automatically refilled on supplies when the mission ends, thus you can fly multiple missions in a row in a single flight.
-360 vision suit is awesome.
-Easy to edit the game (though poorly documented).

These are the changes that I feel could use some improvements:
-Holy balls there's so many aliens! They always come in waves, multiple times a week, and the likelihood of one getting away is high.
-Therefore there are a bazillion ground missions you could end up doing if you don't airstrike them.
-Your aircraft are limited to 2 missiles. Considering the volume of UFOs that attack the world simultaneously, this problem is magnified.
-All aircraft have considerable monthly fees. You don't even get a refund for decommissioning them.
-Explosives destroy equipment upon death, which strongly discourages their use. Their blast radii are also way lower, further discouraging their use.
-Aliens do not suffer from morale problems. I miss the feeling of knowing the aliens are panicking.
-There is no means to train against psionics short of experiencing it first hand.
-Aliens do not need to spot you before they can start blowing your mind.
-No mind control or blaster launchers for your troops. Those were fun!
-Burst fire got removed from most weapons. Those that do have it consume too many TUs.
-The maximum accuracy on any shot is 95%, even at point blank range. You can and will miss on the 95%.
-Weapons consume much more TU on average compared to X-Com, so you rarely get many shots on a full TU bar (not counting machine guns).
-New weapons completely replace old ones. There are no TU or accuracy differences.
-Most weapons are 2-handed now, removing many potential combinations that could have been fun.
-Destructible terrain plays much less of a role. Stray shots rarely destroy stuff, and high TU-shots means creating your own entrance is rarely worthwhile.
-Lack of instant movement. When you start to do dozens of missions, the time spent watching things move really adds up.
-Maps are not procedurally generated. I saw multiple same maps in the same game.
-Overhead map is gone.
-You can't earn money through item production. Thus engineers are a constant drain on your funds, and they will never turn a profit.
-There's very little stuff to buy and sell. Money is very tight in this game.
-You cannot use alien artifacts. I miss being able to grab a dead alien's cannon and use it against his buddies.
-You cannot fire in the air in a flying suit. So much for death from above.
-As odd as this sounds, Xenonauts might be too long. It's very difficult to beat in one sitting, which is discourages replaying the game a bit. The fourth tier weapons might be overkill.
-Sometimes crashes on Win 10.
-The sarcastic scientist isn't very funny.

As far as X-Com clones go, Xenonauts is probably the closest I've played that stays close to the original formula. It's a lot closer than the official XCOM: Enemy Unknown. However some of the changes they made oddly made the game less fun, such as the lack of mind control and blaster launchers. I don't deny these made the game much easier, but darn it, I just want to obliterate the battlefield and rain death from the skies. I like it a lot better than UFO: Extraterrestrials. I'm rather curious how they would write for a sequel to this game. By the end of the game you gain access to exceedingly powerful technology (infinite power??), and I can't imagine where they'd go from there. I give Xenonauts a 8.5/10. It's not without problems but is certainly a fine game.

reviewText: Xenonauts is a strategy game that closely follows the original X-Com:UFO Defense in which you order a team of people who should never hold a weapon to kill or capture aliens in order to turn back the alien invasion. It feels like they took xcom and refined the UI and controls to make it less tedious and 'mis-click' prone, you don't have to build alien containment chambers and there's less chance of you making your solider move unintentionally. There's also a more in-depth interception mini-game that involves manuevers but I'm terrible at it.\n\nBut yeah if you like UFO Defense get it, or if you like the idea of UFO Defense but those early 90's style of gameplay don't appeal to you get it.

reviewText: As some one who has never played the original xcom: ufo defence, I can thoroughly say this game doesnt just try to capitalise on nostalgia. It is a brilliant game in its own right. I would recommend it for any hardcore strategy fan. It can be very unforgiving and will punish sloppy commanders in both the overall strategic conflict and in the combat missions themselves. You need to stay vigilant as you are truly fighting a superior enemy. The atmosphere and aesthetic is very interesting and while the graphics wont blow you away, there are some really nice renders with some lore which create a good picture in your mind of what you are facing even if the little models of the aliens and men arent very detailed in combat. The music is also nice and eerie when you have to face the enemy or soars when your interceptors thunder towards alien craft to shoot them down. The combat itself is tactically very satifying. It has lots of depth and once you take the fight to alien bases and they do the same to you things really start to get interesting. I have many memories of individual missions and the stories that unfold in them. The heroic rookie that pulls of an unbelievably feat of bravery and kills the last few aliens even as his comrades' bodies grow cold around him. The time when I dropped my rocket launcher at the other side of the map coz my man got wounded and then had to hoof it all the way back because i had cornered an alien commander and i was ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off and wanted to blow his ♥♥♥ to xeno hell. The bunch of ill prepared and under equipped soldiers who fended off an attack on my one and only base. There are plenty of moments like this. Buy it...and suffer! In a good way haha

reviewText:
I'm a huge, HUGE fane of the original X-Com.  I was really looking foward to this game and hoped an indie company could restore the glorius gameplay that was X-com -- but they fall short.

They really try to be true to the source material, but nothing quite meshes.  Graphics and animations are meh and the A.I. still makes those magical shots from 300 yards away, around the tree, under the car, through the two house windows -- killing your soldier instantly.  On the other end of the spectrum, you will miss the alien standing next to you, with a plasma shot gun and 99% CTH -- and if you are lucky enough to hit it, it will take a whopping 5% damage, while the other 7 of your soldiers will panic, drop their gun, and run right up to the enemies for a merciful quick killing.

It's very frustrating, to say the least.  So close, but so far.

reviewText:
I like old UFO games and I like the new XCOM: Enemy Unknown (and EW add on and LW mod). I like tactical games. I like turn based games.

And I really tried to like Xenonauts. I tried to like it because in theory it's a great game and because I wanted to justify spending money on it.

But I couldn't.

EVERYTHING in this game is crappy. The first jarring thing is air combat. While in theory very good, it's just too bugged. About 5-10% of my air fights end up in my and enemy aircrafts circling around each other forever at the same spot, and if I try to move my plane it's an obvious suicide, so I can either do that or alt+F4. Other than this annoyance air combat is fine as it is, however, it's much better to just hit autoresolve and spare yourself some irritation from time to time.

The next extremely annoying thing is a field of vision of soldiers. It seems they are are incredibly shortsighted to a point they can't see anything over 10 meters away and miss targets that are five meters away by fvkking miles. The best tactic is to run at enemies to stand one meter away from them as in melee fight and then shoot them because otherwise your dvmb ♥♥♥♥♥♥ t4rded soldier will miss or even perhaps kill one of the other squad members shooting in a wrong direction by a 90 degrees. In addition, while the player is walking around the maps almost blindly, aliens always know where the player's units are. Even if they are on the other side of the map they already see you. So skreew you if you wanted to use a short vision against the enemy.

The next thing is that aliens just love camping". A bunch of them will just sit in their aircraft with a closed door (so far I did not find a way to just blow upthe whole aircrafts with those t4rrds inside) and wait for you. If you run a soldier over there

reviewText:
Something about the screenshots of Xenonauts always put me off playing the game in the past, I couldn't put my finger on it; although I think the game itself looks great, the screenshots didn't do it justice. But as a big fan of the early X-com games as well as the 2012 reboot I was lured towards Xenonauts, it was one of those games that got under my skin, I kept looking at it on steam, on the fence as to whether it was worth the full asking price; I'd have to say after completing the campaign that it most definately is.

Where as the 2012 Firaxis X-com reboot was more of a reimaging, Xenonauts is an up tp date version of the older X-com games, bringing back time units and a whole list of other unit statistics giving the game a certain retro charm.

The main story arc of Xenonauts was brilliant, although it's another version of what has gone before, in my opinion it's a story which is more believable than those that have gone before it. reviewText:
Xenonauts is what Xcom should have been.

The most important feature in the game I can see is the Action system instead of 2 action move or shot. You can move or shoot as long you have enough action point for that action. Want to do a reaction shot save up enough for that shot.
I like how this game force you to look in every direction unlike XCom your soldiers are nearly deaf. You can only hear the sounds of doors and no the game won’t deal you which direction did that sound came from.

From what I read about this game lots of people said it has lots of micro management I disagree the game is simple enough for every and the UI is well designed. Having the ablity to ship items or rearranging my strike force is a plus for me.

It is good to mention that this game has big modding teams doing and add lots of great maps and weapons as well as unities and UI fixes in this game I recommend checking them out.

If you like Xcom get this game It will suck you in very fast and you will have a love/hate relationship with it

reviewText:
If you ever played and enjoyed the original XCOM then Xenonauts is pretty essential while if you played and enjoyed the XCOM reboot 'Enemy Unknown' then Xenonauts is still worth looking into.

In many ways this is the spiritual sequel to the original XCOM and while I can understand that it may be too 'hardcore' and intimidating for alot of people I still believe that anyone who enjoyed the XCOM reboot should still give it a shot. It might end up being too much for you to take in, or it might prove to be too difficult  but I'm pretty sure that you'll enjoy the process of discovering that because it scratches the same itch in so many ways. The base grounding of knowledge that you'll have from Enemy Unknown will also help you bed in gently as alot of the systems are very similar, it's just that in Xenonauts they're also that little bit more indepth.

Steam Workshop support was recently added and already there have been mods uploaded which add even more variety and quality content to the game and I'm sure that in time that content can only grow.

In short. Xenonauts is smashing. Give it a shot if you like this sort of thing. It was without doubt one of my games of the year 2014

reviewText:
As a fan of the original X-Com series, and someone who spent many nights shivering with tension on those critical night missions a long time ago, Xenonauts recaptures all of that - and more. It had a bumpy ride through development but honestly it has turned out a solid game, and I'm very happy to have supported it early on.

One of the strengths of Xenonauts is the tactics that you can pour into playing the game, on the base management level, or the battle maps themselves. This is what people were crying out for and didn't really get in the otherwise decent XCOM game: the ability to fine-tune your planning and tactics, and go different routes. Tank and heavy weapons? Rapid response scout team? Traditional army style? Beserkers filled with explosives? Patient sniper team? You can make all of these work. Plotting your route through the maps and vying with the alotted time just feels right.

And on the globe view - base placement, setup, research order, and all that. This all matters way more than XCOM. I'd say the AI - though not mindblowing - is just as good as the XCOM game if not better simply due to the more complex map design.

Just play out your first night mission and listen to those noises. It's very dark out there and you're all alone and it's all going to go horribly wrong - maybe.

One of the great strengths of this title over the originals, all the unofficial remakes, and the recent XCOM game, is that the maps needn't be repetitious. The system in place for juggling map assets does the hard work, and the editor is extremely powerful and will no doubt fill your hard drive with hundreds of variants (all of which, really, produce their own limitless variants). So if you take the time to download them, or map packs, or produce your own (it's fun!) you can cure one of the biggest nagging problems with the series' formula.

Can't really recommend this strongly enough to strategy fans.

reviewText:
This game is a lot of fun. If your into X-com you will love this game. You have a lot more freedom in  the game compared to x-com.  Most of the time when you shoot down a UFO you can wipe it out with ground forces or just bomb it and get paid for it.

It's very slow paced in the way that you have to move your soilders very slowly and point them in the right direction. You can be right next to a bad guy and not even know it, which at times is annoying.

It's more tatical than X-com, and I like that you can change your soilders roles at anytime. Some roles end up being pointless, but it's nice to be able to do that.

I will say the game is very unforgiving the first round or two till you get some armor. Other than that, it's a different type of x-com experince.

There are some differences however,  you might find youself being able to do more than just 2 attacks in xenonauts and though as I said before you can change the role of your soilders you still have to find what best suits them.

reviewText:
Old school X-COM with nice graphics, well-thought features and controlled air combat.

Played this game along it`s development (a little bit after it started to provide premium access to alpha builds). Witnessed most of the dev`s decisions during that time, most of which were influenced by the premium access players. So, basically, what you get in the game is based on old school X-COM fans` opinions and suggestions.

The game while being complex is a bit simplified compared to old X-COM series. For example - there is no such thing as ammo buying/producing. You are always stocked up with infinite ammo even for produced weapons. You are still limited to what your soldiers can carry into battle.
Other simplification is options to autoresolve air battles and get rid off indesired ground UFO recovery operations. You don`t want to go down and risk your soldiers for a mere amount of alloys? Just blow up the crash site by a single click and get some money for that.
Geoscape (the global view of the world) provides reports of alien activity. These reports indicate presence of UFOs and allows player to send interceptors beyond the radar coverage of Xenonauts bases.

I recommend this game to anyone who is familiar with the old school UFO\X-COM (not the one that Firaxis released).

reviewText:
This game is probably my favorite game in the last few years. Honestly, I almost like it better than XCOM: UFO Unknown. I've played through it once now. I DID play on Normal and without Ironman Mode and saved, like, every three seconds, but I still played it.

But anyways, what's so good about it?
-Feels similar to the old XCOM, which is good
-Pretty deep base management
-TONS of technology. More than either of the XCOMs.
-An EXTREMELY awesome air combat system. Much better than either of the XCOMs. Instead of fighting one-on-one, you can go up to 3v3, and the way it works is almost perfect. Once you get the hang of it. Spend the time getting really good at it.
-A pretty decent economy, you do well, you get more money. I do wish you could sell your advanced weaponry for more than what it is now. You'd think countries would want to get their hands on some shiny new guns.
-Really good tactical combat. Lots of fun. Pretty darn hard if you aren't careful though.
-Mods. You can mod the game. I haven't, but it's there.
-Tons of overall content.

There's not much I didn't like. Mostly just stuff with the difficulty. On normal. So, IT'S HARD. Get it if you want a challenge. IF you just want to blow stuff up like in XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within, this game might not be for you.

As of the creation of this review, I have played one game through, which took me 40 hours to complete.

reviewText:
A good remake of the classic UFO: Enemy Unknown (or X-COM: UFO Defense for the 'muricans). Better than Firaxis' 2012 X-COM, though that game is good too. It's set in the cold war era, which is great, but not much is done with the setting. It's mainly in the art.

Gameplay is pretty much the original UFO with some improvements, like bit more elaborate air combat and cover system. There is a lot of little things that bother me, but mods could fix the most of them, and there seems to be a healthy modding community. For example, the maps are generated semi-randomly like in UFO, but the maps generated are often boring, but there is mods that adds a lot of new submaps for the game to build it's maps from. The weapon tiers are a bit too obvious and gamey, this bothered me on the Firaxis' game too, but I can see how mods could fix that.

Something not as fixable by mods is that the engine doesn't seem to handle z-axis so well. The sightlines are sometimes illogical when looking above and below. That's probably why the UFOs have teleporters instead of those lift tube things of the original game. The enviroment destruction seems to be on par with the original game, not as great as in X-COM: Apocalypse, but OK.

It has some of the addicting quality of the original UFO. Endgame drags a bit, though. Overall very good and I got to try some of those mods.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
As a fan of the original X-Com series, and someone who spent many nights shivering with tension on those critical night missions a long time ago, Xenonauts recaptures all of that - and more. It had a bumpy ride through development but honestly it has turned out a solid game, and I'm very happy to have supported it early on.

One of the strengths of Xenonauts is the tactics that you can pour into playing the game, on the base management level, or the battle maps themselves. This is what people were crying out for and didn't really get in the otherwise decent XCOM game: the ability to fine-tune your planning and tactics, and go different routes. Tank and heavy weapons? Rapid response scout team? Traditional army style? Beserkers filled with explosives? Patient sniper team? You can make all of these work. Plotting your route through the maps and vying with the alotted time just feels right.

And on the globe view - base placement, setup, research order, and all that. This all matters way more than XCOM. I'd say the AI - though not mindblowing - is just as good as the XCOM game if not better simply due to the more complex map design.

Just play out your first night mission and listen to those noises. It's very dark out there and you're all alone and it's all going to go horribly wrong - maybe.

One of the great strengths of this title over the originals, all the unofficial remakes, and the recent XCOM game, is that the maps needn't be repetitious. The system in place for juggling map assets does the hard work, and the editor is extremely powerful and will no doubt fill your hard drive with hundreds of variants (all of which, really, produce their own limitless variants). So if you take the time to download them, or map packs, or produce your own (it's fun!) you can cure one of the biggest nagging problems with the series' formula.

Can't really recommend this strongly enough to strategy fans.

reviewText:
Cold War? Yes
Rich fake history entries? Mmhmm!
Feels like the original Xcoms? Yus!

Simple learning curve, and if you've played similar games like the original Xcom franchise you shouldn't have any issues. It does feel almost as dated but that's almost certainly an artistic choice (I would guess to relate more to early 90s squad tactics games), it isn't the flashiest but it looks really nice for 2D Iso artwork.

Workshop items are also fantastic! everything seems to work flawlessly and there are some really interesting mods out there, a few even drastically change major parts of gameplay, adding a few more layers of depth.

You definetly feel like you're working with the NSA and MIB when your deep into a game.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is a lot of fun. If your into X-com you will love this game. You have a lot more freedom in  the game compared to x-com.  Most of the time when you shoot down a UFO you can wipe it out with ground forces or just bomb it and get paid for it.

It's very slow paced in the way that you have to move your soilders very slowly and point them in the right direction. You can be right next to a bad guy and not even know it, which at times is annoying.

It's more tatical than X-com, and I like that you can change your soilders roles at anytime. Some roles end up being pointless, but it's nice to be able to do that.

I will say the game is very unforgiving the first round or two till you get some armor. Other than that, it's a different type of x-com experince.

There are some differences however,  you might find youself being able to do more than just 2 attacks in xenonauts and though as I said before you can change the role of your soilders you still have to find what best suits them.

reviewText: Xenonauts is an excellent spiritual continuation of a defining turn based franchise. The graphics, gameplay, and UI stay true where they were successful while parts that were lacking have been improved or redesigned. The game is very long, and in some instances will feel drawn out and repetitive, but on the whole it does not detract far enough to avoid playing.\n\nKnow that this game is tough and will take careful thought, experimentation, and a bit of luck to win.

reviewText:
Awesome Turn Based Strategy(TBS) game.

I have only clocked a few hours into this game, but what I have done has been very enjoyable.
Not being big on games with a lot of text etc I have oddly found myself quite interested in the new entries that popup as you progress through the game, these detail new technologies you find, autopsy reports and other general info.

The game puts you in charge of administering and controlling a organisation designed to intercept and stop and alien threat via advancing human technologies to and expanding your organisation deployment globally to defend against said alien threat.
You do this by initially building a base, which gives you two interceptor jets, a helicopter transport and a crack team of individuals to neutralize any alien threats.

Your base is equipped with a radar that covers a set range and when UFO contacts are detected you can launch your interceptors to shoot the target down.
This is done in Real-Time and basically has you controlling the weapons and direction your plane(s) fly.
Once you down the UFO you can deploy your transport of troops and land at the crash site to secure it in TBS combat FOR SCIENCE!

I will not get too deep into it,
The game is straight forward, easy to understand and follow the dev has done some great work in the lore and story and  it is simply enjoyable to play.

Well worth the price if you are into TBS games and or the XCOM series.

reviewText: Xenonauts is a faithful modern version of a classic from 90'. It has the same features that made X-COM such a tense and memorable game, with base invasions and a gigantic open-ended campaign of depth and freedom. Game is not dumbed nor mainstreamed version of Firaxis take on futuristic version of XCOM, but opposite - expanded of current generation game features and more.\n\nXenonauts is the best possible tribute to an evergreen masterpiece like the original X-COM. It is also a must play for any fan of turn based strategy games, as it is one that I'll be playing for some time to come

reviewText:
I'll get the obvious out of the way; if you liked XCom Enemy Unknown, you will probably like this.

If you liked XCom Enemy Unknown, but at times wondered:

- Why can I only send one strike team at a time? Why only one base of operations? Why only one interceptor at a time?
- Why do my troops seem to have seemingly unlimited sources of conventional ammunition?
- Why are the aliens so reactive to my scouting that I'm rewarded for crawling forward at a snails pace to 'discover' groups one at a time, rather than actively scouting things out?
- Why don't the aliens ever try a direct attack against XCom (if you have enemy within, why didn't they try for a conventional attack a second time?)

then get Xenonauts; which does an amazing job of both bringing up the level of depth and realism that I've come to love from XCom (don't get me wrong, I think XCom is one of the best games out there and I love its character and offerings), and delivering something thats still unique and distinctive.

If you're looking for a game that does an excellent job tracking what a campaign against a hostile alien invasion might be like; Xenonauts is amazing. Buy it; buy it now!

reviewText:
Enjoying it so-far, but I will admit that the difficulty is rather high. The invasion escalates faster than research does... which has put me into an Edge of Tomorrow situation on a few missions. Hard to fight Ion weapons with lead slugs no matter how good your tactics are!

But, that aside...

GOOD: Solid X-Com clone, if you're into that kinda stuff. One thing that is pretty cool, is the radar installations. Rather than sweeping a continent, it sweeps a radius from the base at the center. This means you can kind-of tailor base placement to your strategy.

BAD: I should note here that I have not yet finished the game, so the badness might change. But from what I've seen so far... there's nothing really new here. When I said earlier that its an X-Com clone, it is just that. There's really no reason for this game to have been made, since it already existed before (albeit with inferior graphics). Difficulty curve is pretty steep (normal mode). The graphics are obviously kinda dated. I realize that this appeals to some folks, but I personally prefer my modern video games to look modern. Also there are some glitches with the physics where damage isn't quite right, like an alien saucer icing my dude through an intact wall. An explosion that somehow hurt a character when it took down a building that she was not in, on the flip side: 2 of my characters receiving no damage when standing right next to a car when it exploded. Aliens often have line-of-sight to their targets, but those targets are blocked when aiming back. Also I have a feeling that aliens do not have fog-of-war, or at least there is a glitch in their fog-of-war algorithm that makes it so it sometimes does not affect them.

Overall, I approve of this game. I love strategy, and the X-com style games in particular. While its exactly like some of the X-com clones in the past (UFO: Extraterrestrials especially) and brings nothing new to the table, I hold some hope that this game was made as a modern platform for the purpose of making expansions and DLCs that will add to the common base game. That would be a worthy idea: a UFO / X-Com game that gets periodic updates like PayDay2 does! Anyway that's my hope. Otherwise its just a more graphically-enticing X-Com (old game), which I suppose is fine if the new one was too dumbed-down for your liking, or if you just want MORE X-Com. But like... even the technologies are the same, and the species. Anyway, that's my take. Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
I love this game. I think the developers did an amazing job in recreating the old school feel of XCOM and turn-based squad mechanics.
Also, I love their dedication to their fans and their game. I bought the pre-release and even though I had to set it aside for almost a year because of bugs, I continuously checked the forums for progress and release dates so that I could play a full version.
My ONLY compplaint is that since it has been released, the patches are frequent and although no one reported too many problems, I did have a late game break (due to a wierd strategy game mechanic that cost me too much funding because I couldnt target UFOs for a few days) and had to start all over again.
I think Goldhawk Interactive sets and EXCELLENT example for Steam Early Access, especially at a time when many people are skeptical about Early Access companies delivering on promises.

reviewText:
Xenonauts has captured all the fun, excitement, and intrigue of the original X-COM games, and only intensified them in this amazing revival. With over 100 hours of play time logged on this gem, I can safely say that it is one of the most immersive and fun games I have played in a long time.
I have played Firaxis' X-COM and while I loved it, it still failed to quite capture the true spirit of the the original series. Not a problem with Xenonauts. Playing it feels like it was made by the exact same developers that made the original x-com, but with the approach and complexity that decades of gaming refinement have brought to the table.
I've heard some friends express a disenterest based on the graphics, but I can assure you that the elements of the game itself more then make up for this, and seeing how some 3D modeling can end up looking rather...cartoony or kind of silly (Planetary Annhiliation, Showrun Returns), I find it pretty refreshing.
I can't say enough about the content of this game. From the well written and detailed UFOpedia, that keeps a detailed description of every relevent item/creature you will come across and/or research, the rich histories of your team members; their prior combat experience, assignments, countries of origin, etc; to the HUGE tech tree to be plotted and explored.
The game takes place in 3 seperate environments...the Geoscape"
date: where you lay out your bases
hoursPlayed: hire and equip your soldiers/engineers/scientists
voteText: and watch for alien activity. Once an alien ship is spotted
helpfulPercent: you must dispatch interceptors to shoot down the enemy. Once your interceptor has engaged the ship
votesHelpful: the second environment is entered\nIn the second phase
votesTotal: the "Tactical Air Battle" phase
votesFunny: you control up to several interceptors in a top down arial battle against the enemy ships. I have seen this tactical phase balance and transform as it was developed
commentsCount: and can say they have done a fantastic job with this and the balance as you research and develope more powerful crafts.\nThe 3rd and final phase is the "Tactical Ground Combat" phase
column16: in which you control your customized team of soldiers (and various Heavy Weapon Platforms) in turn based combat against the alien invades after you have shot them down. You may also enter this phase without shooting down an alien ship if you get your lander to an already grounded UFO
column17: a terrorist site in which the aliens are already grounded and engaged in terrorizing a major city you must defend
column18: or an alien base they have established on Earth's surface.\nThere is a fantastic variety of terrain
column19: maps
column20: aliens
column21: weapons
column22: armor
column23: etc throught the game
column24: so it always seems fresh
column25: even 40 to 50 hours in. even after my 120+ hours of gameplay (have played offline at times
column26: who knows how many hours there) I still see new maps and have to come up with new strategies/approaches depending on situations.\nAll in all I would recommend Xenonauts to any gamer that won't be caught up on a lack of graphical complexity
column27: and especially for anyone who likes management
column28: strategy
column29: simulation
column31: this game is a great buy. I think the only thing keeping them from charging more is the lack of advanced graphics. The content is certainly up there with any Blockbuster game
column32: in my opinion. Thank you to the fine developers at Goldhawk Ineractive for a wonderful product."

reviewText: Well, I have finished the game for a second time (after a number of mis-starts) and have had a great time with it.  I enjoy the base/financial management aspect but the ground combat is what makes the game.  (The air combat I enjoy watching, but not manually fighting....I generally auto-complete it and hope for the best).  I actually enjoyed the game a bit more on Easy mode than Normal mode.  Normal mode was a challange, but felt a bit grindy to me after a while.  Ground combat is turn based style similiar to the original Xcom (or early Jagged Alliance games).  Fun to flank, blow up buildings, fly, etc.  (more variety mid to late  game).  Note you will get punished for sloppy ground tactics, even on easy levels (but not nearly as painfully as the higher levels).  While there may be best tactics"
date: I found you are able to complete missions a number of different ways.   I will come back to this fmame with the Community Edition/map packs (after a short break to work on my backlog).  The game was very stable for me (although I did have 2 crashes in 40+ hours
recommended: I suspect it had to due with my PC trying to run stuff in the background).    Cons - the final mission was a bit easy and the end screen anti-climatic.  Pros - great fun with turn based tactical combat; for me at least
hoursPlayed: definitely provided the flavor of the original game.   Also has a very active modding community which will give this game some staying power."

reviewText:
Below you can first find an in-depth 7 minute critique video and a written review below that. Thanks for watching and reading!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OnYLWd7Y8N4
STORY: Just as in the original X-Com games, extraterrestrial beings attack the earth and the poorly prepared humanity tries desperately to fend off the incoming aggression. Over time we learn to adapt and use the alien technology to our advantage, while at the same time stronger UFOs and aliens try to assault our planet.

GRAPHICS: The polished graphics are quite nice and offer a throwback to the old generation, however offering a surprising amount of detail at the same time. Some levels are, by their nature (arctic and desert), rather plain and simple, however other areas are rather impressive.

SOUND: The sound design is diffident. It creates a tense atmosphere where not encountering aliens is even worse than having them in sight. The minimal sound effects will make you sit on the edge of your seat as soon as something happens!

GAMEPLAY: Both the ground combat as well as the geoscape offer very strategic gameplay and an immense variety due to an array of tactical possibilities! Balancing when to expand your base, which planes to utilise to intercept which UFOs, which equipment to bring for ground assault and when to know that retreat is the best option is key to Xenonauts. The air-to-air combat seems rather shallow though and I found myself using the auto-resolve function most of the time.

PROBLEMS: The game does a really poor job of tutorializing itself and thus especially the UI, the cover system and the reaction shot system need a lot of getting used to. Once those initial hurdles have been overcome however, Xenonauts kept growing on me and the more I played, the more strategic options opened up due to the very flexible Turn Unit (TU) system.
There are a few minor annoyances like the fact that the soldies customization is incredibly limited since you can only change their name but not face, origin, etc., or the fact that changing equipment is rather time consuming and laborious, or the fact that the UFO's doors close after each turn and thus you always have to put a soldier in harm's way, or the fact that doing an airstrike on a ground target is always worse than actually assaulting the crashsite with your soldiers, even though nothing is to be gained there, resulting in a grind, or the fact that the calculated walk distance sometimes is shorter than it could actually be if you would have optimized the path manually, or the fact that your soldiers cannot utilise their jetpacks to jump over stuff on the highest roof due to level restrictions, etc etc etc. Nontheless, I can forgive all these minor annoyances due to the incredible atmosphere that oozes from Xenonauts, especially when fighting at night in an uninhabited environment.
There is one huge problem though, that still hinders me from playing Ironman mode, and that is the camera of Xenonauts. As it cannot be turned and as working with heights is incredibly clunky and frustrating, I feel that improvement on that front is required. Possibile solitions would be to include a rotate option for the camera or the possibility to switch off the walls similar to the Sims games. If no official solution is on the horizon, I hope and feel that the integrated mod support might lead to great solutions provided by the community in the future!

COMPARISON WITH ENEMY UNKOWN: Xenonauts has a far greater entry barrier and thus addresses an audience looking for a more strategic experience compared to the latest X-Com game (Enemy Unkown). If you are new to tactical turn-based games, consider checking out X-Com Enemy Unkown with it's Add-On Enemy Within, preferably in a Steam Sale. Should you be looking for a hardcore experience reminiscent of the old X-Com games, consider picking up Xenonauts as it offers not only the tactical turn-based combat but additionally a strategic geoscape, which was simplified heavily in Enemy Unknown.

CONCLUSION: Xenonauts is not perfect, however the tactical possibilities and the amazing atmosphere overcome the annoyances and problems. Thus Xenonauts gets a recommendation for every gamer with an interest in tactical-turn-based games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hey kids, have you played x-com. The original one? [jontronmoment]wwwhuszat? yusaidno? Wellthat'sunbeliavable, i don't even see how you came to that conclusion[/jointronmoment]

If you played xenonauts - you practically did. Basically it is a very faitful remake of x-com made by a huge fans, which resembles original almost on 80%.
Everything is there - ability to damage terrain, free fire, science and assembly division, neat ambient music, etc.
And it improves on so many levels which were under-taken in original x-com - like to example - aerial fighting manual mode is best one yet i've seen in fan-made x-com(1-2)'esque games. I mean - best one in series were in x-com 3, but i feel that lots of a-holes which did not actually played 3rd part gonna downvote me for that, but whatever. That's my review, i do whatever I want, god damn it.

Anyway - the game is neat and polished -it crashed only 2 times in 13 hours, and i were able to quickly recover from autosaves, authors just need a little more kicking to make finishing touches and find all the bugs. But even at this point - this is very stable release candidate rather than beta.
Almost everything is there, i believe teleporter and psionic sounds are the same, which they shouldn't be, also some plasma rifles have same sound.

But besides that - core is there, feeling of progress is there too, game just as addicting to mea s the original, and i just spent 14 hours playing it non-stop, for the note - in recent xcom reboot i got bored after 3 (6 in ufo afterlight) and barely finished it. Something to cosider.
I think main thing about this game is that it keeps throwing new stuff at you even after you think everything is done and beaten - on normal difficulty progression is rather slow, but rewarding at that - it doesn't feel rushed, nor does it feel too slow. Just hits the spot.

In the conclusion - buy this game guys - it worth every penny and delivers+it has crazy potential for modding since EVERYTHING is in xml+it has map editor.
And even if you played only reboot of xcom - but original x-com and this one and compare them back to back - they are pretty damn close and xenonauts most certainly can be called X-COM: UFO Defense 2.0.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

DISCLAIMER: Review based on early access and on current V1.03 build.  At this time the game is pretty much ready and should be set for official launch in the next few weeks.  Still working on finishing V1.03 build so review will be updated and finalised by official launch.

Summary: For all intents and purposes Xenonauts is a modern remake of the ORIGINAL X-COM from 1994.  Where as the modern X-COM Enemy Unknown changed alot from the original, making it more of a action tactical combat game (one that I enjoyed alot) it strayed from the original.  Many a vetran from the original game (including myself) have been clamoring for a remake of the original and, now, I can say, that has happened.

Xenonauts remains true to the original and as a player of the old game I was right at home with the controls and mechanics.  To summarise, the game puts you in charge of an organization charged with defending against and alien invasion.  Your main strategic view is the Geoscape, a full map of earth.  You start out by placing your first base whereever you wish.  You must make considerations for how much coverage it will give you and to which funding nations.  You will be able to develope your base, building new buildings, hiring new staff, training new soliders, researching new tech and building new gadgets.  You will outfit your troops and aircraft for battle and eventually build additional bases to increase your coverage.

Soon your first UFO's will arrive.  You will need to intercept them with your aircraft.  This can either be handled via auto-resolve for via an Aerial battle minigame which is surprisingly involved.  Once the UFO is downed (over land) you will send in your troops to retrieve the wreckage and elimate any surviving aliens.

From here, the game turns to the Turn Based Tactical map.  Your troops will start in your dropship, and you will have to move them about the map.  This portion uses a turn based system.  Each unit has X amount of time units which they use to perform any action, being it move, shoot, crouch, etc.  Shooting can take up more time units if you want to improve accuracy.  Once you have used up all your time units for all your units, you can end the turn.  Then the aliens will take their move, and it will then go to your turn etc.

Fans of the original and of old school Turn Based will be at home here.  It allows for fine control of each unit and as unit get more experiened, they will get more time units and their other stats such as accuracy, health, reactions etc will also improve.

The aim of the game is to defend against the aliens, tech up to be able to match them more evenly and eventuallly defeat the alien menance once and for all.

Pros: Playing the game, I felt like I was playing the original...I cannot think of higher praise.  For all intents and purposes this is  the original, given a face lift and brought into the modern world.  It streamlines things a bit, for example, no longer do you have to manufactor basic weapons, nor do you have to manufactor items such as grenades, flairs, and ammo.  This was tedious micromanagement in the original which has thankfully been streamlined now.  Instead, you focus on building weapons, armor, vehicles, planes etc.  Grenades, ammo etc are auto-crafted.

Also, now you have the option of calling in an airstike against a downed UFO instead of sending your combat team.  I remember in the original, during end game it was quite annoying having to deal with smaller UFO's that I shot down, so this is a welcome addition for when you don't want to have to deal with them.  You get a small amount of money doing this, but you gain much more if you send in your assault team.  It's nice to have options.

Now you have a wider array of weapons and equipment including Pistols, Shotguns, Shields, Rifles, Machine guns, Sniper Rifles and rocket launchers.  There is a class" system
date:
but basically this is just a set of pre-determined equipment.  You can assign any solider any class.  It is useful for quickly giving units gear and you can set what gear each class gives.

The graphics are beautiful 2d graphics and the interface works well now with modern conventions.

Cons:  Alas
recommended: all cannot be perfect.  The most pressing issue at the moment is bugs.  Even at V1.03 there are some bugs still left to be addressed
hoursPlayed: but the dev team is aware of them and looking to fix.  Right now
voteText: for me
helpfulPercent: I get crashes when new gear is made and I go to equip my troops.  Since I save alot
votesHelpful: and am now aware of this
votesTotal: it is not more than an annoyance.  I have spoken to the dev's and they are activly trying to fix this.\n\nMaps - While the game has some random placement within maps
votesFunny: it still uses an existing pool.  As such
commentsCount: before long you will be replaying the same maps over again.  The community has already published a map pack to increase the number of maps available.  However
column16: this will always be a problem when not using auto-generated maps.\n\nWeapons - A personal issue

column18: laser weapons handle exactly the same as the ballistic versions

but would be nice to get some more exotic weaponry that differentiates itself a bit more.

In Closing
If you like or are interested in Turn Based games with a strong strategic and tactical element you should give this game a try.  As I said before

reviewText:
Sooo, I am currently limited to a weak tablet as only means of computing power and decided to give this game a try, seeing it's requirements were rather humane and the screenshots looked neat. Handdrawn graphics, classic turnbased action. Seemed nice enough.

What I got from that was absolutely amazing. This game managed to pull me in entirely and made me go through hours, making progress and playing to see what it might pull out next. The handdrawn nature made the absolute best out of this. Detailed depictions of the autopsies, backgrounds for the sections of your base that look like a masterpiece each and change over the time as you develop new technology. It really proves that great graphical experience has nothing to do with a powerful GPU.
The narrative style of the game and lots of lore that come with it only increase the experience and keeps you going on, wanting to see the next artwork and the self loving speech of your chief scientist as he tells in his eccentric way of mixing imperial and metric systems what he developed this time.

Gameplay wise there is nothing too revolutionary, the game relying on what had been proven good on the early XCOM games and making you wonder why so much was lost in Enemy Unknown. It's a good strategic experience that challenges your mind at times but doesnt frustrate you or make you desperate to a point that you toss away the game.

I definitely recommend this to fans of Xcom and the genre in general, a good experience for casual players and more experienced alike and a pleasure to look at.

reviewText:
Did you used to play XCOM back in the day, and now crave a (slightly) more modern experience? Or maybe you played the new XCOM: Enemy Unknown, and found it a little too... gamey. Well, send in the Xenonauts!

COMPARED TO XCOM:

Xenonauts is a more user-friendly, streamlined version that replaces clunky UI for more strategic depth. And this game is DEEP. Spend you hard-earned cash on buffing up your wimpy troopers and giving them sweet, sweet gear or spend it like any rational government agency would and buy more bases and jets. Lots of jets. Upgrade those babies. Yeaaaaahhh... that's it. Jets are the future. I know those lasers look pretty, but jets make those governments happy... yeaaaahhhh...

Also you'll be happy to find that, although challenging, you won't have your entire team mind-controlled on the third mission.

COMPARED TO XCOM:EU or EW:

So you have your flashy graphics and simplified UI. But do you have air combat? Do you have the possibility of managing multiple bases around the world? Maybe you just want one base to have xenonauts in it and the rest filled with jets. Maybe you can't aford anything because you are bad at finances. This game has all the strategic depth that XCOM: EU lacks. Pinch those pennies, ladies and gents.

In Closing...

For those looking for a more management-oriented, strategic experience, Xenonauts will be more satisfying than its flashier cousins. It has its problems, but the free Community Edition fixes the majority of them. I really hope XCOM:EU and its sequels consider adopting the strategic management elements from this game; it makes it a vastly satisfying experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'll do my best to give a rundown of the game, up to the point I've played, as well as explain it to those of you who have never played a game like it.   Sadly the sheer size and complexity of the game, won't allow me enough room to give you a short and long version of my review.  Either way I hope this helps!

If you'd prefer to see the game in action, please take a look at my LP, it should give you a very good idea of what's going on.  If you grabbed the game and are stuck, check it out for a semi-tutorial/walkthrough, as well.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YHJ4gqex0Ok&list=PLtzgP48ATFJB1iDXzaSGTSHFD5ZHQTFYK
or
https://www.youtube.com/bumpymcsquigums

Xenonauts has been heralded as the classic X-COM games spiritual successor.  It's been compared to both new and old X-COM and it's still making quite a bit of noise.  The game is very playable and very enjoyable in it's current state but the devs are still hammering out little issues, doing balance and stability updates and trying to get Xenonauts perfect.  If you liked the old OR new X-COM games then you should very much like Xenonauts.  I could spend hours talking about the similarities between the two games, but you can read that virtually anywhere.  So, I will try to explain the game for those of you who have never played it before.

Xenonauts is considered a Strategic Planetary Defense Simulator.  It's around the time of the cold war in the late 70's and aliens have invaded the Earth.  You are the commander/leader of the Xenonauts and your goal is to basically do battle with the aliens and save the world.  You are graded" each month by the nations of the world and based on how much you helped them
recommended: gain or lose monetary support from the nations.  You have a lot of responsibility and control on how everything pans out or works.  You control where you want to set up your bases
hoursPlayed: what to build in the bases
voteText: which aliens ships to shoot down
helpfulPercent: what to research
votesHelpful: what to engineer
votesTotal: what roles your soldiers have
votesFunny: which soldiers to hire
commentsCount: and even which crash sites/missions to take.  There's a ton to do and it can be overwhelming at first.  I'll try to break it down a bit more.\n\nYour base is pretty much the very start of the game.  You have to place your base so you have decent satellite coverage over land.  The more individual nations you can cover
column16: the more likely you are to please them when the end of the month comes.  Anytime you shoot down an alien ship or send troops to deal with a crashsite or landed alien vessel you gain a sort of "reputation points" with the nation.  The more you deal with aliens in their nation
column17: the more they will fund you.  Likewise if you do not have coverage and alien activity occurs in other places or you ignore it
column18: you will lose those "rep points" and funding.  Base placement is important as is what to build in your base.  It might take some experimenting to find the perfect build.  Xenonauts does have a quick start guide to help you and one of the good things is
column19: it does not overkill you with a tutorial phase.  :)\n\nThe air combat is a pretty cool feature.  There is a mini-game you can do for the air combat when you send your interceptors after the alien ships.  It's well done and enjoyable but one of the really cool features is that the autoresolve is actually really really good.  So if you don't care to do the air to air mini-game
column20: you generally can autoresolve it and skip it.  To explain the mini-game briefly
column21: you can pause or unpause at any point and your ship(s) and the alien ship(s) will close with one another.  Then any weapons you have active at the time will fire on the aliens.  The aliens will fire back and you have the ability to do evasive manuevers as well as retreating.  The aliens also can avoid your missle fire
column22: so you have to plan accordingly.  It's all sort of RTS-ish with the ability to tactically pause.\n\nThe bulk of the game is spent in the ground missions.  It's what makes or breaks this type of game.  You have a roster of soldiers.  Hopefully you outfitted a decent variety.  There are preset classes as well as the ability to make your own.  It doesn't CHANGE the soldiers in anyway
column23: it's more to ease you gearing up people.  The classes are: Assault
column24: Sniper
column25: Shield
column26: Heavy
column27: Rifleman
column28: Scout & Rocketeer(and of course the ability to create your own).  So basically you click and assign your soldier to assault
column29: outfit it with whatever you want
column30: then save the gear configuration.  Then anyone you make an assault class will automatically get that gear.  They have different icons in certain places so it makes it easier for you to tell what role they play.\n\nAll that being said
column31: you chose your soldiers
column32: and deploy them in a drop ship.  Send the dropship to an alien landed craft or a crashsite and the ground battle begins.  It's a throw back to classic squad turn based strategy combat.  It's your turn and you can use any of your soldiers in any order.  You can move each and every one of your soldiers before you end your turn
column33: then it's the aliens turn.  You move cover to cover and with the implementation of the shield units
column34: you even have mobile cover!  All your moves/shots/actions are based on TU's (Time Units).  So any time you move out
column39: you use up a certain amount of TU's.  You can conserve TU's to make sure you can still shoot and move
column40: or have enough for reactionary fire (taking a shot at an alien if it moves past you or shoots at you).  The entire ground combat system is done extremely well and once you get the hang of it
column41: it's amazing.\n\nThose are the big things to cover most of the game.  A few other things worthy of mentioning is the fact that you can rename your soldiers
column43: and I'm pretty sure vehicles as well.  Naming your soldiers generally makes you care more about them and is a nice tool.  Your soldiers DO level up
column45: the lowest being Private and the highest being Commander.  Each time you go on a mission with your soldiers they have a chance to not only earn a promotion(i.e. level up) they also have a chance of increasing their stats.  The longer your soldiers survive combat and the more they do in the missions the better they become.  So it pays to play it safe and keep your people alive.\n\nThere's a ton to this game and I like virtually all of it.  I don't think I could explain each and every part of the game as there is simply SOO much.  I'll give a word of caution about some stuff and those are kind of my "things I don't like"
column46:
or "what's bad" in Xenonauts.

Two things I'd say to be cautious of are:

1.  At the current point in the game
column47: the devs are still hammering out issues here and there.  I have literally only run into one major issue at this point and that was my ironman game got stuck in permanent "Alien's Turn - Hidden Movement Screen".  They had planned to take the game out of early access at the end of May
column48: but decided it's not quite ready.  My word of caution is to NOT use Ironman mode until the game is out of early access.\n\n2.  Money is a bit of a challenge in this game.  Spending enough to keep everyone happy and getting good coverage but not so much as to over extend your funds and end up negative is a big challenge.  A LOT of people are having the issue of balancing what they need and what they can afford.  I know Goldhawk Interactive is still doing balancing
column49: so it's something they are trying to tweak.  It's just something to be cautious of.\n\nAll in all
column50: Xenonauts is an amazing game and I highly recommend it.  The UI is great
column52: the music fits the game perfectly.  It's well worth the investment of time and money
column55: and rewarding when you pull off a perfect plan.  Grab it now and support the Devs!\n\n"

reviewText:
The Metacritic is actually right on the money on this game.

The game is a decent stab at the old x-com game. Interesting setting, faithful to the original game mechanic (both the good bits and not so good bits), nice art direction and basically an enjoyable, stable indie game. Personally I rate this game better than the vanillar XCOM.

BUT, the EW expansion and the Long War mod are both far superior to Xeno. Why? Xeno suffers from being a pre-KS funded indie project that presumably had only a modest budget. The later half of the game runs out of steam with generic aliens, bland tech and pure incremental weapons era progression that makes everything kind of dull. WARNING: there are even LESS things to do than in the vanillar XCOM.

If you are itching for the classic x-com game and wished XCOM had TU instead, then pick up Xeno for a spin. Otherwise, try the long war mod.

reviewText:
To compare Xenonauts to XCom series would be the easiest, but also unfair way to deal with this enormous strategy. Quite certainly and without any shame, Xenonauts developers Goldhawk Interactive are speaking out the truth about their inspiration - Xenonauts is spiritual successor of acclaimed strategic game XCom: UFO Defense.

Gameplay resolves in circles which comprises of three main elements: management of your bases and strategic command centers via Geoscape, your game screen; real-time air combat and final stage - turn based ground combat.

Although we live in cruel time when hand drawn graphics are unfairly judged as unworthy by most of the (childish) players, get over retro, but charming hand-drawn sprites and you'll enter the world of comprehensive, multilayered strategy where you can manipulate every single aspect of your gaming experience. Numerous classes, weapons, tactics, strategies, upgrades and ideas have been brought upon the table and shrouded in mystery and atmosphere which perfectly collides panic of alien invasion and Cold war isolation.

There are numerous selling points to Xenonauts, but one of the most important IS and SHOULD BE that it's an honorable, greatly improved over original and richer hommage to XCom which delivers in every single aspect. It's unbeliveable that an indie team can deliver a game that even surpasses the original on so many fields.

If you're into aliens and hungry for some long-lasting strategic battles that will test your nerves, luck and decisions, go for it.

reviewText:
Why go throught all the trouble of making such a realistic remake if it is to break all the realism by making the earth flat ?

The original XCOM had it all right, the earth was a sphere.  And I'm not just speaking about the type of map projection used, I'm talking about the way aircrafts are travelling, the way radar ranges are depicted and things like that.

I don't feel like I'm defending a planet, I feel like I'm defending a flat table with a distorted map drawn on it, or more accurately a cylinder since the map connects on the sides.

In this game, on the ''flat map'' globe, the radar ranges are circular, no matter where you are on the globe, well they should'nt, the range of the radar should be factored for the fact that it's a flat map, it should widen towards the poles, otherwise the map is all wrong.  Every aircraft travel in a straight line, just like if the earth was flat, well they should'nt.  The map is distorted, and so are the trajectories and distances.  Now what would be the advantage of putting a base on the north pole, since the distances are so wrong when you consider the earth as a cylinder with very wide poles.  For example, in real life, the shortest route from the southern tip of Chile to Australia doesn't involve going all the way on a due east trajetory, it should be trought the south pole.  ( Where is the south pole anyway in this game ? )  By using such an unrealistic approach to the ''globe'' aspect of the game, it really breaks a big aspect for anybody who liked managing strategically the globe part in XCOM.  Once again, the original game from 20 years ago had it all correct, why change that ?

Don't get me wrong, I'm going to recommend this game to any XCOM fan.  XCOM was one of the greatest game of all times and any attempts at bringing back some memories of it should be funded and encouraged.  This remake is an excellent game, with one unnecessary big flaw in my opinion.

reviewText: For those who loved X-Com: UFO Defense/UFO: Enemy Unknown and want to have roughly the same experience as that 20+ year old game with the benefits of modern technology, then this is the game for you. Big battles, multiple bases, and a pretty severe difficulty. But there is new stuff too, like a better interface, a variety of neat toys to use against the aliens, and much more. On the downside, It can get a bit repetitive over time as you send a team to clear out yet another UFO you shot down, but I guess that just adds to the atmosphere of an endless conflict where you are badly outnumbered and outgunned. But you can fix that in time, of course. Still, this game will eat up alot of time, so be prepared for a major time commitment if you are planning on playing this to the end.\n\nSave the world from the aliens! Yey.

reviewText:
I did not play the old X-com games, but I did play the new one, so that will be my frame of reference in this.

To me, this game feels like XCOM:EU bashed together artfully with Jagged Alliance 2 - it's got the depth, graphic style, and sometimes gameplay of JA, with the basic concepts and more modern feel of XCOM. The UI is also somewhat JA style, but has been streamlined enough that it reminds me more of Fallout 2's UI. Like XCOM, it has managed to do away with the tedious, forced micromanagement of JA and other games of that period, but does also seem to reward it a bit if you want to take the time to mess with the details, and has made doing so much easier than games from the period this one is trying to emulate.

Yeah, reading that sure makes this game sound derivative, doesn't it?

That's because it is, and proudly so. And what's wrong with that? Why wouldn't I want a game that looks good enough. lets me tweak things as much or as little as I want, and plays and feels like some of the best games ever?

If you are into shiney graphics and found hard difficulty XCOM:EU to be fun and challenging enough, then don't bother with this - the normal difficulty is generally a little more difficult than hard EU.  If you thought it was a great game, but just lacking something to make it a real 700 hour monster time eater, then you should really check this out. If you liked Jagged Alliance or it's modern clone, then you'll love this - it plays very similarly, and the RNG, LOS, and other mechanics are less broken. If liked the quirky gameplay of Fallout 1 and 2 and the darkly comical world, then you'll probably like this, but if you found the combat there overwhelmingly hard, then you might not.

One more quick little note: If you haven't played any of the above, but want to get into this sort of games, this is a good place to start. Unlike most of them, the easy mode is actually easy enough fora brand new player to get the swing of things, but becomes challenging enough to be worth playing through to the late game.

reviewText:
You could call Xenonauts a truly faithful remake of the orginial classic Xcom: UFO Defense but is it actually any good or is it just a poor attempt at capturing that unique Xcom feeling like some many games have tried?

It's absolutely great! Despite having some minor flaws.

Xenonauts is basically a modernised and up-to date version of the classic with it's own little twists and features. Where Xenonauts excels is that it's just a really enjoyable experience. First of all the aesthetics might look pretty bland but they fit the game quite well and everything looks extremely sharp and detailed. There is a lot of great artwork and sprites in this game. The soundtrack totally enhances the threating atmosphere and truly immerses yourself into the game.

The gameplay mechanics are mostly identical except that they improved the interface and user-friendlyness. The classic Xcom had a lot of tedious micromanagement and a cumbersome interface. I never particularly enjoyed the logistics aspect of the classic. Xenonauts has a great interface that conveys information in a great manner. Equiping soldiers and manageing your base is far better. The research tree is great aswell and the descriptions add a lot of flavor to the game.

The tactical turn-based ground battles are intense and quite challenging thanks to the multitude of difficulties that you can choose from. The geoscape section is also greatly enhanced, the aliens won't hesistate to launch a full scale assault and there is far more to do on the geoscape than in the classic. They also add some nifty new options and events like local military fighting against the aliens as well and airstriking downed ufos.

There is much to talk about in this game but I'll keep it short for now, it's a great game for fans of the classics or turn-based games. I definitely recommend it.

The only negative aspects that come to mind is that there aren't that many maps, you will often see the same layouts during the battles. Luckily there is a huge mappack available on the official forums that adds tons of detailed and varied maps.

Also sometimes the tactical battles can be a bit fiddly on tight spaces and the cover system can be confusing at times, the line of sight works really well but at times it's confusing as well. But once you play for a while you get the hang of it.

reviewText:
I was excited about this release back in 2013 but for many reasons have not gotten around to it until recently. I don't have a lot of hours in yet but all I can say is WOW. This is the most faithful reproduction of X-COM: Enemy Unknown by a wide, wide margin - and that's no knock on the recent reboot by Firaxis; they are simply dramatically different games. Xeno distinguishes itself with the faithful depth and unforgiving, unapologetic tactical harshness that is carried by poor or reckless decision making.

It is amazing that we have both XCOM and Xeno, and that they are both such great games and I found a fantastic article below by Phil Hartup that dives so well in to exaclty this topic and provides an excellent history of what the franchise has gone through. Absolutely worth the time to read if your exposure to the franchise is rooted larely in the recent reboot, and if you loved the classic from 1994 and have, like so many of us, given up hope of a faithful reproduction after decades of disappointment - this is a slam-dunk to run long nights in to the dawn.

http://www.newstatesman.com/killing-time/2013/10/xcom-enemy-unknown-xenonauts-dumbed-down-game-any-less-fun

reviewText:
Much, MUCH like the 90's classic X-Com. Once you dive in, you'll see it.

The difference is the tech trees, discriptions, maps, aliens (beings, ships, weapons, ect). Their motivations are the same, plus the planet Earth, but the interface is quite improved.

You have pretty much total control - planning bases, troop management, improvements, mission planning -  the whole shebang. As you progress, the aliens get more numerous, dangerous, larger, more aggressive, and your apprehensions can get the best of you. Only downside is the end game - it was a tad gamey (maybe even letdown), expected something harder ala the old X-Com. Was fun, though....

There is ample mod support - The Commuinty Edition is widely played, and tweaks many of the standard game to enhance the experence, and is endorsed by the producer, and hosts a lively forum. Pretty darned impressive...

Been following this for a while, and it dropped off my radar, but quite glad it did not become vaporware. Great purchace, fantastic community, and heavily supported.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I never got the chance to play the original X-Com.  I heard the legends, of course, of all the things it did right that no other game (incuding newer X-Com titles) had managed: the perfect balance of weapons and gear so that every type of loadout has its use, the punishing yet fair difficulty (the aliens are stronger than you, but it's always possible to beat them), the general sense of dread at every crash site, the amazing metagame of base building and resource allocation across continents, and so many other features that added up to an amazing, tense, immersive, and satisfying experience.

I cannot say if Xenonauts is as good as X-Com, or how the two compare, but I can say this: Xenonauts does everything right.  It sounds crazy to say, but it's true.  The balance of both your equipment and enemies', especially with the latest patches and Community Edition, is perfect.  Both the metagame and tactical encounters are complex and satisfying.  Every choice, every action has weight, tension, and immense significance to your war with the alien threat.  Battles are tense, tactics are paramount; your soldiers' survival is tenuous, but if you use the right tactics, there is hope.

So, I cannot say if Xenonauts is as good as X-Com was, but I can say that it is as good as X-Com's hype, which is even more impressive.

reviewText:
8/10, Very good game

Review is for default v1.59 game. For enchanted playthrough, see notes about CE-version.

True successor in the spirit to the UFO: Enemy Unknown (1994), its sequel Terror from the Deep (1995) and Microprose's latest 'UFO-colors' game, X-Com: Apocalypse (1997).

Earth is under the attack by menacing alien forces which are gathered around the Earth orbit. Player is tasked to command Xenonaut-organization and plan the battle against this threat. Game consists of two parts: Geoscape where strategic planning happens and tactical turn-based combat which is heart & bone of the UFO-games.

When compared to it's predecessors, game plays fairly lot in the same way. On Geoscape you build your own bases and try to maintain air superiority. Xenonauts get their (small) funding from the continents of the Earth. So one of the top priorities is build air superiority cover over the world parts if you want to receive spending money in the upcoming months. Air superiority means that you have to acquire interceptors, research upgrades to keep your edge up and shoot down UFOs. In addition of embarking to turn-based battle, any UFOs shot down could be airstriked for fixed sum of money and saved real world time.

Aliens seem to first have problems to enter inside Earth atmosphere except with small crafts but that is rapidly changing. Therefore ground combat also has an important role: you acquire alien artefacts and your hired soldiers will get more experience. Increasing your soldier's statistics is one game aspect where you prepare to the end game. Also as this is an UFO-game, there are some inevitable combat losses which means you need to keep up healthy sized pool of soldiers. Also you have to protect your bases which usually means keeping the garrison on the base.

On turn-based you get usual TB-game mechanics, with mid-turn interrupts and soldier movement is limited by 'time units'. Game design blunders are mostly avoided: xeno-soldiers can 'peek' from the corner facing diagonally towards it. Protection and cover is calculated only using the largest blocking object, making the decisions very simple. Weapons are labelled in very generic categories instead of giving you multitudes of the same. Assault rifle is an assault rifle, until you get a laser rifle (which works in exactly same way). This means you could pick generic weapon genre and chosen weapon would work in that role as expected. Combat system sounds very simple, but in practice it's working. Sure, you could have bad luck with the dice roll and aliens might get lucky shots, but that's UFO for you... do not leave your soldiers to the line of sight. :-)

However, some things does not exist even advertised, like jumping through windows or are not advertised at all even they are actually useful (melee attack). Structural damage seems quite mild and there are no spectacular building collapses and wild-fires like in Apocalypse. Game will still have some irritating bugs for which I seriously considered score of 7 from 10. Also I would have liked to have several dropships on the same mission to train my rookie hordes, but you can't get everything, eh? Until you realize there's modders community...

Interface works enough well to do it's job. That's all I have to say which means it's pretty mediocre, simplistic but it won't get in your way. Some people on forums have commented on lack of tablet/touch screen support.

To the credit of the writer every game tech has fairly convincing description how this particular piece fits to the game universe. Even the upgrade works in exactly same way - like assault rifle works technically exactly as plasma rifle  - there is explanation how this particular piece of technology would affect the game universe. Also game soundtrack consists only of few pieces, but these are fairly moody.

If you have waited all these years to pickup old UFO/X-Com and play again, look no further than Xenonauts. Game package additionally contains a short novel. Fairly generic reading, but entertaining enough and it adds to the game lore.

Edit: To avoid already fixed bugs and errors in the game, you may want to use Community Edition (CE) version for your first playthrough. You can install CE version through the Steam.

reviewText:
xenonaughts has a lot of charm and i really want to love it but its punishingly unforgiving

you can make one misclick with the mouse(which can happen often) and it can set off a chain of events that cause you to lose the entire campaign,..very frustrating when youve put in 20+ hours inro that campaign

part of the charm is how punishing the difficulty is as youre constantly on edge and fear just walking round the corner
but when your own soldier shoots a waist height wall in front of them like a talentless spaz causing him to die and the whole squad to panic and run into the open to be shot down one by one,..then it seems youre up against poor programing as well as a very high difficulty

fortunately the games text files are pretty easy to open and tweek
