reviewText:
Absolutely Amazing!

Faithful to the original X-com, xenonauts keeps the core gameplay mechanics and tense atmosphere that made the original so awesome. Personally, i see xenonauts to be superior over the new X-Com: ennemy unknown, because the gameplay is alot more tense, visceral and complex. But not only does it come true to the original, it even expands on some concepts, adds alot of new mechanics and gadgets such as the deeper air combat missions and increased arsenal of your soldiers.
Time units are back, and so comes the class-less soldier promotion system. it is up to you to choose the exact equipment and role of the soldier, and you can come up with very individual loadout choiches perfectly fit for the individual stats of the soldiers, adding alot more depth to equipment. Like in the original xcom, there is a fog of war and aliens shoot out of the dark. if you are careless with a soldier and run around a corner without looking to your side, you will soon run into trouble.
And the thing that makes a real xcom game: Absolutely hilarious/dramatic soldier deaths, situations that escalate quickly, missions that end up in absolute disasters and horror. The best moments were when a plan just did not work out, one soldier after another dies, and suddenly it becomes all about saving the remaining soldiers from their certain death.
The music adds to the atmosphere, and so does the fantastic art direction. I absolutely love the minimalistic, but effective graphical design, and the grim soldier portraits really add alot to the entire scenario.
Occasionally there were some minor bugs which i hope will get fixed someday, and the only thing that annoyed me was the fact that there was no option to change the camera angle, as it would have made navigating trough corridors and detecting the location of grenades on the floor alot easier. Additionally the vertical view of the soldiers seems to be a bit weird, because walls do not seem to obscure the vision of soldiers on upper floors very effectively.
All in all a very well rounded, challenging and absolutely awesome experience, and for anyone interested in an xcom game, i can safely declare xenonauts as the new gold standard for this genre.

reviewText:
More Reviews @ TheVideogameBacklog.com

If you were looking for the spiritual successor to the X-Com franchise, Xenonauts feels like the game you’ve been waiting for. Even though The Buraeu: X-Com Declassified and Enemy Unknown/Within were great games in their own right, they just didn’t quite capture the same feeling that the classic games had. While some things need to evolve and change, there’s something to be said about making a recipe with most of the same ingredients to enjoy the meal you remember. (That’s especially true if they are going to say that it tastes similar.) I covered a lot of the basics of this game in the X-Com: Enemy Unknown VS. Xenonauts review so I’m not going to cover everything since Goldhawk Interactive finished up everything that needed fixing to transition from Early Access to Launch status pretty smoothly.

Let’s start with difficulty shall we? That was a trademark aspect of the originals. (I still can’t complete TFTD.) I started Xenonauts on the Regular difficulty and had both starter interceptor planes shot down in one-on-one dogfights. (At which point I had nothing to shoot down enemy aircraft.) The enemy craft ended up landing after downing my two aircraft giving me my first mission… out of pity. During the pity mission (which happened to be a night mission of course) I had lost two soldiers before I got ten spaces from my Chinook from enemies I couldn’t see. Needless to say I started over and changed the difficulty to easy. I usually don’t like playing games on easy, but this game just kicked me in the nuts and laughed in my face.

Thinking that the game was going to be too easy after the difficulty was changed was a bad assumption on my part. That little dead alien in the corner reminded me that I shouldn’t let my guard down. This little bugger skirted around the edge of the map taking pot shots at my guys almost killing two of them. I was throwing out flares left and right to try to find him to no avail. I eventually found him by sending one soldier randomly to the side of the map and just happened to spot him. Needless to say, when he became visible, the bullets went flying.

Moving on, research has been overhauled to be more convenient for the player. Let’s just say that you go out on your first mission and you clean house very well. When you get back to base you have only a few options to research, general concepts like alien electronics or alien interrogations if you managed to capture an alien alive. What about the dissections and the alien craft that you left behind? Well, it’s being taken cared of. That’s being done behind the scenes and you’ll get that info in good time and the other related research options therein. You still have plenty of things to research so don’t feel robbed here; Xenonauts makes research feel streamlined.

Another interesting note is that wounded soldiers heal more realistically. This is a neat update while at the same time pretty frustrating. I liked it when people just took a few days off and then poof they were combat ready and good-as-new. In Xenonauts they take time to become combat ready with reduced stats and even more time to fully recover. When the number of days are up for your soldier to enter the field again, they are given a percentage of how much they’ve recovered. You’ll have less health to run around with and lose when you get shot. As time goes on, they do get better, but that’s with time.

There are plenty of different looking locals between deserts, desert bases, towns, farms and enemy bases. They have different maps for the same type as well so you’ll never really feel that “you’ve been here before”. That is a very nice feature, because few things feel as cheap than reused levels. Some may call the graphic choice dated, but not only does it look nice aesthetically, the devs do a great job setting a creepy atmosphere with it. I really like the presentation of Xenonauts.

One last note, the NPCs in Xenonauts are freaking amazing. Some are just helpless civilians and do stupid civilian things, but the guys with guns (soldiers and farmers) actually use thier guns to defend themselves. I’ve had some levels be finished by some random farmer killing an alien before my guys got to the part of the map. Well played Goldhawk Interactive, well played.

Score: Tasty!

There is a lot to love here for fans of tactical games. Nothing feels rushed and sometimes that’s a concern people have when games come out of Early Access. It’s all smooth running and gunning here. With the varied locals and very nice looking isometric scenery, there is some really good “retro” (if you want to call it that) eye-candy to be had. Goldenhawk Interactive doesn’t go out of their way to revamp the series with light blooms and next-gen graphics. They pull from what made the originals so great and modernize it. I have nothing bad to say about Xenonauts (especially since they allow me to lower the difficulty setting). I will try a harder difficulty later, but as of now I appreciate having my ego padded a little more.

reviewText: As a huge fan of Turn Based Strategy games, and being raised on X-Com (Still own the floppy discs) I have to say if you're looking for a spiritual successor to the original games this one matches it the closest.\n\nIf you're familiar with the original X-Coms this game will seem very familiar to you. The game falls into two categories of gameplay. A globe you must monitor, while in this Geoscape" the world will go through day and night cycles. During this time you can set scientists to research
recommended: and slowly build from a tiny strike force into a globe encompassing powerhouse as you aquire more and more alien technology and information of what they are doing on earth. The key to this part of the game
hoursPlayed: is sending out fighters to have aerial battles in a very neat radar style where you move your fighters around to position for maximum effectiveness
voteText: or to eventually touch down your transport vehicles to enter the next stage of the game.\n\nThe second part is where the core of the gameplay lies. A turn based isometric game. Rather than diverging away from the original and giving them 2 actions like the new X-Coms. Characters have AP
helpfulPercent: meaning all of your abilities must be carefully calculated for the perfect shot or just to hope you can run far enough away after missing and shouting out loud at your computer.  These points can also be used for a variety of abilities
votesHelpful: from weaponry to alien technologies.\n\nThe gameplay feels very genuine and solid
votesTotal: you'll never curse the game for slip-ups
votesFunny: as it's quite informative about how much AP an action or moving will work. Although knowing if something will still be blocking your shot can be somewhat confusing. The feeling of moving inside of an alien ship will fill you with as much dread as it used to. The only issue that ever came up was spotting enemies and still not seeing them in game.\n\nI was a bit skeptical about the price as I suppose I've been spoiled by steam
commentsCount: but this game is definitely worth it as of now. Although some of the art assets seem a bit out of place and a bit to cartoon like
column16: the art inside the turn based is smooth and polished enough to recognize what's happening. And notice some very nice cosmetics
column17: particularly the exterior of  the alien ships.\n\nIn terms of soundtrack
column18: you'll find it quite suspensful which is always a pleasure on games like this. The sound effects are crisp
column19:
and hearing an alien scream as you shoot across the map will give you a little fist pump moment.

Honestly pick this one up and support the devs. Have fun with it and know this is one of the best successors to those old games you loved.

I'd give it a 9/10
column20: my only qualms are some of the art assets
column21: and a few technical issues. Beyond that it's been a great game!"

reviewText:
This homage/ripoff of the original 1994 version of X-COM is generally updated and improved, but is actually more clunky and awkward by the standards of its time than the now old-enough-to-drink original game. There's no tutorial (and the game DESPERATELY needs one), you can't rotate the camera in combat, preparing your squad for combat is needlessly split across three different areas of the base, soldiers are MORE difficult to tell apart in combat than the original game because every race and gender has the exact same sprite (except for the weapon it carries).

There's just NOT enough effort here to make things clear. In air combat YOUR planes show how much HEALTH they have left, but alien ships show the reverse - how much DAMAGE they have taken (remember that bit in the Bruno movie about the importance of consistency?). You can only see your weapons' stats at base (and only in a particular place at base - can't examine the weapon your soldier is actually holding, no sir, we don't like that kind of basic UI consistency around these parts, Yankee!). In combat, you don't even get to see how many Time Units you need to reload a gun - the reload button just beeps at you if you don't have enough. And don't get me started about the horrible system for reserving Time Units to shoot your gun, which doesn't reserve the Time Units you need to be able to actually turn towards the target so you can shoot it (would anyone really object if they just let you turn for free when you attack, like in the Rebelstar game on Gameboy?!)

Oh, and the art and sound are just nowhere as good as the original X-COM. X-COM's blurry VGA graphics didn't age well, but at least all the aliens looked scary instead of goofy (well, maybe not those dumb Floaters or that Jello alien) and you could clearly tell which room in the base was which - you can't say that about Xenonauts. And a chill still goes up my spine whenever I hear that blaster bomb sound effect used on TV for something else.

You can make a strong argument that X-COM 2012 lost some of the original's charm with gamey" elements and being dumbed down
date: but it also had some clear improvements that Xenonauts is sorely lacking. Despite 2012's many terrible design choices
recommended: it's still clearly the true sequel to X-COM."

reviewText: FINAL RELEASE REVIEW: This review was originally a negative review. It turned into a positive one, and now it's negative. Prepare for a rant.\nXenonauts still feels like it's in beta. Civilian A.I is stupid. You can't tell them to stay put; they still run around like idiots and get killed. The game pretends the aliens have moved. A lot of the time, you won't be able to see an alien after your team JUST took potshots at it. You will have to move up a squadmate (wasting that soldier's TU) so that you can see the alien again, which has not moved. The game's rendering system is RIDICULOUS. Here's an example: I activated C4 on the front door of an alien ship. The turn ended. The area where the fire should have been was dark. It seemed like the C4 failed. I brought my soldier up and he walked into fire that didn't even render until he stepped on it. Seriously? Also, if you have your tank (hunter scout car) blow up in front of the UFO doors, you're ♥♥♥♥ed. You can't open the doors, shoot through the tank, get on top of it, or push it away. The animations are lacking severely. The doors just snap; there isn't any cool animation of their opening. The geoscape takes a bizarre amount of time to load, too. It's a ♥♥♥♥ing PICTURE, not some 3D holographic image from XCOM: Enemy Unknown. The soldiers are ♥♥♥♥ing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, too. Am I hiring my family members and people off the street to join my organization or something? Like I said, this game still feels like it's in beta.

reviewText: It's great to finally see a game that lives up to the x-com legacy. It tries its own thing here and there and most of the time it manages to improve on the concept. It is not perfect, but it is a damn well realized vision and re-imagining of the original X-Com formula.\n\nIf you enjoy strategy games in general, or turn-based squad combat in particular, it's a no-brainer. Buy it. Will not disappoint.

reviewText: This game was not made in a vacuum. If it were not for XCOM: UFO Defense, I doubt this game would have been made. That being said, it is more than fair to strictly compare Xenonauts to XCOM:UD and the latest, much more streamlined, XCOM: Enemy Unknown.\n\nGiven the choice between XCOM:EU and this, I would choose the former. The over-simplification of XCOM that Xenonauts sought to address is no longer a concern once The Long War mod is installed. Xenonauts' incredibly plain graphics and visual design are something I just cannot get past. Everything about it is pure blandness. XCOM has unique visuals, and most importantly, small graphic nuances during the tactical combat that makes it feel like a thrilling shootout. Xenonauts on the other hand is a VERY by the numbers turn-based tactical game.

reviewText:
This is an amazing game by an indie developer, well worth purchasing if you enjoy strategy or xcom or even the new x-com


Presuming you know the genre already

Pro's
You can build more than one base
You can build bases anwhere you like(on land) and it matters where geographically, not just 'base in xxxx country' you can protect multiple counteries with a single well positioned base
You can build individual buildings in your bases any way you like(it matters if/when a base is attacked)
Nations care wether you protect their airspace
You can recruit soldiers and make them ANY class you like and equip them in many different ways(ie, carry a sniper rifle and  a rocket launcher if you like, weight matters of course)
You can send your fighters on patrol even if you don't have radar range in a spot (get lucky!) or respond to civilian reports just outside your radar coverage
MULTIPLE DROPSHIPS
Manufacture gear
Scientists and Engineers require space to live/work
Beautiful music and very nice art design
There is more than 1 ufo at a time, at times.

Cons
Crashed once in about 20 hours of play
I wish I could customize my soldiers color to more easily differentiate them(ie, know without clicking/looking at what they are carrying)
You will play more than you should. . . . . . .

PLEASE DO YOURSELF A FAVOR AND BUY!!!!!

Add me if you have any questions :)

reviewText: I dont want to be too harsh, as I kind of enjoy the game. Problems are front and center though. Like aliens having amazing accuracy and your soldiers dying quite often. Its not that the loss is unbearable, I like that, its really just a balance issue. The combat is way off. Its best to just have a random guy you didnt name, push up with a shield. Then all the other characters use sniper/rifle, and a machine gunner. This circumvents the crazy high enemy accuracy/damage. It makes the combat dull and even without that element, the combat is dull enough since its really a very standard turn based combat system.\nThe building of your base is clunky, after awhile you figure out what does what (most of it), and why you need it. But building is expensive and income is limited. Early on you can only wait to loot UFOs you shoot down. Thing about that though, is on my first game I had the game is max fast forward and waited a literal 8 minutes before a UFO triggered my radar. Bad placement, I thought... Worst of all, I couldnt catch the UFO. I waited another 3 minutes in max speed, until I got my first UFO. Then inbetween them, they were so scarce. My 3rd game was much better, still more rare then I liked, but I got about 11 of them, out of maybe 18, shot down and secured.\nThe research and mechanic shop are nice, the game does have a good feel to it, but overall the problems with it bog it down from being overly exciting or absurd fun. I got it on humble bundle for like 2$, at that price I absolutely recommend it.

reviewText:
This is not the improved x-com for which you were looking. It feels unfinished and in time modders may fill the gap but its painful and repetitive in a way that the original was not. The start of the game is well tuned and feels like the original and you don't notice how the AI reacts to your approach often increasing in aggressive level (which in gameplay terms equivalent to knowing you where you square are). However, the gameplay barely advances as the game progresses; at least on veteran alien scales faster than your weapons and there is no psi combat. This just means later missions are just slower and longer than at the start. The tech tree has the same feeling, repeated upgrades but without any excitement or dynamic change to you as the player. In addition without psi combat of your own alien psi is just another random frustrating element to add to the handful of aliens with three times the health of your toughest troops you will find camping in the final room of each downed alien battleship

I am amazed after my first few hours to say that the latest xcom reboot that i felt i barely made through the campaign without being bored probably has more replayability.

reviewText:
Although I enjoy playing the game, it definitely has really clumsy and illogical mechanics to it.

The game has great artwork, and the actual strategy and gameplay is solid enough for me to want to play it for a few hours at a time (which is rare), but there are things in the game that make it hard for me to recommend it.

For example, corners turn out to provide 0 cover and there is no clearly defined cover system. This means that a guy crouched in a doorway with a riot shield is actually completely exposed from 45 degree angles. And the game is full of things like this. Where did you toss that grenade? At the alien? Or is it at your feet? You'll find out soon..

The game is full of small bugs, poor design, and crashes every once in a while.

The menu system is also extremely clunky, and could've been much better. A huge amount of the game is spend managing through the menu system that is simply painful to use, especially for the outfitting of soldiers.

And soldiers are completely depersonalized except for a portrait and their origins. No matter what backround or gender a soldier comes from, they will appear on the map as a faceless white guy. There is no dialog or anything.. just feels like a missed opportunity.

I love the game for the strategy and the cold war art style, but I just can't recommend it to anyone who isn't a hardcore strategy fan

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Xenonauts is quite ok game honestly, but do not expect too much. It is slightly modernized X-COM and that's all.
Graphics is indie-good. Transition to Cold War times is a nice move and ufo-generated events (abductions, crop circles etc.) adds a lot to the game creepy atmosphere. The story... well, I can't tell much about it yet, but it can turn out to be good.

Otherwise this remake of X-COM is extemely close to original, even in its awful, really awful interface and slow uneventful combat system. Seriously: Time Units suck, especially when interface doesn't help you much to predict whether you have enough of them to complete your plan. Soldiers can't look behind a corner! They need to WALK behind a corner, then TURN - take a REACTION shot from an enemy - then maybe SHOOT, then WALK back. WTF. Cover system is very obscure. You cannot tell at first glance how much protection a cover offers and where you should place your soldier to use it effectively.

New air combat is unnecessarily hardcore though it can have an appeal of its own. I struggled to fight against light scouts losing a fighter after a fighter, while autocombat offered me a 100% victory. It's not impossible to master, but well, it's hardcore. I warned you.

Back to ground missions. Maps are extremely similar to each other. I found myself playing on the same map three times in a row, only differences being my starting place and UFO type!

Xenonauts could be a much better game if they dared to shred some X-COM's obsolete features like TU's and interface micromanagement, but well, we have Firaxis XCOM with Long War mod for that.

reviewText:
The game is buggy to all hell, and crashes constantly. Often not randomly. The keyboard binds do not save, and the interface is.. sticky and unpolished.

Between losing support, the insane maintenance cost of multiple bases, staff, vehicles and production costs,
the game difficulty curve never changes, and there is nothing you can do get ahead of it. Your troops never even get as good as the aliens troops, they are ALWAYS better, faster, more accurate.

The aliens are ALL snipers (even the blind ones). They can shoot through glass, over obstacles and kill your troops in one hit easily on normal. Whereas my troops will sometimes miss a 3 yard shot with an 85% chance to hit, 4 times in a row. Or a heavy weapons soldier with a 25% chance to hit will miss all 10 bullets with his\her burst. Even with 8 Colonels for a fire team my troops cant help but shoot each other and miss 95% accurate shots way more often then they should. Additionally, shots are % based on your total time units, so your troops NEVER get to fire more shots per round, just move further.

The reaction fire system makes it almost impossible to kill any aliens without getting shot yourself by the alien who's turn it ISN'T, because all the aliens seem to have AMAZING reaction times.

2 Months into the game you need 4 bases and 20 fighter craft to deal with the entire worlds ufo problems and you will only have money 1\5 of that. Ufo invasions come in literal swarms so your ships sit and wait or are outnumbered 3 to 1.

Scientists and engineers can NOT be moved from base to base, they must be fired and re-hired.
(What year is it and how many turn based strategies have there been?)

Tech options (research trees) are mundane and boring. Its the same old Balistic-Laser-Plasma, blah, blah, blah. Translation: more damage, better accuracy, different sound effects. Nothing interesting like a toxi-gun, or other biologic warfare. Even the bullets from the shotgun look like sniper and assault rifle bullets. Same with laser and plasma.

All in all. The game is glitchy, my soldiers would rather shoot themselves, and it's a save\load-fest even on normal, the load times on the larger ship missions are un-godly long..oh and no quick save\load option.

X-Com Apoc is STILL the best turn-based strategy. It was beyond stable, ran like water off a hydrophobic surface, good mission time vs geo-scape time balance (didn't spend 98% of your time in missions), well balanced difficulty curve (troops got dope), with interesting tech options.

The soundtrack on Child of Light would get a better score than this game.

reviewText:
I got this game while to hold me over until xcom 2 came out and was quite hyped for it after some of the gameplay I had seen.

The logistical aspect of the game, managing your bases , building facilities and hiring more staff is awesome. and has even more scope then xcom eu. The abilitiy to build and field TANKS was one of big things I was looking forward to in this game and I was not disapointed.

I never played any of the original xcom games so I found the combat a little hard to grasp, and it took me awhile to figure out how turn units work, but after I got past the learning curve it wasn't bad at all.

The artwork is top notch and all the lore behind research projects is well worth the read.


You're probablly wondering why I'm giving this a negative review after hearing how great I think the game is, but the last is also the most important.

The game feels dead.......When I go on a mission and deploy my troops there's no life, A simple idle animation would suffice so people don't look like cardboard props standing in a field. There's no discernable ambiance and while this may not sound very important, it is. The game might actually be very entertaining but after a few minutes it simply gets to dry to play.

I hold high hopes for the next game because with just a little more work this game could easily be better than the current xcom.

reviewText: I waited on this game for close to what... a year now? At first I was unsure if it was worth the money, and people's complaints about LoS and other annoyances held me at bay even more. Today, finally, FINALLY a discount worth getting the game at. I love it more than the new X-Com. Not only do I already enjoy it's systems just a few hours in, but besides the stray trick-shotting alien, the game runs perfectly and feels fair. The time period is spot on, the music is spot on, and the atmosphere gets so tense that I have jumped twice playing so far. Top this with the time units, allowing you to pop out of cover and fire, the great LoS(the ability to face your soldiers and actual vision arcs)/cover (the abiltiy to crouch, and intervening objects actually having an effect on accuracy) systems and you have a tactical game that is better than most on the market. I've dumped copious amounts of money to my regret into games that are too slow or too shallow, where the atmpshere it too light for the game or the game too light for the atmosphere. Xenonauts does not stand in the ranks of those games. If you played the new X-Com, throw it away and come learn how to run an actual defense network. Buy it. I give you my word you wont regret it. The truth is out there.

reviewText:
XENONAUTS FANBOIS BEWARE : THE FOLLOWING WILL BE A HARSH COMPARISON TO THE CLASSIC XCOM (1994 - 1995), DO NOT READ THIS REVIEW IF YOUR WELLBEING DEPENDS ON CONSTANT GLORIFICATION OF THIS GAME OR IF YOU GET UPSET EASILY :

(scroll down if you want to read about reality, please)







































1) in parts buggy

2) bad, miniscule research

3) interesting aircraft-recovery, losing a craft costs nothing but WILL cost time (usually 72 hours)

4) difficulty-progression is worse / more steep than in XCOM (yes, the real, classic ones) - basically you have 2 years  ... which is far from good and isnt any fun --- unlike XCOM in which the player has at least a decent amount of time before ♥♥♥♥ hits the fan

5) available money seems adequate at first - but if you dont want to lose after 2 years you will need to invest EVERYTHING and fear every loss because that can (and will) end the game. Thats XCOM on high difficulty, in this game its medium. Thats sad.
(i dont remember the exact difficulty-names, sorry)

6) research doesnt make much sense - the results are well explained but its senseless to gain knowledge about ARMOR during PLASMA RIFLE reseach, for example - that should've been available after alien alloys" .... and its only a small example

date: even if your fighter has already left\n\n9) ground combat is ... not bad

everything else looks pretty cheap to be honest and thats exactly what this game is -- even the dying-animations (if one could call em that) are cheap and consist of .... one (?) single step - in XCOM it was at least 2-3 per alien.

11) It has no XCOM-like feeling

reviewText:
I don't understand the positive reviews because this game is not very polished or playable. The level of polish is from a game I would have expected 20 years ago. It doesn't have the same playability as the original XCom and shouldn't be compared to it.

1. The in-game help does a poor job. Why does it say I don't have enough hangar slots for a new fighter when I have a free hangar? This and a bunch of other questions send me to google searches 10 minutes into the game.
2. Why is it when I buy new solders they don't show up in my ship list?
3. Why it is when one research completes it doesn't automatically start a new research on my queue, instead of requiring me to manually assign scientists?
4. It's extremely cumbersome to reserve action points. I have to click or make a hotkey to reserve a certain amount, but this doesn't account for kneeling or soldier rotation.
5. Melee attacks don't work, clicking the button just uses action points and does nothing.
6. How many action points do I need for grenades? No way to tell that doesn't take a lot of clicks.
7. How does cover work?
8. How does overwatch work?
9. Things which should be simple take many clicks - healing myself, throwing grenades, assigning soldier gear.

There is no in-game narrative. Unlike XCom which has animations and voice acting to flesh out the feel of what is going on, you are just dumped into a bunch of spreadsheets and left to figure things out.

The only real positive to the game is the 2D art, which is generally well done.

reviewText:
I bought this game expecting a modern take on the classical XCOM formula. Instead I got a huge buggy mess.

Ground combat is just too damn clunky in almost every aspect from taking cover to how field of vission works, how grenades are thrown, etc. Turns out trained armymen don't know how to shoot around corners...

While I enjoy some of the added depth that Enemy Unknown/Within lacked, the gameplay itself is just subpar in almost every aspect except the air combat part which is better in Xenonauts.

I really wanted to like Xenonauts but that is not happening. I suggest you keep away.

reviewText:
UPDATED: With the release of version 1.51 I decided to give this game another go.

Unfortunately after putting in enough time to get to the final mission I still have to give this game a thumbs down.  Much of the game has been improved, many bugs fixed but there's ultimately still some very weak or bad mechanics and a lack of balance to the game.

The difficulty level even at Normal is still punishing of even the smallest of mistakes.  By the end game even with troops with almost all max'd stats using the best armor and weapons available it's not uncommon to be sniped at by monsters that are beyond view range and are very good shots, sometimes killing your soldiers in one hit or two hits.  This turns the game into a load/save fest because if you lose your well trained troops in late game it'll be very hard to train new troops with bad stats up to the level your previous troops were.

There's still issues with visibility and firing angles that often don't make sense, such as cases where I'm 100% blocked from shooting an alien I can see but yet it can shoot at me.  Also missed shots are entirely too erratic, standing right behind your own tank your veteran soldiers can still fire off a shot so badly aimed it hits and severely damages your own tank.  Or trying to shoot an alien in a second story window and having the missed shot hit a stack of pallets 10 feet in front of my soldier at ground level.  I've never fired a real gun in my life but I'm confident I could get the bullet to go in the general direction of the window with minimal training.

Morale also gets silly, my squad has been on dozens of missions, each member killing dozens of aliens, but still will find reason to panic or flee at times.

Many UI elements are not well designed or missing information.  When you unlock new weapons that you can build in your workshop there's no tooltips in the workshop to provide details on what the stats of the weapons are.  So you end up having to blow money to build a single weapon to then look at its stats to understand if you want to bother making more.  Item weight is not listed in the tooltips either, you have to equip them and do the math to figure it out, not hard, but annoying.  It wasn't clear to me until late game that when intercepting an alien craft you can send multiple planes.  Hiring a soldier and putting them in a dropship requires going through 3 screens.

It's odd that you can't build other base buildings until the command center is completed. This isn't apparent until you experience it firsthand.  So be careful - the second base you build is going to take 10 days longer than you think it will.  They should really let you plan out/execute a blueprint all at once for the entire base.  Take into account build times and existing structures automatically if you want.

Run in Windowed" option only works if the resolution is less than your native desktop resolution.

Other countries that you don't have coverage over seem to lose money faster than reasonable when playing at normal difficulty even after version 1.51.

The entire interception portion of the game is entirely too tightly balanced and crucial to success.  I'm here for the TBS not the interception game.  Having said that
date:
I can't stress the value in having a large air force and doing airstrikes on many of your alien crash sites.  You can't and will not want to raid them all.

I ended up having to tweak the monetary values of several items in the game in order to loosen the difficulty up (on Normal) to something more reasonable to the point where the focus of the game was on the missions with your troops rather than trying to balance a checkbook.

Don't get me wrong
recommended: the game isn't horrible.  However unless you're dying for a new TBS game (and I was) I'd recommend waiting till it's on sale before trying.  If you're a fan of the new XCom and are expecting more of the same look elsewhere."

reviewText:
If you are an autismo dank memelord philosopher-warrior like myself, then this game will give you an insufferably persistent erection of the most dire intensity. This is simply one of the best strategy and tactical games I have played in years.

You are leading a black ops organization that exists to defend the Earth from alien invasion, and it is multinational, receiving funding primarily from the USSR/USA but the rest of the world as well. You start at the beginning of an alien incursion into Earth, and you are charged with building base[s] from which to base interceptors, infantry strike teams and their helo transports, radar, SAM sites, research laboratories, workshops to build dank new memes for your infantry and pilots, medical centers, et cetera!

The strategic side of the game occurs in the geoscape, where you make decisions regarding the administration and disposition/construction of your bases. You monitor world events - alien incursions will occur with the aim of terrorizing populations, and the more South Americans ♥♥♥♥ their pants, the less money they will allocate to fund your operations. You can increase your relations (and funding!) with regions by intercepting and destroying UFOs. By shooting down a UFO over land, you create a crash site, which you need to launch a raid on aliens and recover alien technology and resources. This is critical. The strategic side of this game is very engrossing.

On the tactical and RPG side of the game, you scout, hire, and deploy infantry in a variety of roles, with a variety of equipment, on a variety of missions including raids/assaults and base defense. Your troops come from all over, with pertinent information (aside from their ability statistics) being age, nationality, prior unit, and combat experience. I've had an American paratrooper with combat experience in Vietnam, Soviet Spetsnaz GRU member with experience in Ethiopia, Soviet Spetsnaz with Afghan experience, Norwegian FSK, British Paras and Royal Marines, Italian Bersaglieri, et cetera... autismo dreamscapes! DANK #swagover9000

Combat itself is very well thought-out and challenging. You never know what sort of enemy you will be facing, and caution is a good idea while moving out from your infil point. Assaulting a crash site is always messy, and a genuine challenge.

One point of contention - I'm a Marine, and as such it pisses me the ♥♥♥♥ off to see virtually 50% of troops in the game be females. There has never been a female SEAL and never will be - why the ♥♥♥♥ am I see female Alfa, SEAL, Royal Marines, etc.? Stupid SJW ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, very offensive.

reviewText:
Certainly an interesting experience, and certainly not the worst in terms of value-for-money, but unless you are interested in the old XCOM I found that the mechanics can get quite grating towards the end of my playthrough:

There is a lot of UFOs, and thus crashsites to clear, and this doesn't exectly hide the fact that there is a VERY limited number of maps - about 8, so you can expect to have to clear EACH map about 30 times if you were to manually do every mission.

A related issue is that the game doesn't handle multiple levels very well - e.g. so move a soldier from the first floor to the ground floor you need to press tab once, select the soldier, then press tab about four times to cycle back to the ground floor before issuing a move order. Enemies on higher elevation can hide in spots not visible from the ground, occasionally annoyingly prolonging combat.

And sadly, there is not a huge amount of gear to choose from - e.g. you end up with two choices for armour (heavy armour limiting the user to machine guns, and light armour with a jetpack that makes the character FLY nearly every time you give him a move order and also makes checking corners redundant due to 360 degree vision), which ultimately contributed to me rushing towards the end; having everyone in the annoying jetpack armour was just too damn annoying.

If this review had been for the first half of the game I'd have recommended it, but with the 2nd half I don't think I can recommend the game overall UNLESS you are already into what I assume old school XCOM was like; I, at least, won't be playing it without looking very hard at mods to fix the above.

I have no idea why the developers chose 1979 as the time to set the alien invasion, but the fact that they did and actually made some of the aliens look like 1970's aliens (Caesans) makes the whole thing feel kind of cheesy.  I mean, the original X-COM felt more stylistically appealing than this groovy rendition.  So a blah rating from me.

reviewText:
TLDR: Game is too repetitive, slow and has very bad UX, further exacerbating the slowness.

I've completed Xenonauts on veteran today. And Xenonauts is NOT a good game. The user experience is horrible. ***Mild spoilers ahead***

2 main points to illustrate, strategically and tactically:

1)Strategically, this game pointlessly drags on for many, many hours more than necessary because the UFOs that contain necessary tech just simply DO NOT arrive until VERY LONG time into the game. Case in point: First Battleship for me? UFO-199... You have to go through like 100+ tactical mission drudgery just to advance the game... And you sort of HAVE TO play the tactical part because Airstrike doesn't give enough resources. Then, even when you have some Marauders (but not a lot yet), you still have to play each air combat out, and it's exactly the same, you patiently click and wait, click and wait, until you are tailing UFO for comfortable Cannon takedown to avoid taking damage... And you will have to play 10s of air battles, which gameplay you solved 10+ hours ago, just to farm enough money to afford 10+ Marauders so you can autoresolve.

2)Tactically the game is also really bad. The maps are too ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ large and Industrial map is the biggest nightmare of them all - you will have to advance at a REALLY SLOW pace, or else you will get killed. That is not difficulty, that is just boring. And all 90% of deaths I had was because I got so bored of advancing a few tiles a turn I just rush in with all TUs spent.

Late game things get even more messed up - Once you got Sentinel Armor, you cannot simply order a soldier to move to a point, and then do it with the next one - The camera will FORCEFULLY center on a soldier who's flying MULTIPLE times and will break your control of someone in a Predator armor because your previous soldier is flying at a DIFFERENT ALTITUDE LEVEL... And thus you are forced to watch EACH of 12 soldiers SLOWLY move one by one to the target point. The same bull$hit happens on UFOs with multiple levels.

I think the developers didn't play this game themselves. I do not know how they could subject anyone to this mindless boring repetitive piece of krap.

What's the difference between old school UFOD and this?
1)Turns resolve momentarily. In Xenonauts they take 5-15 seconds on I5-3570K. The simple AI logic doesn't warrant this amount of computation.
2)The animation was instantaneous. Courtesy of DOSBox speedup, but still. In Xenonauts. you have to watch people fly for like 7-10 seconds each in Sentinel armor for NO good reason.
3)The UFOD does not swarm you with pointless spam of UFOs. Maybe it should have, but you should NOT have to capture EACH of them in order to barely have enough money for anything. I've had 10 colonels by mission 30-35. Then what? Nothing - you still play 100 more combats with them, with barely any progress at all once TUs and Accuracy are maxed out.
4)Game pace in UFOD is much better, you do not have to trudge through 50+ UFOs to advance to next tech level.
5)With late game tech you can own small UFOs no problem. Not true in Xenonauts. Due to best armor in the game being unable to stop the very wild 50-150% damage fluctuation, you still have to be wary of a lucky burst from a simple Caesan.
6)UFOD had Psi. Xenonauts? Only aliens do.

Would I play this game again? Hell no. Too much time wasted NOT playing or making decisions, but watching unit animation, and waiting turns.

reviewText: Pushed forward as a spiritual successor to the classic 1994 X-Com, it tries to mimic the classic game while pulling in the mechanics of Jagged Alliance, but somehow loses the fun aspects from either game.  The ground combat lacks punch or amusement, the world map is bizarre (Mercator projection with no adjustment for curvature) in the geoscape, research and manufacturing feels limp and while the air combat actually makes sense now (compared to the old X-com) and is quite tactical, it becomes a chore quickly.\n\nOverall it just seems to be missing the aspects that make it fun.

reviewText:
So far, I'm rather disappointed.  While I was hoping for XCOM UFO Defense expanded and prefected, what I got was a rather dumbed-down version with some Facebook-esque artwork.  What's worse is that upon researching the game, I learned that there were several great features cut during early access and dumbed down, with developers being extremely hostile towards anyone who thought otherwise.

Let's start off with the good: First of all, it's more XCOM.  No, not Firaxis' streamlined and modfiied reboot, XCOM: Enemy Unknown, but the classic XCOM: UFO Defense and Terror from the Deep.  It's got a wider scope than the reboot, more micromanagement, and places equal emphasis on your planning as it did combat, unlike the more combat-focused reboot.  Regardless of your opinion on Firaxis' attempt to reboot the franchise (which I absolutely loved), this game is a completely different experience.Air Combat has been revamped, and feels like a game mechanic rather than a short prayer to the AI Director that has screwed you over so many times in your Warframe loot tables and L4D2 sessions.  It's one of the few changes I genuinely enjoyed, a fully realized version of the air combat in which you operate your ships in real-time and attempt to outmaneuver the alien contact.Variety of weapons.  XCOM classic had launchers, Assault Rifles, and pistols, Xenonauts added Snipers, LMGs, and Shotguns.New feature: Airstrikes.  They cost $15,000 and you miss out on loot, but if you simply don't have the resources to respond, you may have to take the loss to control damage.  It's a great addition, and one of the ways this game's best points is interception.
Now, let's go ahead and address the neutrals.
External launcher.  I count this as a negative, but it's simply something I really can't take too harshly.Civilians are almost ALWAYS present.  I have mixed opinions on this, as while it gives the missions a bit more tension, it turns civilians into a regular instance of combat.  In XCOM, The announcement of a terror mission genuinely scared you, as it put your entire monthly rating on the line.  It threw off your usual strategies, and it forced you to take risks you would have never done before... now, civilians are just a oh well
date: let's go through plan D."You're no longer protecting a planet

reviewText:
If this game is on sale, and you like tactical/strategy games, Xenonauts is a fairly good experience.

In a decently imagined world lifted directly from the XCOM series, you can watch your apparently untrained trained soldiers fumble with their weapons, panic, fail to aim completely and die horribly at the hands of a wide variety of alien scum.

If playing the game on any difficulty is too frustrating and arbitrary, you can just re-balance the game with a text editor of your choice.

4/9, Would bang.

reviewText:
After enjoying XCOM Enemy Unknown (XEU) and Within, I decided to give it  a  try.  I started the game and had no clue what to do. Had to go back and read stuff. OK, lot of common elements to XEU but with a very clunky interface. Fine. So this game has an strategic level more complex than XEU. Many of the mechanics are similar to  XEU like constructing the base by expanding locations and selecting what to build. Combat is also similar turn based and using cover, changing weapons, etc. But I just have no fun with this game. Here is what I dislike.

The combat in XEU is implemented much better. For example,  in XEU line of sight works is carefully implemented. In Xeno it seems they use a random factor to simulate it and it doesn't work well. For me combat was the most fun part of XEU and it is the worst part of Xeno. Xeno relies low hit rate to simulate difficulty. Chance is not a replacement for implementing strong combat elements like line of sight. XEU adds chance on top of strong combat elements, that is fun. Xeno adds chance as a replacement to implement strong game elements, that is not fun.


I will stop purchasing games with low production values like Xeno. This seems implemented for the 1980's before dedicated graphic cards were implemented.

reviewText:
Direct ripoff of the UFO series, which would offer a lot of quality time is implemented in a nice and clear manner. However, not only bugs like an occasional bullet through wall mar this incarnation of UFO, but the gameplay is basically broken. You'll end up with a boring series of save / make a move / see if it turns out well in the enemy turn / load. Save / Load. Save / Load.... which makes a boring play.

The reason to save so often is that you can ill afford losing soldiers, whose abilities will get better with time. Also if you're new to the game you have no way of knowing which research does what exactly and base management is a silly drag with limitted space.

What finally killed the game for me was the Predator armour. Going into action with two heavy armour suits had shown that they're a bit better than Wolf, but they'll easily get penetrated by the aliens.

Anoter note is that aliens are not much worse than your squad, so statistically your chances of making it through 100 fights with your people intact are zero unless you save and load and load and load ...

I've had more fun at work than playing this game.

reviewText: Oh alright. I've finally found myself reviewing this game. There's a lot of thoughts slewing around in my head about this game. And I've finally come to a conclusion. In it's core concept it's a literal sucessor to UFO defense. For, at the time of this post, 5 times the price of the original  X-COM UFO Defense on steam. The guns are pretty unbalanced, generic and boring, the game feels odd, it doesn't feel like an advancement from the original. There are currently a lot of problems with this game. And I could go on and on about them. Most of them have to do with the gameplay. (However I should note the modder community is currently doing a lot for the game, making a lot of new weapons and whatnot to be put into the game.) There's a difference between 'Difficult but fair' and 'Difficult and stressful'. The developers have yet to figure out how to do the first one. Until the game is patched up a lot and a lot of the game hopefully fixed, I don't recommend this game to anyone. It's not so much that it's bad, but you almost might as well get the original game unless you're willing to spend $20 more for updated graphics and unbalanced gameplay.

reviewText:
I have been in the beta for this for an age and have tried really hard to like the game.

However it fights back just too hard.  Window mode does not work, the game still crashes regularly and performs poorly despite a very decent spec PC.  Even though the game is now released, It still feels very beta and riddled with bugs and design faults.

It's a shame, the concept has been done before and done very well.  A carbon copy of previous Xcom games with better graphics would be so well received, but even with this game being released in 2014 the graphics are very poor.

I'll keep coming back every couple of months but Xenonauts needs significant work to become a finished product.
voteText: 15 of 40 people (38%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I REALLY wanted to like this game and was excited that the team put together a turn based tactical game. Something that has been sorely missing for a while, but this game is just tedious.  Aliens shoot you from way beyond your vision and through corners/walls that show as 100% obstruction.  Enemies literally can be standing behind you without your knowledge as the Line of Site is absolutely wonky.

My 'elite' team sent out to save the world usually misses the braod side of any barn, while aliens with horrible vision seem like well trained snipers shooting around corners and despite 2-3 points of cover.  The best hit chances for my guys usually tap out at 30%. I suppose I should have simply bought a baseball game so those averages would be quality.

Despite my best intentions, I just cannot give this game a positive review.  There are hints of a great game here and there but the tedious pieces need to be addressed.

reviewText:
Don't waste your money. I bought this on another site and played it and got this as part of a humble bundle, I didn't want to gift it because I don't dislike anyone that much. So I decided to redeem the key to write a review.

I'm sure the developers had good intentions. But this game is hot garbage. There's no reason to make a game purposely using horrible design, simply to make the barrier of entry too difficult, for old times sake.

We use to read manuals and draw maps on graph paper and all that.

We've evolved game design to involve a tutorial which welcomes a player. Even Civ, which has more complex ideas I think, has a tutorial complemented with a full in game manual which is easy to access and use.

Hopefully we don't get a Xenonauts 2.

reviewText: This is a significant step up from the original UFO Defense in many ways, but still not enough to be worth playing today. reviewText:
This game is XCOM. It ***is*** XCOM. If you own any of the XCOM games, save your money and play them instead.

Don't get me wrong: there's nothing wrong with it. It's just that it's so much like XCOM that I'm surprised it's allowed to exist. There's nothing new about it except for a graphics update, and if you've played any of the latest console versions of XCOM, even that's not there. So, why am I surprised it's allowed to exist? It's just a photocopy of the XCOM. To me, this game borders on trademark/copyright infringment. It's like me opening a McDonald's restaurant and making just one change: calling the restaurant McDanold's.

I've read other reviews where people have written, This is XCOM as is was meant to be
date: or This is XCOM perfected." Really? Well

reviewText:
If your a patient person then this is the game for you.
Between your turns while waiting for the PC to take its turn you'll have time to learn another language and brew a coffee the old fashioned way, so get up,
stretch your legs, put the kettle on and Google Mandarin because it's going to be a night of intense gaming because this is the waiting sim you've been waiting for and it
will have you hooked and on the edge of your seat.
Laugh along as the game takes longer to take it's turn than Nanna takes to get to the point, and laugh as your PC seems like it's about to blue screen making a family game of Monopoly feel like a game of Flappy Bird.
I hope you enjoy this game as much as I did.

reviewText:
Do not buy this game unless your the nostalgic type. It is very much like old school turn based strategy games, but also lacks modern game mechanics and improvements of newer turn based strategy games. The GUI is awful. It is poorly laid out. It isn't even remotely intuitive. Theres no cover mechanic. In fact it seems like shooting from cover makes your shots inaccurate. Sometimes your shot will hit the waist high wall in front of you.

The complex gameplay is good. The game does have a lot of depth to it, but it is just poorly made. Its an indie title so I'll allow for the poor graphics, but it is not worth $25.

1 / 10 would not recommend. DO NOT BUY.

reviewText: If you did not play classic X-Com, stay away! This game is rife with dated choices and overly complex mechanics. Lots of awesome ideas ruined by a strict adherence to emulation of a decades old game. Combat is a snooze fest and air combat is complex for the sake of complexity. However, the fluff of the world is fantastic and I really enjoyed unlocking new technologies  just to read the descriptions. I would have loved to spend more time with the game, but the very long and tedious battles just wore me out.

reviewText:
This game has two levels: the strategic geoscape, and the tactical maps.
The strategic aspect of this game is spot on.  Building facilities and managing your budget are key aspects to this game.  And the most enjoyable.

That being said, the tactical part of this game sucks.  It is ENTIRELY based on a poorly designed random number generator (RNG.)  The RNG determines if shots will hit or not.  Your shots frequently miss (and your soilders are ex- SPECOPs by the way,)  while shots from the aliens will pass through several solid objects, including shields and other soilders (without injuring them) and fatally strike a soilder you were retreating.  Shots will frequently miss even at point blank ranges with all weapons, especially with shotguns and sniper rifles (I mean, really, shove the gun down the xeno's throat and pull the f---ing trigger.)  Your troops seem to have failed basic training (read: boot camp.)  They will FREQUENTLY panic without even being shot at.  They will throw down their weapons and run (I once had a soilder run INTO a UFO.  (What the f--- made you think of that idea dumba$$?)  You can not sling a soilder's weapon, throw a grenade, and unsling the weapon (so its back in your soilder's hands) during the same turn.  Needless to say, this make a panic smoke grenade impossible.  It seems that some doors are incapable of being closed (really, you're in the military and you can't close certain doors?)  It seems your soilders are incapable of melee combat without a certain weapon (a stun batton.)  (So, let me get this straight, you DON't know how to slam the butt of your rifle into a xeno's face?)  I've also had issues with soilders throwing grenades at thier feet.  (I'm not even going to say anything about that.)  Finnaly, the alien's psionic abilities are completly imbalanced.  Theroretically, they are capable of mind controling a soilder they can't even see while he is still on the dropship (and possibly dropping a C4 charge with zero turns on the timer.)  Not good at all when a core mechanic of the game is permadeath.

(My English teacher would be saying to start a new paragraph here, so...)
Then there are bugs.  Aliens seem to be capable of seeing through walls (then running up to your assult trooper holding a shot gun and blow his (your soilder's) brains out.  Meanwhile, your three other soilders covering that door don't do a damn thing.  I've had issues with blank screens and freezing as well (and this is a very resource unintensive game runing on a gaming PC.)  I've had soilders get shot, survive, and then drop dead as soon as my turn begins.  Finnaly, in the year 2014, this game uses a launcher.  A launcher that will not launch itself with certain background programs running (i.e. firewall and anti-virus.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Interesting concept. On the plus side this game does offer gameplay reminiscent of the original XCom series. The abilty to research alien technology and then reverse engineer to enhance your team of elite soliders as they battle aliens in a variety of tuen based senarios is still there. Also there is the need to manage the logistics surrounding managing your resources including contsructing new equipment and costs associated with expanding  your bases facilitites.

What is different is the pace of gameplay. Even on easy setting this game is very difficult, so much so that you find yourself saving and reloading again and again. The result is slowed gameplay that often feels like a real slog whereas the original titles were challenging but well paced.

Other annoyances include the constant bugs that plague each release. All of my games work seamlessly with the expcetion of this title which crashes again and again. I accept this is a beta but this game is well into its software development life cycle so I'm dismayed to see so many problems still cropping up this late in the piece (the designers state they want to release this game in its completed form early this year).

With the exception of die hard fanboys I can not see this title have much appeal to mainstream gamers like myself. Good effort but still not enough to dethrone the original Xcom titles.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Still too buggy.   Lost my entire roster of soldiers when I reloaded my save from the previous night.

It is a fairly faithful re-creation of X-COM, except for the cold-war skin they've wrapped it in, but I'm reluctantly forced to admit that Time Units are a fairly bland and overly complicated mechanic that ultimately slows down the game flow.  Games have been dumbed down quite a bit since 1994, but in some ways they have evolved as well.  What Xenonauts tries to do, it does well, but better ways to do it have been thought up since then.

XCOM EU used the D&D4e rules to great effect on ground missions, and it was much less headache inducing.

reviewText: This game has the same feel as the original X-Com, much more so than the Firaxis remake. While the remake has a small team, they tend to feel more like some sort of action movie super team. In Xenonauts, your team dies. And dies. And dies some more. When you reveal the map, you only increase the tension for those places still hidden, the awareness growing that as you eliminate hiding places you are only closing the range and make it easier for the unknown enemies to perforate your squad with vastly superior firepower. The fire superiority enjoyed by your foes makes no difference to the mission generator, often outnumbering your soldiers as well. You deliberately harden your heart to avoid becoming too attached to that one officer who can move a quarter way across the map and still have time units and accuracy to put a shot through an alien's eye because you know it's just a matter of time until...BANG! And your favorite is a crumpled corpse on the ground, not even identified by name.\n\nThen you finish the mission (if it's not a total wipe), go back to base, and hire some more, ready to do it again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Xenonauts is a wonderful clone of the original XCOM - UFO DEFENSE and is in many ways a better experience. Xenonauts is more intuitive and pretty than its predecesor as well as creating the same feeling that you are juggling 9001 balls at once, and are constantly a few poor choices away from total collapse. All in all, the game is a great experience.

Although I have not completed the game, just scratched the surface really (I've played three months in-game), I can say for certain that all of the difficulty of the original game is present. Every desicion is vital and it is imperative to really consider the best course of action at all times. If you don't, well, let's say there have been more than a few missions which resulted in complete annihilation of my squad, a terrible loss.

The game is also much more faithful to the original than XCOM - ENEMY UNKNOWN, bringing back TU's, much larger squads, and a more complicated geoscape portion of the game. In many respects, though, it improves on the original. The OP Blaster bomb has been removed, the graphics look polished and attractive, and useful/relevant data is more easily accessed.

However, I do not mean to say that the game is without faults. For new players to the series, there is hardly and tutorial to introduce them to the many facets of being an international super-secret alien defense force commander. This means the learning curve can be quite steep. Furthermore, the game has some frustrating line of sight issues. Sometimes, I will attempt to move my soldier to firing position, only to discover that the bush I was trying to shoot through might as well be a solid wall. Although over time I have been able to more successfully ascertain what I can and can't do, it has provided a great deal of frustration.

All in all, the game is excellent, and in my oppinion more pleasurable to play than the original. (Although the punishing nature of the original adds a bit to the feel. Ironically by making it better it's worse?) Anyway, if you are a fan of strategy games or the original series then I would highly recommend you purchase this game immediately and begin fighting off the extraterrestrial invasion!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Revist/remake of the old school Microprose UFO: Enemy Unknown game. Its very similar to the original with a lot of the content removed(multi-format release) from the latest XCOM game returning .
This game has improved strategy in the global setting over Xcom, with you needing to way up more options like; do I build another base to incease radar & aircraft range or add labs & scientists to get better equipment. Time is not on your side, funding dissapears very quickly on hard settings, especially due to unmonitored alien activity.
The visuals do a decent job as does the AI (on normal & above). The maps are reasonably varied, yet do repeat slightly more than i'd like. They're about the right size & unlike the original I havent found myself hunting the map for the last camping in a loft alien for 30 mins. Theres also a nice addition in the form of being able to airstrike downed UFO's rather than sending a team in.

Overall I've throughly enjoyed this so far and am happy to recommend it, if you havent played the original this is well worth your money. Do bare in mind though that the game is very unforgiving, especailly on the more challenging modes.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Most games find it difficult to provide a challenge, and make it feel fair, most end up having situations in which your character or characters are killed, and you feel cheated at tge way it happened, it normally feels like a cheap shot.
Not in Xenonauts though.
If a soldier is killed, you don´t feel like the game pulled a ♥♥♥♥ move, no, you know it was your fault, that you ♥♥♥♥ed up, and that you ♥♥♥♥ed up hard.
Even then, losing soldiers is part of the game, the game clearly tells us that for all your preparations and tactics, you are still going to lose men and women to a much superior foe, and even if you start closing the gap, that it will keep happening, and happening, and there´s not much that you can do about it.
But, that´s the alure of Xenonauts, a game that manages to strike a balance between challenge and fun.
So, in short, this is a well recommended game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Xenonauts is Xcom's less flashy, more in-depth brother: where Xcom is streamlined and sexy, Xenonauts is more tactical and strategic.

In other words, where Xcom is more about how a team of super heroes saves the world by working their way up to god-like power and ability, Xenonauts is more like a real special forces sim: sooner or later, something is going to get someone (or half the team) whacked, and your going need to prepare if you don't want to lose the game. In other words, the loss hurts, but it is far more manageble than Xcom.

With that in mind, I still recommend this game as a somewhat successful x-com copy. reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nWhat can I say about Xenonauts? Well, if you are an oldie such as I. Then you will come to appreciate old classics, like Ufo Alien defence (The old X-com), Jagged Alliance 2 and Panzer General. With the exception of Panzer General, the other two are very similar games. With their core underlying mechanics being grounded in managing a team of soldiers in accomplishing some sort off objective. How is that relevant? Well, for starters. You need to understand what this game is trying to accomplish. And that is replicating an old classic and making it more pleasing to the eye. The 'pleasing to the eye' has already been accomplished by the remake Firaxis has made. So again the question is: What does this game bring? Well it successfully manages to incorporate the core aspects that made the original Xcom so great into a neat little package that is pleasing to the eye and keeps the features rich. 'Feature Rich', that is the key here. Everyone including me loves the new remake of X-com very much, but again, if you are like me. Then you will yearn for the classics. reviewText:
If you loved the original X-Com, you will like this game a lot.

This game can be rather unforgiving if you're not well versed in the old games. The X-Com reboot is but a pale shadow of what this game is. (That's not to say X-Com wasn't fun. It totally was).

Xenonauts will test your patience in the battlefield as well as your tactical senses. If you're impatient and charge in, you'll be replacing soldiers more often than not. If you decide to make a beeline to the UFO, you could get blindsided by aliens you didn't see.

Outside of the actual battlefield and into the Global Map, there are a fair few choices as well. Research is all important so that you begin to level the playing field between you an the aliens. You will also need to decide whether or not to expand quickly or build up your current base and its forces. There are bonuses but also negative points to this. A new base means more coverage, happier nations, more UFOs to tag, etc, but then you have to juggle this with the costs involved with running a new base.

Because of the depth this game offers, this game is a welcome sight to strategy veterans.

reviewText:
First and foremost, this is a brilliant game. The best way I can describe it is take XCOM: Enemy Unknown of 2012 and for every graphical superiority that game has that you take away, improve and refine an aspect of gameplay.
This is UFO/XCOM of 1994 as a similar IP, the aliens are named and look somewhat different, but you're looking at a lovingly crafted tribute that far surpasses it's inspiration. If you didn't play XCOM 2012 because it was different and therefore dirty compared to your rose-tinted nostalgia goggled view of UFO/XCOM then this will certainly float your nostalgic boat.

Gameplay wise, believe me that the moment you research stun batons you want 3 dudes with high TU packing a baton and a riot shield. Storming a downed UFO is a cakewalk when you just stroll in and punch everybody in the face :D

I only have two possible critiques and they are that while the sprites are quite detailed, you really can't tell one soldier from another so it's hard to build the kind of bond you had with your troops in XCOM 2012 and secondly the fixed isometric veiw can sometimes cause you to leave a soldier in your dropship because you forgot him/her as you can only see the top of their helmet, that's happened a couple of times but isn't even a serious problem as you might guess.
If those are the only two negatives my fussy butt can think of after around maybe 20 hours playtime it really boils down to one question:
Are you a graphics ♥♥♥♥♥?
If not, you really should buy this game!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Review based on V1.01

Most of what is good in this game has to do with the fact that for the most part its gameplay is copied directly from the original (1994) XCOM. XCOM is easily one of the best designed games ever, so a faithful remake can't be too bad by definition, and this one is not bad at all.

Where Xenonauts tries to diverge from XCOM it does that with mixed results. For example, the alien races are quite a bit more diverse. One of the starting races is tough, has innate regeneration, but poor eyesight and is best dealt with from a distance. The starting weapons are great - the classic pistol, shotgun, assault rifle, sniper rifle and machine gun differ not only in stats (as in the original), but in their tactical values. Shotguns are deadly close-up, machines guns dish out tons of damage and can easily punch through obstacles, sniper rifles are amazingly accurate from a distance.

Advancing the weapon tech is, unfortunately, quite boring. It is the same set of classic weapon archetypes all over again, only gradually more powerful. This is exactly the same as in the original game, but after seeing the initial diversity of ballistic weapons this was very disappointing. I had the same issue with the Firaxis XCOM - a laser shotgun" just has to be one of the silliest sci-fi weapon concepts. The more interesting parts of the original tech tree
hoursPlayed: the psi technology and the blaster launcher are no longer in the game.\n\nThe UFO activity seems to be much more involved
voteText: later in the game the aliens will start defending their missions with aggressive fighter wings that will bring down your dropship or fighters returning from a mission if you are not careful. The aerial terror missions are also a nice touch.\n\nOn the other hand
helpfulPercent: the interception mini-game is highly repetitive
votesHelpful: and very slow-paced - I have been using autoresolve most of the time because it gets very tedious after just a few interceptions
votesTotal: and the game will usually swarm you with UFOs because of how the economy works.\n\nI really didn't like the change where the engineers can no longer build items for profit - that option made a lot of sense in the original game (though was  probably too good to the point of Xenonauts' authors calling the feature an "exploit"). In Xenonauts your engineers are just wasted resources unless you need something built immediately
votesFunny: which you don't always do
commentsCount: so they have to be fired / re-hired as needed to save money.\n\nThe funding provided by the nations is just about enough to run 2 bases and fund two workshops. The only source of income for further expansion are the UFO raids
column16: which are (relatively) less profitable than in the original
column17: and therefore have to be more frequent. There is even an option to earn about 33% of the downed UFO's worth by bombing the crash site in order to avoid losing money when the ground squad is not available. Still
column18: the income is quite low. For instance
column19: the cost of a new base is $1M. Medium-sized UFOs that are prevalent in the mid game are worth about $50-75K if you raid them and $25K if you bomb them
column20: minus the combat losses that can be VERY painful (a basic scout vehicle costs $60K to produce
column21: and they are easy to lose). This means that in order to get a new base you need to raid about 15 UFOs with near perfect performance
column22: and that is not considering the cost of buildings
column23: staff and maintenance.\n\nGround combat is pretty much the same as in the original game
column24: except for the cover system that can sometimes be frustrating because it is not at all obvious how it calculates the lines of fire
column25: and the game won't show you the cover calculations unless you are aiming at something.\n\nThe game's performance is frankly embarrassing at times. The Geoscape scrolling is very laggy
column26: visibility calculations cause obvious frame rate drops on larger maps
column27: and the animations seem not to load until they are played for the first time
column28: so the first time a new animation is shown it is basically dropped frames. This is simply unacceptable for a 2D game that is not particularly more complex than a 20 year old game that ran fine on computers compared to which your today's phone is a freaking alien planetary mainframe.\n\nOverall
column29: the game does not really add that much to the original XCOM experience
column30: however it recreates it quite successfully. I am finding myself returning to play just a couple more missions all the time."

At the time I recommended not purchasing the game due to its significant list of missing features, bugs, and poor gameplay. My review of course got condemed, but I'm a true believer in reviewing a game on how it is *now* and not what it *might* become in the future.

Over a year later, here we are at the official release.

Now that the game is officially finished and released I am re-doing my review to reflect on how the game is in the current state.

Xenonauts takes the conecpt and gameplay that many of us fell in love with long ago with the DOS game X-Com: UFO Defense and brings that into the modern world. It isn't a direct copy however. The aliens are different, their are different weapons, different technologies, different aircraft. It takes the best of the original game, and combines it with some of the best modifications to that game. As icing on the cake, it also incorporates some of the features the XCOM reboot by Firaxis had.

It keeps the isometric 2D view from the original game, but with more modern graphics. Large squad sizes are present (your first aircraft can have 8). Base defense is present. You are allowed, and required, to have multiple bases. Combat remains turn-based, and time units are very much present. That convers just about all of the complaints series fans had with the XCOM Enemy Unknown reboot.

New is a more indepth aircraft interception mini-game (that's optional, you can auto-resolve if you wish). Unlike most games with an auto-resolve feature, this one doesn't screw you over with excessive losses/damage if you use it.

For anyone who was a fan of the original XCOM: UFO Defense game, or new people who don't want to deal with a DOS Box game I reccomend they check out this game and give it a shot. The initial difficulty spike is quite large, but after a few games you can learn what works for you and really start to dig in.

reviewText:
I've been playing and modding Xenonauts for a year, now.  Steam tells me I've played ~200 hours and I could easily double that with the modding and mapping I've done.

Since I'd played it so much, I wanted to see how it compared to the original X-Com: UFO Defense.  So, a few months ago, I loaded it up and started a game.  Half an hour in, half way through a ground mission, I quit.  For possibly the final time, I quit one of my most favourite games of all time; a game I've played on and off since I was 8 years old.

X-Com is dead; long live Xenonauts!

reviewText:
If you loved the original X-Com, you will like this game a lot.

This game can be rather unforgiving if you're not well versed in the old games. The X-Com reboot is but a pale shadow of what this game is. (That's not to say X-Com wasn't fun. It totally was).

Xenonauts will test your patience in the battlefield as well as your tactical senses. If you're impatient and charge in, you'll be replacing soldiers more often than not. If you decide to make a beeline to the UFO, you could get blindsided by aliens you didn't see.

Outside of the actual battlefield and into the Global Map, there are a fair few choices as well. Research is all important so that you begin to level the playing field between you an the aliens. You will also need to decide whether or not to expand quickly or build up your current base and its forces. There are bonuses but also negative points to this. A new base means more coverage, happier nations, more UFOs to tag, etc, but then you have to juggle this with the costs involved with running a new base.

Because of the depth this game offers, this game is a welcome sight to strategy veterans.
