reviewText:
I've been following this title for ages and while I couldn't resist trying out the alpha demo about two years ago, mainly checking the looks and feels, I never really played the pre-release versions. I prefer having a complete experience, so I patiently waited for the magical 1.0.

And now it finally arrived. I am not disappointed.

I completed a playthrough on Normal not using Iron Man Mode in an 18 hour session, interrupted only by a short break to catch some Zs. I was pretty much hooked right from the start. The base building and overall beginning of the game is very XCOM-y. If it wasn't for the 2D geoscape you might as well be thinking you're playing the original. But there are certainly differences.

Aerial Combat:

The mini game for this got made over quite a bit. You can manually move your jets around the battlefield and issue basic orders like 'evasive maneuvers', 'fire missile' and 'retreat'. I found it especially fun to fight bigger UFOs. Get one Jet to distract the enemy and another to get on the bogeys tail, hammering away on his butt. If you don't like this kind of gameplay you can just let the CPU auto-calculate the outcome for you, with the approximate winning chance displayed on the encounter screen.

Annoyances:

- The Corsair is way too strong, making alien air superiority fighters nothing more than a nuissance.
- The amount of UFOs appearing during end game can get quite the hassle. Not because they are dangerous, but because it ends in a neverending clickfest.

Ground Combat:

Awesome. Finally you can freely equip your soldiers again (unlike in Firaxis' XCOM, which had way too few options after my fancy). You can use a squad with different specialists or just stick to a jack-of-all-trades kind of team. I managed to work with the latter, but it was way more difficult and less fun at the same time. However I only played on normal difficulty, so I don't know how viable this is in harder modes. I'd definitely recommend going for specialized troops.

Aliens behave differently. There are smarter ones and dumber ones. Overall the AI is ok, but not breath taking. Yet the suspense IS there. Playing the game in a pitch black room, sweeping the area for hostiles while trying to keep your men and the civilians alive never ceases to be great and thrilling fun.

Movement and aiming hasn't changed much, but the newly included suppression system makes the combat feel way more alive. It counters reaction shots, so you can't just camp in a good position until the sun explodes. However this tactic is very often neglected by the AI. Would like to see them be more aggressive. Yet again, maybe that's the case in harder modes.

Also, you can now just bomb crash sites if you don't need anything in particular from it. This will yield no XP/loot but money. Really saves you from getting dizzy doing the 100th scout UFO ground mission for just some crap loot. Good thinking there.

Annoyances:

- Why no quicksave/-load? The hardcore crowd will play in Iron Man Mode anyway, so why not include this simple feature? If I just didn't see the button, shame on me.
- Sometimes maps repeat, I only ever had it happen twice I think, but it shouldn't happen during the same game at all.
- Alien Bases are too similair. I always found the base commander in the same corner of the base (I did 5 base assaults). Can this be randomized a little more? (Why did I just write 'base' four times in one sentence?)
- Why are there ALWAYS civilians? If a UFO crashes in no man's land, there shouldn't be any. Just a minor thing, but the occasional map without friendly NPCs would do for some randomization as well.

Tech Talk:

Uhh, well it's an indie game with a 2D engine. If you expect some fancy AAA effects and stuff you will be disappointed. But I have to admit the ingame sprites and art work in the game's encyclopedia are very good. The battlegrounds look great and especially the alien assets (and UFOs) look very nice.

Sound effects are nothing too special but meaty enough. The music during ground combat is awesome though and really helps create the creepy mood. Well done!

Conclusion:

That pretty much sums it up. The geoscape gameplay is mostly the same as always. Research, build, expand, intercept. I wouldn't know what to drastically alter there and everything is well made, so it's fine for me.

All in all I am very impressed and would recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed the old XCOM games or is looking to get into this kind of genre.

tl;dr: 9/10 would play again

reviewText:
I bought it even though I never played the original XCOM games, but I still liked it very much.

A good third of the game you spend watching a world map and sending air fighters to fend off alien UFOs. You can autoresolve the air fights and a calculation will tell you whether you won and how much damage your planes took, but it is much more fun to run the 2D eagle view simulation to navigate the fight yourself.

Each time an enemied UFO crashes, it creates a crashsite that can either be airstriked to deal with the alien survivors, or approached with your soldiers in ground battle to recover alien technology to either sell it your advance your own weaponry, whcih becomes an essential part of the mid to late game. The ground batlle for me is the most interesting part of Xenonauts. It is very strategic and thrilling and you really develop feelings for your experienced soldiers and mourn for their unexpected deaths. But still there are sometimes so many Crashsites to deal with (each one can last up to an hour, if you are a careful player) that it can get a bit tedious in the long run.

Although the ground battle is the essential part of the game, the real strategy lies in distributing your very expensive bases, airplanes and soldiers over the globe efficiently without losing your relations to a contintent that provides your funding in return. I personally considered the game very challenging even in Normal difficulty, since everytime you feel you can somehow cope with your enemy, the UFOs and ground units get even stronger and higher in number. Some elements can also be quite frustrating (for example your armour and good cover are worth nothing when a reaper" approaches over vast distances out of the fog of war and one-hits your soldier making him an armored zombie enemy
date: too). The AI is not super-intelligent (especially not the civilians always blocking your way)
recommended: but challenging.\n\nI enjoyed the game very much
hoursPlayed: but it could be considered a bit repetetive in its basic principle (manage upgrades -> UFO atttack -> shoot down planes -> intercept crash sites -> manage upgrades). The writing and the "science" elements in the well-written codex full of some beautiful artworks as well as the soundtrack set you right into that alien mood. Atmosphere

reviewText:
Finally! Xenonauts replaces the original X-Com for me! The remake by fraxis didn't but I like it for separate reasons (like the Bureau).

The game can be a little long the first play through since you dont' know what your doing, and the geo strategy game can be brutal. There are also a few bugs, but most of them are harmless. The end game has one that's crops up every once in a while, that requires you to reload.  The graphics a good for a indie project, but not state of the art.

Despite the downsides, this is the modern X-Com! It adds a lot of new twists,  I love the strategic depth of Xenonauts, managing multiple aircraft in dogfights with UFO's. Truth is,  I didn't immediately realize the tactical depth in this when I first started playing, but after a few hours I realized it had more depth (and control) than I initially relaized.

I also loved the addition of tactical shields to your teams arsenal, makes a new tactical element to your teams, and being able to set up defeault equipment for a role, or create a new role, or a hundred other small improvements over X-Com really show how Xenonauts isnt just a clone, but a player that sets a new bar.

I love the armed civillians,  Billy Bob on his farm with a shotgun killing the aliens for probing his cows. The local cop who saved my beacon in a  tough fight. The military that shows up later in the game armed with the laser rifles I supplied them with, now helping my team out (somewhat).

I loved my predator armor that could walk through walls and obstacles. I really enjoyed setting off several chain explosions with my explosives and firefights that clears large portions of the map!

I'm really impressed with this game! It really is the ultimate X-Com homage. Its going to be tough for me to try other indie efforts after this unless they bring something vastly new to the table.

Others have come close, but Xenonauts gets enough of it right to take the mantle. I hope some aspiring moder converts it to the original X-Com with the included modding tools. I would so play that mod!

There is also a lot more under the hood that could be used. Some modder created a nice wav collection that realty amped up the tactical combat with lots of military chatter, lots of mods already and can't wait to see where this is in a year.

reviewText: If you like X-Com, then you'll love Xenonauts. In my opinion, this game did everything that i wanted the new X-com to do and with some fancy new features stacked ontop. The ground combat is intense and satisfying, there's plenty of gear and technology for you to research and progress through and the game is hard as nails. Everything you could want if your looking for that nostalgic playthrough of the old X-Com games with a bit of a newer coat of paint. The only flaws that stand out to me is the user interface is a bit janky in places, alt-tabbing makes the game act wierd for a few seconds, and the graphical quality of the ground combat isn't the best, and in the later game you really aren't given enough funding, i feel like they should scale it in some way, in my playthrough i was on two bases, and i was doing fairly well for myself, making 2.9 million every month, but the maintinence costs of the bases shrunk that down to a mere 800 thousand a month. And i haven't even completed the game yet. Other then those flaws however, the game perfomes admirably and certainly deliveres that classic X-com experience.

reviewText:
This is a really good game, and in many regards, this is indeed XCOM's true successor.
- The tactical game feels a lot like the original, with the same dilemmas and cold sweats, but with a nice gameplay refresh integrating modern concepts such as cover. It is a real success; the general way you play the game is very faithful to the original game, but it is significantly deeper and more interesting.
- The same can be said for the strategic game. The general feeling is the same as in the original game, but it is much, much more complex and the game has little forgiveness for people who make wrong choices.
- The interception minigame is really nice. There are a few problems that should be solved (some dogfights which have good success chances on autoresolve are actually unwinnable if you try to play them) but it adds something that had not been attempted or done right by any of the previous XCOM-inspired games.
- The general cold war atmosphere is nice and the flavour text (research reports, news ticker, etc.) fleshes out the universe nicely. All the text-based universe description is a real success.
- The music is good, and the sound effects are good too.

Now a few criticisms:
- The graphics. Seriously. The geoscape and base layout screens are OK. The background art (research/engineering screens, etc.) is decent, even though it lacks something. Everything else is horrible. The aliens, the equipment, most of the armours and almost everything in the tactical game is ugly, bland and unremarkable. I would go as far as saying that I prefer the visuals from the 1994 game in their VGA splendor. They are pixelated and often cheesy in a 90s SF way, but they have a character that is completely absent here. Even the recent X-COM: Enemy Unknown, which is much more bland and soulless than Xenonauts in many ways, easily wins this match.
- The UFO missions eventually become repetitive. True, you can airstrike crash sites, but it is often not an economically viable option, and the combination of low resources, quite slow research and high enemy activity leads to phases of the game where you have nothing else to do than wait for your research/engineering projects to eventually complete while playing non-stop difficult missions which look a lot like one another, have each the potential to wipe your team, and do not bring you any reward except some cash and the chance to live another day. This is somehow realistic, but not so funny.
- This is not a true Linux game: the developers juste made special efforts to make the game run correctly with Wine. This is not nothing, and I don't blame the developers, but Wine compliance is not the same at all as a native GNU/Linux version, and I find it misleading and disappoingint to see it listed as a Linux game" on Steam. (And even more so since you can't even install the Linux Wine port through Steam) This is one of the reasons why I so readily bought this game
date: and although it is a fine game
recommended: on that point I feel cheated."
hoursPlayed: August 25, 2014

reviewText:
Xenonauts is basically a modern remake of the original Xcom, and it retains most of its original features.

-Uses TU(time units) which allows for a large diversity of actions to be taken during a turn, instead of the simplified scoot n shoot action system from Xcom:EU
-Destructible Terrain: you can destroy light cover, such as haybales and low barricades, to larger things such as entire walls
-Can have more than one base to operate from on the globe, and it can be placed in any exact location down to a pixel
-Base building: a 6 by 6 grid that can be outfitted with a variety of structures to win the war
-Base assault and defense: You can assault alien strongholds on earth and vice versa
-Medium size combat teams: You get to start off with 8 units, and you can increase that amount to 10 later on.
-No class restricting roles: You can equip any soldier with any item, and designate their roles as you deem fit.
-Soldier Inventory system: though slightly streamlined, (no more leg or shoulder slots, just hands, belt, and backpack.) you   can equip soldiers with as much as they can carry weight/space wise.

For those uninitiated into the wonder of the Xcom universe, the game basically plays as a world defense simulator. The earth gets attacked by aliens, and all of the worlds super powers are left bent over a table with their pants down. You, and your organization, the Xenonauts, are effectively the last defense we have left.

You start out by placing a base on the globe, and then monitor alien activity around you via radar dishes. While things are dark, you can research alien artifacts and technology,  build new military toys, and invest in both your base and its employees. Once a Ufo is spotted, you can choose to launch a fighter or interceptor to its location to try and shoot it down. If you succeed, you'll most likely be given the option to send a mop up crew to kill off any survivors and acquire whatever the ship had aboard it. Alternatively, you can also send in an airstrike in to obliterate the crash site, netting you a small amount of cast from the pieces left.

Once a crew of soldiers arrives at a crashsite or other battlefield, the game plays out in a turn based fashion. You move your soldiers around a battlefield, using various cover, weapons, and equipment to out position and destroy your foe. Whether that be by blowing a hole in the side of a building and running inside to flank an enemy, tossing a flash bang or smoke grenade to disorient and charge the enemy head on, or laying down supressive fire while a sniper gets into position and guns down an enemy. The choice is up to you.

While Xenonauts does however, have its own share of faults, (Playing the same levels over and over in combat missions, predictable enemies inside downed ufos, graphics ocassionally bugging out, etc.) they are few and far between, and the game can be modded to the point where most of these things are not an issue.

If you liked the original Xcom, I can almost assure you that you will love this game, and if you've never played one before, you should give it a shot.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the best remake of XCOM yet. I loved Enemy Unknown but it's got nothing on the original. Xenonauts is as close to an original as you can get.

So far, there are some issues regarding balance. Some battles are far too easy and aliens will flee pretty quickly but it's always being addressed. Play it on the harder difficulty and it's quite fun already and we just saw it enter beta.

The UI and graphics have been upgraded multiple time and are still being worked on. It is already extremely playable.

Xenonauts has the best micromanagement of the original with the suppression and new weapons of EU. It is the best of both worlds and, at 20 bucks, there's no reason not to own this fantastic game.

XCOM for life.

reviewText:
Absolutely loved this one, kick back to the original UFO with a lot of little quality of life improvements and a reasonably interesting storyline. The ending is a bit anti-climatic but on the whole, the game kept me involved to the end.

One thing that really impressed me was (until the very very end) the interception mechanic is much improved over other games, advanced alien craft can prove a real threat to your interceptors and you need to play it carefully if you don't want to start losing hard.

Could have done with a little more exposition, particularly in the ending but overall was a game that held me solidly in its grasp from start to finish.

reviewText: This game has the same feel as the original X-Com, much more so than the Firaxis remake. While the remake has a small team, they tend to feel more like some sort of action movie super team. In Xenonauts, your team dies. And dies. And dies some more. When you reveal the map, you only increase the tension for those places still hidden, the awareness growing that as you eliminate hiding places you are only closing the range and make it easier for the unknown enemies to perforate your squad with vastly superior firepower. The fire superiority enjoyed by your foes makes no difference to the mission generator, often outnumbering your soldiers as well. You deliberately harden your heart to avoid becoming too attached to that one officer who can move a quarter way across the map and still have time units and accuracy to put a shot through an alien's eye because you know it's just a matter of time until...BANG! And your favorite is a crumpled corpse on the ground, not even identified by name.\n\nThen you finish the mission (if it's not a total wipe), go back to base, and hire some more, ready to do it again.

reviewText: This is not a recreation of the original xcom. This is an improvement. Everything is a complete improvement. Instead of sending out lone interceptors to fight off lone ufos you are able to send multiple fighters after a ufo and its escorts. It also gives concrete reasons for the invasion starting off so slowly. The ufo's are not suitable for atmospheric flight and must be modified and the smaller the ufo the faster and easier the modification. It also expanded on the variety of weapons you can equip your soldiers and the utility of other weapons. For example stun gas rockets and the addition of suppressive fire giving lmgs a more significant purpose than being extra powerful rifles.

reviewText:
This is the kind of tactical game I love: it's turn based, it has a strategic section that makes each game different, and has the right difficulty (i.e. it's very hard, but not to the point it becomes frustrating).

It's not for everyone, but if you like hard-but-fair tactical games with a moderate level of complexity, then look no further, because you won't find anything better.

It's the perfect middle ground between the high complex Jagged Alliance 2 1.13 (still the best of the genre) and the more casual experience offered by EA's X-COM

reviewText: I've played thousands of hours of old X-COM (UFO Defense, Terror From The Deep, Apocalypse), and over 500 hours of Enemy Unknown/Within.  I'm enjoying Xenonauts tremendously.  Details follow, but if you're a fan of the old-school X-COM games, I'm already telling you that you should check this game out.\n\nXenonauts describes itself as a spiritual successor" to X-COM.  It's important to note that they were very probably not talking about Enemy Unknown/Within; the differences in polish will disappoint you if you're expecting that level of visual quality.  However
date: as a successor to -old- X-COM (UFO Defense
hoursPlayed: Apocalypse) it succeeds pretty brilliantly.\n\nThe look and feel of the Geoscape is very UFOD/TFTD (only much prettier)
voteText: while the tactical aesthetics are much more like Apocalypse turn-based mode.  Bases have radar ranges determined by the number and quality of detection facilities present
helpfulPercent:
but the range limits are far more visible than in previous games.  This makes it far easier to understand the coverage consequences of base placement.

Ship Combat:
X-COM ship fights (even in EU/EW) are like sumo wrestling.  The ships' locations on the field are completely abstracted away
votesHelpful: and there are hit percentages simulating mobility
votesTotal: so you see two craft holding relatively still and slugging at each other.  Misses look more like bad aiming than evasive action.\nIn Xenonauts
votesFunny: the ship combat display is a 2D grid wherein momentum and turning radius count.  Weapons have ranges and firing arcs
commentsCount: ammo and fuel count
column16: afterburners are a thing (but see: fuel counts) and missiles have their own maneuverability values.  Defensive maneuvers exist for evasive actions
column17: and a dogfight isn't always 1:1 -- in fact
column18: encounters can get up to 3 vs. 3 in some cases; as UFO's begin to appear with escorts
column19: and fighter squadrons roam in packs daring your interceptors to come out and play
column20: you respond by sending attack groups instead of lone planes.  There are light and heavy interceptor classes
column21: with maneuverability
column22: range and armament consequences.\nYou can't form an attack group out of craft from more than one base
column23: unfortunately.  I'd have loved to see a rendezvous point system wherein disparate fleets could join up
column24: but ship combat is a fun
column25:
complex mini-game in and of itself and a strategy guide could be (and probably has been) written just for that facet of gameplay.
NOTE:  There are -way- more UFO's in the early part of the game than in any iteration of X-COM.  This becomes important during...

Ship Combat Aftermath:
You can send troops to fight at a crash site
column26: but that's not always an option.  You probably don't have enough strike teams to cover every site where you've shot something down
column27: especially early on when a single Condor is still a match for anything the aliens field.  Rather than letting the sites rot and taking a PR penalty with the nation where they crashed
column28: Xenonauts provides the option to call an airstrike and saturate that area
column29: then send a non-combatant cleanup team to salvage what it can.  This results in a static amount of cash based on the class of crashed craft
column31:
but no soldier experience or personnel equipment captures.

Soldier Management:
Enemy Unknown/Within introduced the concept of soldier classes; a Rookie
column33: was assigned one of four classes.  That class distinction determined what stats increased when the soldier was promoted
column34: what weapons the soldier was allowed to carry
column35: and what special abilities became available to that soldier as rank increased.  It's a novel concept
column36: but there are downsides.  Class assignment is for life
column38: and there's little room for creative misuse of inventory -- you can't load down an Assault trooper with grenades
column39: for instance.  Nonlethal weapons were considered Items rather than weapons in EU/EW
column41: which meant that you had to choose between that and grenades
column43: or whatever else.  It added importance to the range of choices
column44: but only by limiting them.\nXenonauts doesn't have classes
column45: but it does allow you to assign a soldier a role.  The main differences are that any role can technically carry any equipment; there are customizable default equipment templates for each role; you can change a soldier's role in the barracks anytime the soldier is on base; and you can create new roles.  Weapon disparity is a little wider
column46: and there is in fact a "laser shotgun" and other mechanics-only nonsense
column47:
but in general the strategic and tactical choices you can make in Xenonauts is far wider and more granular than in its ancestors.

Tactical Combat:
Oh
column48:
man.  Where to start.  Quick list of things that don't require explanation:
- Stun rockets are a thing.  You get them as soon as you get stun grenades.
- You don't have to wait half the game to get stun grenades.
- Nonlethal melee weapons exist
column49:
and they're weapons -- not some other item class.
- All soldiers carry an infinite number of flares!  (But vehicles don't.)
- Vision arcs are back.  An unarmored human has a 90-degree effective vision arc.  (Heavy armor can reduce this.)
- Cover is not a light switch like in EU/EW
column50:
but rather a stack of calculated obstruction percentages like in older X-COM titles.

Stuff that might require some more description:

- Range matters a lot.  Different weapons are optimized either for long-range armor-piercing fire
column51: or massive trauma at point-blank range.  You have to make sure you send the right soldier for the right tactical situation
column52: all the time; the aliens are as merciless as they ever were in TFTD
column53: and a soldier caught at a disadvantage is very probably toast.\n\n- Area denial is a real thing.  Enough shell-shock (automatic weapons fire
column55: etc.) in the immediate vicinity of a soldier (human or enemy) can cause them to become Suppressed
column56: which takes away their TU's (no reaction fire from that soldier)
column57: and reduces the TU's they get next turn by 50% (no burst fire
column59: just movement adjustments OR one decent shot).  Heavy weapons and vehicle weapons are wonderful for this
column60: but remember ammo is being counted.\n\n- Reaction fire is not solely a function of the reacting soldiers' statistics -- reaction initiative is calculated using (get this) modifiers determined by the weapons and equipment worn by both the active and reactive soldiers
column62: and *TU's the reacting player has left*.  That doesn't just mean that low TU's result in snap shots; it means that high TU's can result in normal or snap shots
column63: and low TU's can lead to the reactive soldier being unable to respond fast enough even though he technically has enough TU's to take a shot.  In addition
column64: assault weapons actually inflict a reaction penalty on anyone calculating reaction fire against them; carrying a shotgun actually makes it much more likely that you'll get the first shot in a point-blank
column65:
room-to-room encounter.

Summary:
The mechanics of Xenonauts are closer to what I've always wanted X-COM to be.  I'm not in love with the tactical display's graphical quality
column67: I'll look for that to improve.  Meanwhile
column68: the game is a beautiful example of this game type
column69: and the creation and maintenance of it is behavior we enthusiasts should reward by burying the developers in enough money that they decide it would be crazy not to make another one."

reviewText:
A great recreation of the original X-Com, with some much appreciated improvements to air combat and simplification of the base management UI and so forth. Some drawbacks as expected - the shiny new tilesets mean you can't breach a UFO like you can all the other buildings - and money can be hard to come by if you are not dominating the air battle (which in turn means you can't produce the planes you need to dominate the air battle....). However I have sunk about 13 hours into this over the weekend and still keep wanting to see one more mission, wipe out one more alien base, save Budapest from the alien terror attacks....


Big recommendation from me!

reviewText: This is not a recreation of the original xcom. This is an improvement. Everything is a complete improvement. Instead of sending out lone interceptors to fight off lone ufos you are able to send multiple fighters after a ufo and its escorts. It also gives concrete reasons for the invasion starting off so slowly. The ufo's are not suitable for atmospheric flight and must be modified and the smaller the ufo the faster and easier the modification. It also expanded on the variety of weapons you can equip your soldiers and the utility of other weapons. For example stun gas rockets and the addition of suppressive fire giving lmgs a more significant purpose than being extra powerful rifles.

reviewText:
XCOM:UFO Defense was released the year I graduated.

Let me clarify that I do not remember the release date because it is the same as my graduation. I remember my graduation date because of the release date.

I first saw this played on a 486DX and then had to hack and upgrade my Tandy 1000EX to be able to run it. I spent $700 in 1993 money to upgrade my RAM to a whopping 768kb. In the end I upgraded machines to play this, Mechwarrior and AOE.

I have also played numerous attempts at sequels, upgrades and fan made remakes. There is NOTHING that come even close to this one. This game is solid, true to it's roots and adds, answers all the things you wanted in the original without ♥♥♥♥♥♥ the things that made it unique. True the last update wiped the scalable destruction but it is a small price to pay. I would spend twice the price for this.

reviewText:
My intro to XCOM was the 2012 game, and I found the original tough to get into because of the UI and the graphics.
Thank goodness for Xenonauts, then. It takes the gritty, granular tactics of UFO Defense, and adds a fresh coat of paint and some new controls. The art and setting are distinctly darker and more realistic than XCOM's cartoony superheroes, and the gameplay is waaay more stressful (enjoy getting shot at from offscreen!)

Highly recommended if you found 2012 XCOM wanting in some ways.

reviewText:
EDIT - (some 20 hours of gameplay later...)

Having tripled my playing time and gotten deeper into the game I have gone from 'pleased' to 'impressed'. The curve at the lower levels is pretty good. You develop your newer guns, finally build and issue some, have fun for a mission or three and then suddenly 'WHAM'! New alien to bring your ego back crashing down.

The air war ramps up quickly to the extent that while you start to feel you can handle everything being thrown at you on the ground, even at EASY you get the impression you just do not have enough intercepters and you never feel completely confident about handling all of the latest swarm.

Having played more I have realised there are a lot more maps then I first assumed. Still not so many that you don't start recognising previous locations from time to time, but definately enough that even after 30 hours you are fighting on areas you haven't experienced before.

Lot of fun, has that 'just play for a bit longer until...' attraction that easily chews up the playing hours but again, if you are not an existing XCOM fan then this game may seem a little old school to you.

(end edit)


(based on v1.07 and 11 hours play on Normal)

Tentative THUMBS UP.

Thing to remember is this game is Xenonauts, and NOT X-COM classic with better graphics. If it was sold as X-COM Classic -HD version or something similar.
What that means is that, surprise! there are differences. Bases are now only one level, the world map is 2D rather then the funky globe. Some of the starting weapons and equipment from Classic either require research or are simply not within the game.
Why?
Because it is a different game and let's be honest, if you think classic X-COM was better, then maybe you should go play that instead (hint, I still do - or would if it wasn't so punishingly hard!! :D )

The game is a bit of a mixed bag. Some of the interfaces are very simple, some (research screen I am looking at you) are downright ugly. Combat seems easier (in that it is possible to complete the early ground missions without having half your squad KIA) and the way reports of 'strange' activities pop up on the global map is interesting. You wont spot UFOs outside your radar coverage, but by looking at the reports of corp circles and abductions you can sometimes have a good idea where to send out a patrol.

Ground maps are no longer randomly generated as they were in classic. On the plus side they now look a lot better, on the down side there is no longer the tenseness of simply exploring the map to work out where the drokk you actually are. Hopefully the game will add new maps with upgrades as once you have explored a map for the first time, remembering the danger spots with weird lines of sight is reasonably easy.

Slightly disappointing is that crashed UFOs are no longer massively damaged when you arrive. Player's of classic will remember turning up on a crash site to find half a wall section and some un-lootable piles of smoking scrap and can breach the craft from the gapping holes your air to air missiles made in the hull. This means that every combat seems to back down to going in through the front door. Oh well.

Some of the micromanangement has been removed. Everything you can't use yourself is automatically sold, so you no longer have store rooms full of stuff you are loath to get rid of.

Also slightly disappointing is the study of the corpses you bring back, which are now done automatically. Gone is the choice between removing your limited science teams from the new lazer rifles you want to develop in order to study the latest hunting trophy.

So, I think this is a good game. Maybe not 'great' and maybe not the sort of thing you would be interested in as an XCOM newbie trying to work out what the fuss is about.

reviewText: Rather than write a long and somewhat scattershot review of the game I'll just say that it's excellent. It's tense and challenging. You'll see soldiers distinguish themselves in combat in terrible situations, and you'll see your vets get killed when things go sideways. You'll have to juggle the competing priorities of the air war and the ground war (hint: focus on the air war) since you can only build so much expensive stuff at once. The only glitches/bugs that really bothered me got patched (timing of bleed damage, Harridan snipers glitching into walls, berserking) and there really wasn't anything else that I feel has gone unresolved. Great game, just know that it's much more complicated than the Firaxis XCOM and will take you a lot longer to finish.

reviewText: Play it with the money and weapons mods because it makes the game fair on your end. The money mod makes sense so I didn't feel any gamer guilt using it. If the world was under alien invasion I am pretty sure every goverment would scrap the idea of money and just use whatever resources Earth had to defend it....not charge those responsible defending for a garage and such. The weapons mods do give you a good advantage in a ways but still those aliens will one shot you, through a wall or just walk right up to your units and MURDER all of them. You will miss just about every shot and each alien takes about three to four rounds but with the weapons mods it gives you a chance. The air combat is great and hope XCOM 2 has something along the lines. Overall it is a great game, has that looming atmosphere of the unknown, great music, the art is good (especially in the alien autopsies and weapon/gear descriptions) besides the character models. They could have done a bit more because your soldiers look extremely plain and paper cut outs. The micromanagement of your bases and world events is pretty awesome too. I suggest this game if you liked XCOM games in anyway. Just use the mods, my first ten hours of this game were without them and I was so hopelessly frustrated.

Is this the closest to the original? YES.
Is this a clone of the original? NO.
Is this better than the original etter than the other titles? YOU JUDGE.
Is the difficulty tuned for monkeys? NO. Your men and women will die. A lot. As they should.
Is it moddable? HELL YEAH. (see below)
Is it the perfect xcom? SHUT UP and don't bother me with silly questions.

I strongly suggest you take a look at the modding community of Xenonauts. The developers made a really good and professional work, but as often happens modders can make you cry with joy and bow in awe.
As of now, 21 of May 2014, you can find their creations at: http://www.goldhawkinteractive.com/forums/forumdisplay.php/10-Xenonauts-Modding

An example of mods I'll personally install for my first playthrough:
- Jsleezy's Real Fighter Portrait Pack: http://www.goldhawkinteractive.com/forums/showthread.php/7357-Jsleezy-s-Real-Fighter-Portrait-Pack
- Skitso's Oppressive UI MOD: http://www.goldhawkinteractive.com/forums/showthread.php/8573-Skitso-s-Oppressive-UI-MOD

These are just a few examples, feel free to check the forum or whatever other place the mods will migrate to yourself.
Have fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Xenonauts is a wonderful clone of the original XCOM - UFO DEFENSE and is in many ways a better experience. Xenonauts is more intuitive and pretty than its predecesor as well as creating the same feeling that you are juggling 9001 balls at once, and are constantly a few poor choices away from total collapse. All in all, the game is a great experience.

Although I have not completed the game, just scratched the surface really (I've played three months in-game), I can say for certain that all of the difficulty of the original game is present. Every desicion is vital and it is imperative to really consider the best course of action at all times. If you don't, well, let's say there have been more than a few missions which resulted in complete annihilation of my squad, a terrible loss.

The game is also much more faithful to the original than XCOM - ENEMY UNKNOWN, bringing back TU's, much larger squads, and a more complicated geoscape portion of the game. In many respects, though, it improves on the original. The OP Blaster bomb has been removed, the graphics look polished and attractive, and useful/relevant data is more easily accessed.

However, I do not mean to say that the game is without faults. For new players to the series, there is hardly and tutorial to introduce them to the many facets of being an international super-secret alien defense force commander. This means the learning curve can be quite steep. Furthermore, the game has some frustrating line of sight issues. Sometimes, I will attempt to move my soldier to firing position, only to discover that the bush I was trying to shoot through might as well be a solid wall. Although over time I have been able to more successfully ascertain what I can and can't do, it has provided a great deal of frustration.

All in all, the game is excellent, and in my oppinion more pleasurable to play than the original. (Although the punishing nature of the original adds a bit to the feel. Ironically by making it better it's worse?) Anyway, if you are a fan of strategy games or the original series then I would highly recommend you purchase this game immediately and begin fighting off the extraterrestrial invasion!

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Pros:
1.) Interesting and detailed cold-war era story/setting showing a believable struggle against a force that humanity barely understands.
2.) Every unit matters, losing soldiers, espically veterans, and vehicles is punishing.
3.) Nicely done tech progression system. You have reason/incentive for wanting to upgrade.
4.) Combat is balenced in such a way that while you have a chance to win. You're still the underdog. You have to rely more on strategy than muscle to win against the aliens.
5.)Varied alien types.
6.) Balenced out base building system. You can't spam several bases/buildings at one time and expect to win. They cost a lot of funding/time to make. So you have to balence expansion with needed supply.

Cons:
1.) Dogfights could use more fleshing out in terms of gameplay. Feels too simple for my taste.
2.) Night missions don't really have much point to me. It just a way for your troops to get slaughtered.

+/-
1.) Game is really forgiving on easier difficulties, often making the game very repetitive. The expierence doesn't truly shine till veteran or insane with iron man is on.

reviewText: Definitely preferable to Firaxis' scripted 3D X-Com reboot"
date: this is much closer to the tense atmospherics and more realistic combat of Julian Gollop/Sid Meier's original X-Com/UFO game. For example
recommended: the line-of-sight mechanic is in this version. The aliens can sneak up on you and vice versa. If an alien is obviously hidden from the view of a soldier
hoursPlayed: then that soldier can't hit it. Why would Firaxis take this out in their version? It's CRITICAL to the feel of the entire game!\n\nPlus everything unnecessary about the original X-Com has been streamlined
voteText: e.g. selling useless items at the end of a mission & buying ammmunition is done automatically. Just lots of little things that weren't really decisions you needed to make
helpfulPercent: more like chores that had to be done every few minutes.\n\nOn the negative side
votesHelpful: the maps get a bit repetitive when you've played for a while
votesTotal: as the original had randomly generated maps to keep things fresh (although Map Packs can be downloaded from the Steam Workshop). I also preferred the droney music of the original as well
votesFunny: it always put me on edge! Otherwise
commentsCount: everything else is definitely better.\n\nOverall
column16: I'd say this is the definitive X-Com experience for fans of the original."
column17: June 6, 2015
column18: true

reviewText:
Having played Xcom 1, xcom 2, xcom apocalypse, xcom interceptor, ufo aftermath, ufo aftershock, ufo afterlight, extraterrestrials (have it in physical copy),xcom the bureau, xcom eu and xcom ew, AND having backed up the early access from the beginning, I must say that I don't know what to think.

On one hand, it's the most accurate recreation of the classical Xcom that I've had the pleasure to play, on the other hand it's the recreation of a twenty (20) years old game.

Surely it brings something new (aerial combat is good -better than I expected-), but the game quickly reminds me why it was so boring to play xcom more than a tactical mission per day: tactical combat is long, tactical options reduce to flank or either snipe while sending rookies to expore and to be slaughtered, and there is only one (1) mission type: kill them all ( a thing that was corrected in xcom eu where you had to evacuate, defend... even stop a train!)

On top of that psiskills are gone, your troops doesn't have the chance to develop was probably the SKILL that really made the game funny.

Conclusion: It's a good game being constantly revised by the developers (superb support), and a game that could be easily groundbreaking with a couple of DLC's correcting the mission variety and psipowers.

100% recommended.

reviewText:
This game feels a lot like XCOM: EU where all they did was remove the best parts of the game but this time they did it even worse. The only thing great about this game is the workshop, because the vanilla game is actually pretty bad.

You see, what made you invested in the tactical part of the game was the alien loot you could grab when you finished the mission. From there you could continue your research, or if you were low on funds, sell it to foreign powers. That was the best part of the game, manufacturing weapons, and then selling them to the governments of the world. It allowed you to continue funding science projects, and recruit staff had the odds swung against you. Sometimes you couldn't get enough missions or things didn't turn out right, and a few nations stop funding your project.

That was removed, and from what it seems, the political aspect as well. You aren't trying to convince the governments of the world that your project can work. You seem to just get a set amount of income each year, I don't know who funds us, or why, we just get money.

Well, I can take a good challenge, tough aliens, and the great level design the game throws at me. But the most disgusting part of the game is aiming. This game takes XCOM's difficulty over the top. While yes, enemies did cheat a bit, but there were few times when they could shoot through walls. But the game's difficulty doesn't come from enemy health, uniqueness, or powers or even intelligence. No. The game's difficulty comes from your soldier's ability to aim, alone. I find it hard to be invested at all in this game, with the ability to sell loot, manufacture items, or attempting to convince the UN that the xcom project works. I find it even harder to invest myself when soldiers shoot like idiots.

You can have 1 alien surrounded by four soldiers, and have ALL of them miss. You can have the odds in your favor, the perfect LOS, and miss. What? You don't think it's that bad? It might not be that bad
date: I'll give it a go" Let me give an example of how BAD a soldier's aim is:\n\nThere was an alien in a ship
recommended: the door destroyed by my rocket launcher. I took my heavy weapons soldier
hoursPlayed: told her to fire at the alien inside of the ship. You know what she does? SHE TURNS AROUND AND SHOOTS THE SOLDIER NEXT TO HER. SHE UNLOADS ON THIS POOR ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ LIKE SHE WAS INJECTED WITH ADAMANTIUM RAGE. KILLING HIM INSTANTLY.\n\nThis game has so much potential
voteText: but it's like the developers thought the only way to make aliens any kind of threat was to nerf your soldier's aim. Down to the point where they couldn't even shoot an alien that's in a square next to them. Stuff like this NEVER happened in xcom
helpfulPercent: in xcom YOU'D HIT! But you were never sure if you were going to KILL!\n\nAlso
votesHelpful: the morale in this game feels so screwed up! Your soldiers would take one hit
votesTotal: and then immediately go beserk? The last time I played xcom
votesFunny: your soldiers would only go beserk if someone DIED. In fact
commentsCount: beserking soldiers were actually pretty rare if you kept everyone alive. And even if I'm wrong on this
column16: they should fix it
column17: soldiers should not beserk or panic after getting hit once.\n\nThis game is frustrating but I feel like the workshop fixes some of it's problems."
column18: August 12, 2015

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you like the first X-Com Game from 1994.. developed by Microprose, you should buy this game. Same strategic elements, like research new captured technology, manufacture tanks, weapons and aircrafts, building and expand your bases, train your soldiers, shoot enemy vessels and infiltrate alien bases. Prepare for some challenging missions and lots of fun !

* Game supports other languages by community. ( See Goldhawk Forum )
* Coming with modding support and intigrated level-editor.
* Gameengine with Cel-Shading look and very good artwork !
* Good Music like in X-Com: Enemy Unkown, that match the situation.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the best remake of XCOM yet. I loved Enemy Unknown but it's got nothing on the original. Xenonauts is as close to an original as you can get.

So far, there are some issues regarding balance. Some battles are far too easy and aliens will flee pretty quickly but it's always being addressed. Play it on the harder difficulty and it's quite fun already and we just saw it enter beta.

The UI and graphics have been upgraded multiple time and are still being worked on. It is already extremely playable.

Xenonauts has the best micromanagement of the original with the suppression and new weapons of EU. It is the best of both worlds and, at 20 bucks, there's no reason not to own this fantastic game.

XCOM for life.

Firaxis' take on the series just left me disappointed in many ways, but this indie studio hits the nail firmly on the head.
